fields.headline: The cult of Reagan
fields.standfirst: The Reagan Legacy Project is hell-bent on securing a prominent memorial for Ronnie in the US capital. Martin Kettle in Washington argues that posterity should be doing the hard work
fields.trailText: The Reagan Legacy Project is hell-bent on securing a prominent memorial for Ronnie in the US capital. Martin Kettle in Washington argues that posterity should be doing the hard work.
fields.body:
The cult of the individual is normally part of the political culture of communist regimes or other dictatorships. But the supporters of Ronald Reagan are doing their best to install just such a cult at the heart of the world's most powerful democracy.

Not content with ensuring that Washington's domestic airport is named after their hero, or with renaming the capital city's international conference centre after him too, supporters of the former president are now poised to win congressional approval for a law that would instruct the US government to erect a Ronald Reagan memorial on the Mall, right in the centre of Washington.

The plan to honour a living politician in this way would not seem out of place in North Korea or Iraq. But it is unprecedented in all American history and it would place Reagan among the most publicly esteemed and honoured of all US leaders.

Only George Washington, who founded the nation, Thomas Jefferson, who wrote its constitution, Abraham Lincoln, who saved it, and Franklin Roosevelt, who led it through economic depression and world war, have been thought worthy enough to merit national memorials on the Mall.

In each case however, the memorials to these presidents were only proposed, approved and erected long after their deaths and after later generations had had time to weigh the leaders' long-term legacy more dispassionately than their immediate contemporaries could trust themselves to do.

The Washington Monument was not begun until 1848. Work on the Lincoln Memorial began in 1912. Authorisation for the Jefferson Memorial was enacted in 1934, while the Roosevelt Memorial was opened only in 1997. In each case, nearly half a century had passed since the death of the memorialised president - and more than a century in the case of Jefferson.

The idea that Reagan is uniquely entitled to more privileged treatment is bizarre. Now stricken with Alzheimer's, Reagan was a personally charming president whose principal achievement was to make a generation of Americans feel good about themselves.

His substantive legacy is much harder to quantify, and the idea that he should be numbered among these other indisputably historic leaders - and in his own lifetime too - owes nothing to consensus or objectivity, and everything to a fanatical campaign among conservative Republicans determined to raise Reagan into this select company.

The Reagan Legacy Project, which has its headquarters in Washington, states without any qualification that "Ronald Reagan was America's greatest president". Its aim is to ensure "naming something significant after President Reagan in each of the 50 states and in every county of America."

Among the achievements it claims so far are everything from a US Navy aircraft carrier, the USS Ronald Reagan, which is due for completion in 2002, to the Ronald Reagan Fundamental school in Yuma, Arizona.

Other commemorations include the Ronald Reagan professorship at California's Pepperdine University, the college which invited the former independent counsel Kenneth Starr to become its principal, and the Ronald Reagan Foundation for Conservative Studies at the Texas A&M University in Bryan, Texas, also home to the George Bush Presidential library.

Some supporters of the project make clear that they will not be truly content until they have had a head of President Reagan added to the Mount Rushmore monument in the Black Hills of South Dakota, where Presidents Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt are commemorated.

To achieve their goal of a Reagan memorial on the Mall, Republicans have drafted a bill which brushes aside all existing procedures and checks and balances for commemorations in the capital. Until now, proposals for memorials have had to be submitted to three separate federal commissions for consideration and - in some cases - rejection.

The most recently accepted memorial under this procedure is one in honour of Martin Luther King, the design for which was unveiled this week. But the commissions have already warned against the danger of a proliferation of monuments in the US capital, and have agreed to a moratorium, designed in part to protect existing vistas, but also to slow the politicisation of the process, of which the Reagan memorial is now the prime exhibit.

The Reagan memorial bill bypasses these commissions, putting the whole issue in the hands of a Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission. The objective is as clear as it would be if this were Pyongyang or Baghdad rather than Washington. No disagreements, no delays, no doubts are to be tolerated. Dissent is un-American.

The continuing Republican cult of Reagan bears many similarities - though the American version is much more enduring - to Britain's supposed love affair with Margaret Thatcher at the same period. Paradoxically, though, the Reagan cult was given fresh energy by the election of Bill Clinton in 1992, an event which appalled conservatives and made them more determined than ever to ensure that their own years of triumph were not forgotten.

One day, believe it or not, there will be plans for a Clinton monument in Washington. Even to imagine the theme - and the shape - of such a memorial is to open up a subject best kept closed at present. But it is as powerful a vindication as one could wish for of the old system that the Republicans are trying to overthrow. Decisions about such commemorations are best left to the judgment of later generations.

webTitle: Uefa Cup: Leicester 1 - 1 Red Star Belgrade

fields.headline: Red Star have the firepower to blow hole in Leicester hopes
fields.standfirst: Taggart 43 | Acimovic 1
fields.trailText:
Leicester 1 - 1 Red Star Belgrade
Leicester still do not know where they are going for the second leg, but last night they lost their direction even at home when confronted by a well organised and highly skilled Red Star side.
fields.body:
Leicester still do not know where they are going for the second leg, but last night they lost their direction even at home when confronted by a well organised and highly skilled Red Star side.

The best that could be said was that they finished strongly after Stevo Glogovac was sent off for a second bookable tackle with quarter of an hour left. The finish though was not strong enough.

Stan Collymore, receiving from Muzzy Izzet, saw his shot from four yards blocked by Aleksandar Kocic and in the closing moments both Collymore and the keeper were booked when tempers flared.

Things could not have begun more badly for Leicester after Red Star supporters lit flares which held up the kick-off. As the smoke cleared, before a minute was on the clock Red Star were ahead. No one picked up Milenko Acimovic, who advanced to within 35 yards of goal and released a scorching shot that cleared Tim Flowers and dipped under the bar. It was the first time Flowers had been beaten in open play this season.

Acimovic, the only Slovenian among Yugoslavs, is nominally the playmaker but by the ninth minute he had almost managed an encore, shooting narrowly past the post with Flowers scrambling. By the 13th Robbie Savage had been booked for a dreadful challenge on him. No one had thought to guarantee the visiting players' safety here.

Neil Lennon had heartened Leicester before the start by passing a fitness test on his shoulder which enabled them to keep their preferred line-up. With Izzet he was crucial, holding the show together, a ruddy outlet for defenders under pressure and a constant source of inventiveness in attack. But it was Red Star who were bossing the midfield, Leicester who, unusually, were chasing.

In reaching second place in the Premiership, Leicester's front two had scored twice in five games, and that was with abundant possession. In their desperation now City looked more than ever to set-pieces and midway through the first half Matt Elliott flicked on Steve Guppy's in-swinging free-kick and Kocic could only palm it away for a corner.

But on the half-hour Acimovic picked out Goran Drulic's run and Elliott and Flowers were both in two minds as to who should close him down. Neither did and the striker's shot looped over the bar.

If there was a sigh of relief then there was a roar of the same just before half-time as Leicester got back on terms. Typically the goal came from a defender, Guppy gathering confidence in his ability to fleece men as he doubled back to cross and Gerry Taggart beat Kocic with a flicked header.

The stage was set for Collymore, who replaced Andy Impey, and Leicester slipped to a 4-4-2 with Guppy and Darren Eadie dropping back. But before they could get used to it Branko Boskovic cut open the heart of the defence and only a mis-hit byAcimovic spared Flowers.

Not until beyond the hour did Leicester recover conviction, Izzet shooting over from distance and Collymore's exchange with Ade Akinbiyi almost putting the latter past Goran Bunjevcevic, the last defender.

That was a signal for Richard Cresswell to make his debut, in place of Akinbiyi, but it looked increasingly as if Leicester's only consolation would be that they are not going to Belgrade for the second leg.

Leicester City (3-5-2): Flowers; Rowett, Elliott, Taggart; Impey (Collymore, h-t), Savage, Lennon, Izzet, Guppy; Akinbiyi (Creswell, 65min), Eadie.

Red Star Belgrade (3-5-2): Kocic; Lalatovic, Bunjevcevic, Glogovac; Markovic, Acimovic, Lerinc, Boskovic, Vitakic; Pjanovic, Drulic.

Referee: T Henning (Ovrebo, Nor).

webTitle: Euro on ropes as rescue attempt ruled out

fields.headline: Euro on ropes as rescue attempt ruled out
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Europe's single currency remained under pressure on the foreign exchanges last night after the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, all but ruled out the chances of a rescue attempt being launched at next week's meeting of the G7 industrial nations.
fields.body:
Europe's single currency remained under pressure on the foreign exchanges last night after the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, all but ruled out the chances of a rescue attempt being launched at next week's meeting of the G7 industrial nations.

Speaking after the ECB decided to keep interest rates in the 11-nation eurozone on hold at 4.5%, Mr Duisenberg said the chances of an international agreement along the lines of the Louvre and Plaza accords of the 1980s which shored up the dollar were not high.

"I know what the agenda is for Prague and I know what the agenda is for the G7 meeting and the point you mentioned is not on the agenda," Mr Duisenberg told a reporter.

The euro, which earlier this week fell to a record low of below 86 cents against the US dollar, had earlier rallied on hopes that the ECB was about to take on the dealers who have shaved 27% from its value since it was introduced in January last year.

Ahead of its interest-rate decision, the currency gained more than a cent after the central bank said it was buying euros with the interest it had earned on its forex reserves since January 1999.

ECB insistence that the purchases were not to be viewed as intervention led to the euro falling back to just above 86 cents at the close.

fields.headline: Nickels and dimes
fields.standfirst:
After a long period of stability the pound has fallen to its lowest rate against the dollar for 14 years

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: While ministers have been battling to limit fallout from the fuel crisis, they have been able to take some consolation from having avoided the bane of all previous Labour administrations: a good old-fashioned sterling crisis.
fields.body:
While ministers have been battling to limit fallout from the fuel crisis, they have been able to take some consolation from having avoided the bane of all previous Labour administrations: a good old-fashioned sterling crisis.

Indeed, to the extent that Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have had a problem with the pound it has been that it has been too strong rather than too weak. A rising currency makes exports dearer and the government has been given a fearful earbashing by manufacturers over the past couple of years about lost orders, declining profitability and job losses.

But while ministers are aware of the problems caused to exporters by sterling, they would prefer to be in their current predicament rather than the one the Tories were in eight years ago today, when George Soros was preparing for the speculative attack that blew the pound out of the exchange rate mechanism. On the plus side, the strength of the pound has lowered the cost of imports - adding to the purchasing power of consumers - and helped keep the lid on inflation. Although they are wary of admitting it, the government quite likes a strong pound. Given the political torture that was inflicted on Labour as a result of the financial crises in 1931, 1949, 1967 and 1976, this is not surprising.

But recent developments on the foreign exchanges may well have sent a tremor through Whitehall. Over the past month, sterling has not been strong at all. It has been so weak in fact that in the league table of 54 global currencies produced by Bloomberg, the pound was propping up the rest in 54th place.

The public has yet to wake up to the fact that sterling's downward lurch has occurred primarily against the US dollar rather than against the euro - which itself has been going through another weak phase. However, sterling's weakness has certainly been noticed by dealers in the City and other global financial centres, because it has brought to an end a prolonged period in which sterling has not moved against the greenback. Since the election in May 1997, the pound has appreciated sharply against European currencies but held rock-steady against the dollar, trading in a 6% range around a central value of $1.55.

That era now seems to have come to an end. The pound slipped quietly below $1.50 against the dollar in August, and earlier this week fell below $1.40, its lowest level in 14 years. Even in the aftermath of Black Wednesday the pound managed to keep its head just above $1.40. Yesterday the pound was trading at around $1.41.

This downward move is long overdue. Although the UK economy has been doing well since 1992, it has not been doing as well as the American, which is attracting huge flows of capital that are boosting the value of the dollar. "The evidence does suggest the pound should be in a lower range against the US dollar. UK economic performance, in terms of growth and productivity, does not compare with that in the US," says Tony Norfield of City firm ABN-AMRO. "UK productivity growth is trending at around 2.5% compared to the recent 5%-plus numbers for the US."

In addition, interest rates in the UK are below those in the US and the last occasion this happened for any sustained period - in the mid-1980s - sterling was trading at around its current levels against the dollar.

The combination of the pound's weakness against the dollar and its over-valuation against the euro means that industry is currently suffering the worst of both worlds. Most UK imports of fuel and raw materials are priced in dollars, so a falling pound adds to industry's costs. But the strength of the pound against the euro means it is hard to export to euroland.

The size and speed of capital flows in liberalised markets mean that once dealers scent blood they can send currencies plunging with alarming swiftness. And even before money was free to move around the globe, the pound had some sticky moments.

As Nick Parsons of Commerzbank put it: "The history of sterling crises is that they happen suddenly and extend further than ever thought imaginable."

Some analysts therefore believe that sterling has a lot further to fall against the dollar and might be trading at around $1.25 within a few weeks. In such circumstances, the Bank of England would consider whether to defend the pound with higher interest rates. With the economy showing signs of slowing and an election looming, Mr Parsons said the chances of "defending the pound with a rate rise are close to zero. After all, if 15% did not save sterling in 1992, then a hike from 6% will do nothing today."

But if tighter domestic monetary policy is unlikely to prevent further sterling weakness against the dollar, then international events just might. The United States is not only running a colossal and burgeoning trade deficit, but is also showing signs of slowing down. It is no longer the case that the American economy is growing rapidly while euroland is in recession; both are expanding at pretty much the same rate according to the latest data.

As a result, logic suggests that the dollar should start to fall on the foreign exchanges at some point soon - and that the euro will be the main beneficiary. In a perfect world, the pound would then rise against the dollar to around $1.50 but fall against the single currency to the equivalent of three German marks. But it is not a perfect world and there could be more choppy water ahead for sterling.

Larry Elliott is the Guardian's economics editor

larry.elliott@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Spirits from South Africa
fields.standfirst:
Crossing
Riverside Studios, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Crossing
Riverside Studios, London

Rating: ***
fields.body:
Few people in Britain know more of South African theatre than the work of Johannesburg's Market Theatre and the apartheid liberation plays of Athol Fugard. This is an enjoyable drama written by the country's most prolific contemporary playwright, Reza de Wet, its subject the liberation of the soul.

It is 1930. In the isolated north of South Africa two sisters, the severe Hermien and hump-backed Sussie, live in a cottage by a fast-flowing river, offering travellers refuge and warning of the dangers of trying to cross the river when it is high. The sisters see it as their duty to retrieve and bury the bodies of those who fail to take heed, not least because they are haunted by the restless spirits of those who do not find rest in a named grave.

So it proves with Ezmeralda, the beautiful, unstable assistant of a hypnotist, The Maestro, who drags her unwillingly around the country putting on shows for the rough mining communities of "diggers" who are chasing their own dreams of gold. Twenty years previously, the pair stopped by the cottage on a wild night, ignored Hermien's advice not to cross the river and disappeared into the water. Now Ezmeralda's wailing is keeping the sisters awake at night.

De Wet's play shows how the past influences the present as the sisters' seance raises the spirits of the dead and different variations on the theme of love, dependency, hate and the desire to escape are played out by the four characters.

One of the best things about the evening is the way in which de Wet makes the characters so multi-faceted. The Maestro is truly monstrous, and yet in touching Sussie's hump, a deformity much despised by her sister, and telling her "you have wings there, but very tightly folded", he offers both the kindness and the idea of escape that have been lacking in her life.

This is a domestic drama -sometimes, in this somewhat uneven production, something of a melodrama - and some of the play's meanings remain obstinately hidden. But de Wet writes with tremendous power, creating a world both familiar and out-of-kilter, ordinary and magical, and whose surface is like that of a deceptively calm river under which terrible currents rage.

Until September 30. Box office: 020-8237 1111.

The sisters see it as their duty to retrieve and bury the bodies of those who fail to take heed, not least because they are haunted by the restless spirits of those who do not find rest in a named grave. So it proves with Ezmeralda, the beautiful, unstable assistant of a hypnotist, The Maestro, who drags her unwillingly around the country putting on shows for the rough mining communities of "diggers" who are chasing their own dreams of gold. Twenty years previously, the pair stopped by the cottage on a wild night, ignored Hermien's advice not to cross the river and disappeared into the water. Now Ezmeralda's wailing is keeping the sisters awake at night. De Wet's play shows how the past influences the present as the sisters' seance raises the spirits of the dead and different variations on the theme of love, dependency, hate and the desire to escape are played out by the four characters. One of the best things about the evening is the way in which de Wet makes the characters so multi-faceted. The Maestro is truly monstrous, and yet in touching Sussie's hump, a deformity much despised by her sister, and telling her "you have wings there, but very tightly folded", he offers both the kindness and the idea of escape that have been lacking in her life. This is a domestic drama -sometimes, in this somewhat uneven production, something of a melodrama - and some of the play's meanings remain obstinately hidden. But de Wet writes with tremendous power, creating a world both familiar and out-of-kilter, ordinary and magical, and whose surface is like that of a deceptively calm river under which terrible currents rage. Until September 30. Box office: 020-8237 1111.

fields.headline: Exchange bosses rebuked
fields.standfirst: Management team holds on to jobs by skin of the teeth
fields.trailText: Angry shareholders delivered an unprecedented rebuke to the London Stock Exchange yesterday - attempting to eject the chief executive in a torrent of criticism over aborted plans to merge with its German rival.
fields.body:
Angry shareholders delivered an unprecedented rebuke to the London Stock Exchange yesterday - attempting to eject the chief executive in a torrent of criticism over aborted plans to merge with its German rival.

In a dramatic twist in the 200-year-old exchange's history, Gavin Casey, the chief executive, narrowly survived, securing only 56% of shareholders' votes in a secret ballot.

Earlier in the day, Mr Casey's fate appeared to be sealed after a sea of purple cards emerged from a show of hands in the exchange's first annual meeting as a public company. This vote would have meant that Mr Casey would have not been re-elected - a stark departure from the style of the old-boy network which has rallied around the exchange in the past.

Pinstripe-suited stockbrokers politely waited their turn to speak. Michael Savory, director of HSBC Bank Stockbrokers, said: "The exchange has become an embarrassment". Sir David Rowe-Ham, director of brokerage Brewin Dolphin, said it was time for "certain people to fall on their swords". Mr Casey kept quiet.

The 300 shareholders attending the crowded meeting forced embarrassing secret ballots on the re-election of directors Don Cruickshank, the chairman of the exchange, and Michael Marks, who runs Merrill Lynch. The men, who scraped through the show of hands, survived with the backing of 66% and 73% of the voters respectively.

One shareholder described the knife-edge votes as a protest, another as putting the directors on probation.

Mr Cruickshank, who had earlier told the hostile audience that he was a "not a quitter", said he saw the vote as mandate to continue.

He admitted that the Stock Exchange was reviewing the role of its advisers, who include Merrill Lynch - Mr Marks's company.

He said the exchange would not hide behind the 4.9% cap on shareholding stakes - effectively barring a takeover - to fight off the £800m hostile bid by OM of Sweden and would call a shareholder meeting to scrap the rule. "The London Stock Exchange, your company, is not up for sale," he told the meeting.

He would not say whether he had confidence in Mr Casey, citing the takeover code rules under which the exchange is battling to "see off" the audacious OM bid.

Brian Winterflood, chairman of the specialist stockbroking firm Winterflood Securities, called for the appointment of a new chief executive who needed to be "young, aggressive, computer literate, a whiz-kid" from the stockbroking community.

Mr Casey, who has overseen a rapid rise in the volume of share trading at the exchange, slipped away from the meeting after sitting stony-faced during the 90 minutes of hostility.

Shareholders at the crowded meeting, attended by some of the grandest members of the City establishment, suggested replacements for Mr Casey. Among those listed were Brian Williamson, chairman of Liffe, the futures and options exchange.

Angela Knight, chief executive of Apcims which represents the small brokers, described the meeting as a "sea-change" in the history of the exchange. Of the result of the secret ballot, she said: "It's a very close call. A lot of this is about confidence. Anyone at the meeting will be very surprised that he's been elected."

fields.headline: Retailers hail spending spree
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's hard-pressed retailers are seeing the first signs of a let-up in the long period of deflation in the high street after consumers embarked on a summer spending spree last month.
fields.body:
Britain's hard-pressed retailers are seeing the first signs of a let-up in the long period of deflation in the high street after consumers embarked on a summer spending spree last month.

Despite a bounce back in prices after the July sales, the volume of business in shops and stores rose by an unexpectedly brisk 0.6% in August and was 4% up on a year earlier, according to figures from the office for national statistics.

Clothing and footwear outlets, supermarkets, household goods retailers and department stores all enjoyed buoyant trading conditions, with consumers showing less resistance to attempts by retailers to widen profit margins.

Although this week's inflation figures showed that the annual increase in the cost of living (excluding mortgage payments) is well below the government's 2.5% target, the clothing group Next said that the two-year period of price deflation in the high street was coming to an end.

The ONS data showed that the volume of retail sales in the three months to August was 1.1% higher than in the previous quarter and 4.2% up on the June to August period of 1999.

Richard Iley, economist at ABN-AMRO, said the surge in spending ran counter to the Bank of England's desire to see private spending ease back to accommodate Chancellor Gordon Brown's boost to public spending. "Far from slowing, consumer demand is still growing comfortably above its long-term trend of 2.5%."

However, Graham Turner, at GFC Economics, said there was no clear evidence to indicate that higher growth led to higher inflation. The next interest rate move was still more likely to be a reduction.

fields.headline: Blasts from the past
fields.standfirst:
Action Spectacular
Monarch, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Action Spectacular
Monarch, London

Rating: **
fields.body:
"Spectaculars" rarely live up to their name. When you expect fireworks, you get rain. Action Spectacular have been much lauded, but waiting for them to begin their live London debut it is easy to wonder whether their choice of moniker was wise.

The Sheffield-based five-piece are known for their wacky stunts. Singer Jim Muir and co arrive wearing baggy suits, seaside comedy glasses and wide grins, so we're not disappointed. Well, those of us who find baggy suits and silly glasses amusing aren't. And Muir is certainly pleased with himself, standing with his arms in the air, an all-conquering hero.

"Good evening, Castle Donnington!" he proclaims, as a slab of funk plays behind him. Then it's straight into a spoken intro paying homage to Elvis and the 70s in an early morning voice. It's gruff and off-key. But then Action Spectacular pride themselves on their quirkiness. General Lee begins as a gentle nursery rhyme before jumping into deep indie-pop territory, jangly guitars against a jaunty country melody.

It's as if Britpop never died, with shades of the Charlatans and the vaudeville side of Blur backing up a lyrical style that Jarvis Cocker copyrighted in 1994. "We are the new Menswear, except better looking," says Muir.

Except Action Spectacular can play. Bassist Paul Flaherty stands sideways, rocking backwards and forwards, a danger to both himself and guitarist Martin Hirons, who's perilously close to him. Paul Galpin adds some Happy Mondays-style psychedelia with his keyboards - and it's in this stoner's paradise that the band work best.

The problem is that they're besotted with their record collections and too eager to please too many people. As the laid-back charm of Music in the Sun gives way to the embittered rant of Half Empty Bottle, Action Spectacular cease to be interesting, despite an on-off light show and some impassioned playing. Although the punky Roxy Music will go down well with the cheap cider on student night, it's already past its sell-by date. Muir clearly believes his band are the future of rock'n'roll. But they're too much like the Stone Roses' second album for that.

fields.headline: Virtual Internet triples turnover
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Virtual Internet, the domain name, brand and trademark protection group run by Jason Drummond, one of Britain's wealthiest "e-preneurs", has reported a dramatic increase in turnover despite a delay in releasing one of its most promising products.
fields.body:
Virtual Internet, the domain name, brand and trademark protection group run by Jason Drummond, one of Britain's wealthiest "e-preneurs", has reported a dramatic increase in turnover despite a delay in releasing one of its most promising products.

The AIM-listed company saw a 355% increase in turnover for the nine months to July 31 compared with the 10 months to the same date in 1999.

Turnover rose from just under £1m to £4.1m with gross profit margins up 65%.

A cash reserve of £21.7m contributed to a positive forecast, as did the debut of Nomodo, a product that allows automated domain name registration. The company warned in June that Nomodo's appearance would be delayed.

Shares in the company fell 34% from 950p to 213p after Nomodo was delayed. They climbed yesterday by 15.5p to 230p as prospects for the full year improved.

Virtual Internet recently undertook a review of its international operations resulting in a management restructure. Previous results statements acknowledged difficulties in the international area.

Group clients include Royal Sun Alliance, Reuters and Channel Four. The number of domains managed by the company has tripled from 25,000 in October 1999 to 73,000 this July.

fields.headline: Logging on and dropping off
fields.standfirst: My last client was sacked for looking at dull websites, an employment tribunal writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: My last client was sacked for looking at dull websites, an employment tribunal writes.
fields.body:
"I was a paratrooper. I am trained not to surrender."

I am trying not to look at Jim, my client , in a manner which could be construed as sceptical. True, he is shorter and slighter than me but I suppose he could be unexpectedly wiry under his suit. He also has the slightly translucent almost luminescent flesh of a person who has worked for a long time in a large open plan office with fluorescent strip lighting and no windows - like those glow-in-the-dark plastic toys that sometimes come in cereal packets or the white tuberous parts of neglected pot plants.

I am trying to visualise him a sort of barbecue brown with combat stripes and a helmet with greenery in it. It's not working.

Jim has just been offered £1500 by his ex-employers to settle his case. This is what we call a nuisance offer. It has occurred to Jim's ex-employers that it would be cheaper to give him £1500 than to carry on fighting his case. This probably struck them when everyone arrived at the tribunal to discover that the case was "floating".

This means that although our case is listed to be heard today, no tribunal has actually been allocated to hear it. So we have to "float" around waiting for a tribunal to come free because someone else has settled their case or finished it very quickly.

But it is now 11:30 and Jim and I are still sat in the waiting room with the clammy dregs of our coffee and not much left to say to each other. It has probably just struck Jim's ex-employers that even if we get a tribunal now, we are unlikely to finish the case in the remains of the day, which will mean coming back another day and more legal costs.

Whereas Jim doesn't have to worry about that kind of thing because I am doing his case pro bono. So he can afford to be a paratrooper.

I think the £1500 is attractive. And not just because I want to get away from Jim. Jim was dismissed by his employers for excessive use of the internet when he was supposed to be working. Our best point is that Jim, unlike I suspect most bored surfers, was not looking at hotchicks.com or pussytown.com or any other sort of porn. Jim was looking at some very dull stuff. I've seen the logs. Jim spent over an hour looking at avocado recipes on one occasion. At other times he conducted searches on

 his mother's maiden name  various cricket players  verrucas

There are hundreds more. There are hundreds of pages of these logs. Taken together they are somehow intimate and awful - an appalling record of days and weeks of dullness and Jim's response to it. I feel like I've looked into Jim's brain.

Personally I think his employers have got a point when they say that Jim couldn't have been doing very much work. But Jim, as he says, was a paratrooper. So when they send us away tribunal-less at 12:30, Jim has not accepted the £1500 and we live to fight another day. Never surrender.

webTitle: A lifelong problem for you, Darling

fields.headline: A lifelong problem for you, Darling
fields.standfirst:
Minister faces social insecurity

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Social security minister Alistair Darling made a hasty exit from yesterday's presentation on occupational pension schemes. With the fuel crisis, an overhaul of the minimum funding requirement probably ranks about 932nd on the cabinet's list of priorities.
fields.body:
Social security minister Alistair Darling made a hasty exit from yesterday's presentation on occupational pension schemes. With the fuel crisis, an overhaul of the minimum funding requirement probably ranks about 932nd on the cabinet's list of priorities.

Yet the lowly MFR has enormous implications, not only for members of company pension schemes - 12.5m of us - but for financial markets and ultimately for the health of the economy. Change the basis of the MFR and you change how almost £1,000bn in pension fund money is invested. Take the long end of the gilts market. The workings of the MFR and the lack of new gilts issuance has created a terrific squeeze on 15-year plus gilts, driving yields down to levels lower than almost anywhere outside of Japan.

True, it has made pension funds more secure, but at the cost of lower returns to pensioners and higher costs to employers, which was not quite the thinking behind the MFR when it was introduced after the Maxwell crisis.

Pension funds have been gasping for the DSS to give them some relief from the MFR squeeze on gilts. Yesterday no concrete proposals emerged - the DSS wants a further consultation period - but it is clear that a much anticipated switch to a new basis for valuing future liabilities, using higher yielding corporate bonds, is on the cards. As Barclays Capital said, nobody was selling corporate bonds in the City yesterday.

But a switch to corporate bonds, although easing the distortions caused by the MFR so far, does not come at an auspicious time.

The £22bn mobile phone licences auction in Britain, and its replication across Europe, promises a flood of new corporate bond issuance of possibly dubious quality.

The DSS also warns of a risk that investment distortions will simply show up elsewhere, with pension funds potentially switching out of not just gilts but also equities to go into corporate bonds. This hardly ties in with the government's attempts to encourage the City to invest in start-ups and venture capital.

More immediately, interim proposals to shore up the MFR include a 6.5% increase in employers' contributions to cover the fact that pensioners are now expected to live two years longer than when the actuaries developed the MFR in 1995. That equates to an extra £700m that companies will have to cough up to support their schemes.

The National Association of Pension Funds believes that this will not deter finance directors from supporting final salary schemes. Their confidence may be misplaced if the economy goes into a downturn. The DSS proposals are silent on the future security of final salary schemes. If the government is truly committed to secure, quality pensions, it should be bringing forward proposals to either support final salary schemes or ban employers from switching to money purchase schemes unless they match the benefits. Mr Darling's work is far from finished.

LSE farce
The poll results from yesterday's meeting of shareholders in the London Stock Exchange amount to a serious clout on the head for board members of this befuddled institution.

In the world of business - and this is supposed to be a business - directors do not hold on to their jobs on a simple majority basis. They can only continue to manage with the consensual backing of the owners.

For Gavin Casey, the chief executive, a 44% vote against his continued tenure says he should either make sure his pension arrangements are in order or get another job.

It is probable the only reason he is still there is that his colleagues do not know who to hire in his place. It is all very sad, as well as farcical.

e-nonsense
With technology stocks back in fashion again and the markets mumbling about a fresh wave of flotations in the e-business sector this autumn, net surfers weary at the prospect of a new stream of e-jargon should point their browsers at Dack.com.

The site includes a so-called Web Economy Bullshit Generator, where the press of a button labelled "make bullshit" produces a wonderful flow of new economy nonsense.

You can seize "vertical initiatives", while continuing to drive "efficient schemas", or simply "synergizing distributed paradigms".

At the end of the day, we are talking about "embracing cross-media deliverables" here.

The button-pressing quickly becomes addictive, users will find.

For internet consultancies this website could prove to be an industry killer. For business commentators, the day of the stick and paste Financial Notebook may finally have arrived.

webTitle: Employers to find another £700m a year for pensions

fields.headline: Employers to find another £700m a year for pensions
fields.standfirst:
Life expectancy dictates overhaul

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's employers will have to find an extra £700m a year to fund pensions because people are living much longer, the Department of Social Security warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's employers will have to find an extra £700m a year to fund pensions because people are living much longer, the Department of Social Security warned yesterday.

The extra burden is part of a sweeping overhaul proposed by the DSS yesterday of the "minimum funding requirement", or MFR, introduced in 1995 Pensions Act to protect the 12.5m people in company pension schemes after Robert Maxwell plundered £400m from the Mirror's schemes.

New mortality figures suggest that pensioners are now expected to live two years longer than thought in 1995, increasing the pension burden for employers by 6.5%.

But actuaries said the extra cost may further accelerate moves by employers to ditch final salary pension schemes in favour of pay-as-you-go "money purchase" schemes, where benefits to pensioners are often much lower.

However, the DSS stepped back from implementing immediate changes to the MFR in favour of further consultation, delaying new rules until at least 2002. It also indicated that it may abandon the MFR entirely, opting instead for an insurance-based scheme.

The DSS welcomed proposals in an Institute of Actuaries report for a change in the calculation basis for future pension liabilities amid concern that they have created a squeeze in the gilts market and pushed yields to artificially low levels.

City analysts had expected the IoA to recommend wider use of top grade corporate bonds but were surprised yesterday when the proposals went further and included all investment grade bonds.

"No one will be selling corporate bonds today," said Barclays Capital, but Deutsche Bank said that the proposals will be negative for holders of long-term gilts.

 CGNU yesterday admitted that it has made a multimillion-pound error with a pension fund. It has discovered a £15m overvaluation of one of its funds which contains the pension savings of company and local authority workers. It described the mistake an "isolated admin error" which has already been rectified at a cost of £135,000. "No one will lose out as a result of this mistake," said a spokesman.

He said the mistake happened in June and July of this year but had only been spotted within the last month.

"There was an isolated failure in the administrative system involved in the pricing of units in the fund. It is impossible to say how many have been affected because the fund is designed for institutional investors, not private individuals, though obviously private individuals have money in those pension funds," he said.

CGNU could not say whether the matter had been reported to the Financial Services Authority.

fields.headline: Driven with urgency
fields.standfirst:
The Car Man
The Old Vic, London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
The Car Man
The Old Vic, London

Rating: ****
fields.body:
After three months on the road, Adventures in Motion Pictures' latest show, The Car Man, has arrived in London, playing at the theatre that from 2002 will be its resident base.

Last night, as the curtain opened on the production's arrestingly sleazy opening scene, it was clear that the company have found a good home. The Old Vic may offer more cramped conditions than, for instance, Sadler's Wells, but it has a slightly seedy intimacy, a lineage of lively theatrical ghosts that will serve the company well.

AMP are not a ballet company who insist on a grand setting, or a modernist dance group who look best in a plain frame. They are a uniquely motley troupe of dance actors whose inventive, sometimes shockingly direct body language is famous for getting under the skin of the characters they portray and whose effects become more vivid the closer they are seen.

Certainly in The Car Man the characters' skins are visibly crawling with sweat, lust and tension. In this reimagining of Bizet's Carmen, 19th-century Spain has been relocated to mid-20th-century America; the cigarette factory has become a greasy garage-diner and the original story of cuckoldry, murder and lust has been notched up several gears. Replacing the gypsy heroine are a pair of lawlessly erotic lovers, a charismatic drifter called Luca and the siren wife of the elderly garage owner, and as in AMP's cult hit Swan Lake the plot is complicated by several twists of gender and sexual orientation.

Also part of the mix are the thriller conventions of film noir and the intransigent Fates of Greek tragedy, but what is impressive is not only the controlled tension of director Matthew Bourne's storytelling but the close-up detail of his characterisation.

The disintegration of Angelo, the story's gentle victim, from fastidious loner to flayed psycho is riveting, particularly as played by the excellent Will Kemp, while Luca (Alan Vincent) is an intriguingly unglossy hero, who has the aura of a dangerous past. In their duets the interplay of violence and desire becomes so combustible you flinch from the heat

There are still problems with the show that the touring period has not ironed out, notably that the women's choreography does not equal the men's in complexity and glamour. But in other areas the timing seems tighter and the choreography finessed. With Lez Brotherston's set defining a brilliantly louche and period atmosphere, The Car Man drives with an urgency that at moments has our nerves and hearts at full stretch.

Until December 9. Box office: 020-7369 1762.
This review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Frank Keating on Chelsea ans Vialli

fields.headline: Managing to fall off the Bridge
fields.trailText: Arrivederci Luca. Ciao Baldie. Suddenly the only surprise about Gianluca Vialli's sacking by Chelsea was that it came as a surprise.
fields.body:
Arrivederci Luca. Ciao Baldie. Suddenly the only surprise about Gianluca Vialli's sacking by Chelsea was that it came as a surprise.

Sure, one win in five is not the way to start a season when you so struttingly fancy yourselves in the big league. But more crucially, methinks, nice Signor Slaphead wantonly ignored the most basic tenet of sports-team management, laid down half a century ago by Casey Stengel of the New York Yankees: "The job is a cinch. All you have to do is keep the five players who hate your guts away from the five who are undecided."

Chelsea's past is littered with disunity. But in a way their recent history fulfils rewardingly theatrical dramatic unities: the previous manager Ruud Gullit, obsessed with selection by rotation, drops one-time friend and favourite striker Vialli; exit Gullit, enter Vialli, who drops one-time friend and favourite striker Gianfranco Zola; exit Vialli.

Zola yesterday shrugged off the very idea of his assuming command, fitting though it might have been given the capricious burlesque which has forever swirled around Stamford Bridge's egocentric ringmaster Ken Bates. The rest of English football is enjoying the revels immensely; to them Chelsea's whole raison d'etre is to be too big for their boots.

It will be intriguing to see which way Bates jumps now. With comparative speed, beginning with Glenn Hoddle, he has appointed three successive player-managers - a rare figure at the top of English football. Does Bates find inexperienced managers more pliable, more amenable to his dominant personality? (You could see the grey beard bristle and he would stroke and preen with pleasure whenever Vialli addressed him as "Il Presidente".)

But to be sure, what the businessman Bates does know about football is that you cannot guarantee to fill £1m corporate hospitality boxes to watch an itsy-bitsy temperamental team playing in the bottom half of the Premiership.

So where might he turn now, apart from the usual suspects Terry Venables and George Graham? Another player-manager plucked, literally, out of the blue from the Bridge's towering Babel might be flattered, as the previous two were, but now he would be mighty wary too.

I remembered yesterday the snort of derision from the Milan manager Fabio Capello when Bates appointed Vialli from the ranks in 1998: "Crazy! It's like giving the keys of a Ferrari to an 18-year-old."

Nothing wrong with youth, mind you: nine of the top 10 post-war managers of English clubs (Busby, Clough, Cullis, Ferguson, Nicholson, Ramsey, Revie, Robson, Shankly and Stein) were all former players who became managers in their early or mid-30s; Clough did it at 29. But none was a player-manager.

The player-manager option has seldom worked. Kenny Dalglish seemed an obvious exception at Liverpool - but they drafted in good old Bob Paisley to help him for a year - and I remember interviewing him at Anfield in his first season when he was greatly worried "because Phil Neal, who I think expected the job himself, still calls me 'Kenny' and refuses to call me 'Boss'."

Shouldn't the incorrigible Bates and his incorrigible Chelsea just settle for being themselves, what they have ever been: swankpot glitterbugs who can occasionally turn it on?

That sage Yankee Stengel uttered something else relevant as Bates's Chelsea ponder a new direction. "If we're gonna win the pennant," he said. "We've gotta start thinking we're not as good as we think we are."

webTitle: Zola ruled out as Chelsea take time

fields.headline: Zola ruled out as Chelsea take time
fields.standfirst: Four in the frame
fields.trailText: Gianfranco Zola and Graham Rix were yesterday ruled out of the race to succeed Gianluca Vialli at Chelsea - but they are about the only two who were.
fields.body:
Gianfranco Zola and Graham Rix were yesterday ruled out of the race to succeed Gianluca Vialli at Chelsea - but they are about the only two who were.

The club's managing director, Colin Hutchinson, said somewhat cryptically that Chelsea were: "A continental side playing football in England and this will be reflected in the choice we make." To confuse the issue further he added that the hierarchy had not decided whether the new man should be British or from overseas.

This suggests Chelsea are looking for someone with experience of coaching on the continent, or a British manager who has enjoyed some success in Europe - not that this group runs to much beyond John Toshack and Terry Venables - to replace the sacked Vialli. Hutchinson insisted: "We are in no hurry to make an appointment."

Having lost their 2-1 favourite Zola, the bookmakers immediately installed Terry Venables as the man most likely to succeed Vialli. However, he has not managed a top club side for almost 10 years and it is not certain that Ken Bates is a great fan of his.

Another potential candidate is George Graham, but his reputation as a winner of titles has been dented by Leeds' progress since he left them and Tottenham's lack of it since he arrived. He also has a reputation as a man who dislikes dealing with the kind of star players who form the bulk of the Chelsea squad.

Other candidates who have been mentioned include Frank Rijkaard and Dino Zoff, who have both been out of work since resigning after Euro 2000.

Rijkaard would perhaps be a more likely choice than Zoff, who, in common with the similarly unemployed Arrigo Sacchi, speaks no English.

Aimé Jacquet, who took France to the World Cup triumph two years ago, has also been touted, as has Jean Tigana down the road at Fulham.

In the meantime the first-team coach Graham Rix has taken charge of team affairs. His first task is to pick a side for tonight's Uefa Cup first-round tie at home to St Gallen.

"It was sad what happened to Luca," said Rix. "I am full of admiration for him but life goes on and I am sure he will want us to win. I think the players owe it to the supporters and the club to get together and perform against St Gallen."

Hutchinson, who admitted that Vialli was his choice originally, said of Italian's sacking: "There is never a happy time for a parting but at the end of the day the club is more important than any individual. It was felt the time was right."

Hutchinson addressed the staff and players before training yesterday to try to reassure them about their futures under a new coach.

fields.headline: Four in the frame
fields.trailText: Terry Venables 10-11 fav
fields.body:
Terry Venables 10-11 fav

Pluses Respected coach, clever on tactics and forging team spirit. Won Spanish title with Barcelona in 1985 and led England to semis of Euro 96.

Minuses Allegedly doesn't get on with Ken Bates, has a murky business past and hasn't coached a top club since 1991 at Spurs. Recently Australia coach, Portsmouth chairman and Crystal Palace head coach - hardly reasons to be managing Chelsea.

Aimé Jacquet 8-1

Pluses Greatest moment two years ago when he combined a vintage crop of French players and home advantage to win the World Cup.

Minuses Happy in back-seat role as French FA's technical director. Now aged 60 is unlikely to relish the pressure of club management again. Has not managed at club level since 1989 at Bordeaux.

Dino Zoff 16-1

Pluses Impressed in Euro 2000 by taking Italy to the final. Coached at top club level with Juventus and Lazio. Not in a job at the moment.

Minuses Tactics at Euro 2000, though effective, were negative and out of keeping with Chelsea tradition. Successes as a coach at club level were limited; a Uefa cup with Juve but disappointed during his four years at Lazio. Does not speak English.

Frank Rijkaard 7-1

Pluses Produced thrilling Dutch team at Euro 2000 before losing to Italy on penalties in the semi-finals. Resigned because he felt Holland, as hosts, should have won the tournament. Recently turned down offers to coach Fenerbahce and South Africa.

Minuses Dutch coach for only two years and, at 38, relatively inexperienced, never having managed a club.

webTitle: Football: Carling to help fans to get to games

fields.headline: Carling give fans one for the road
fields.trailText: Carling, the sponsor of the Premiership, is promising to provide free coach transport for fans of clubs facing the longest trips on Saturday as the fuel crisis continues.
fields.body:
Carling, the sponsor of the Premiership, is promising to provide free coach transport for fans of clubs facing the longest trips on Saturday as the fuel crisis continues.

Supporters of Newcastle, Ipswich and Derby, who go to Southampton, Leeds and Sunderland, have been guaranteed help with their travel arrangements and Carling is anxious for other coach companies with full tanks to offer help to fans of the rest of the travelling clubs.

Carling's sponsorship manager Rob Salmon said: "The passion and loyalty of supporters is at the heart of football so we're trying to do our bit by laying on coaches to help away fans make their trip."

Premiership football supporters interested in booking tickets on the special Carling coaches are advised to call the Carling Travel Hotline on: 0207 898 3354.

Football's governing bodies have not yet decided about the viability of their weekend programmes. The Scottish Premier League will hold an emergency meeting with its 12 member clubs today to see if the weekend's five top-flight matches can go ahead.

The Celtic manager Martin O'Neill has admitted that he has spoken to his Blackburn counterpart Graeme Souness about the Israeli international Eyal Berkovic. Blackburn and the player's agent have revealed that discussions have been ongoing between the two parties.

The Football Association meanwhile has launched an inquiry into Souness's tirade against the referee Mike Jones at the end of Tuesday's 4-3 home defeat by Watford.

Souness described Jones as "inept" and a "clown", and confronted Jones at half-time and again at the end of the First Division game.

webTitle: First Division: Sheff Wed 0 - 1 Nottm Forest

fields.headline: Jewell hit hard by Lester's strike
fields.trailText: In a climate of national crisis Sheffield Wednesday remain mired in a pretty profound one of their own as they recorded their third home defeat in four league outings this season.
fields.body:
In a climate of national crisis Sheffield Wednesday remain mired in a pretty profound one of their own as they recorded their third home defeat in four league outings this season.

Defeat by a Nottingham Forest side not without their own problems may not have been as damaging as some others, but barely a month into the new season Paul Jewell's decision to swap Bradford for Wednesday this summer is an early contender for most ill-advised move of the close season.

Of the two managers affected by the inevitable early-season rumour mill, there was little doubt that Forest's David Platt was in greater need of victory and his team showed marginally more urgency in a moribund opening period.

Forest drew first blood with an excellent 34th-minute finish by Jack Lester, Sheffield-born and a childhood United fan. An excellent pass by Alan Rogers, catching Ashley Westwood out of position, reached the Forest striker on the edge of the box and a superbly-placed shot left Kevin Pressman with no chance.

The finish was out of keeping with what had been a drab first period. The England under-21 winger David Prutton was a rare exception, dominating Wednesday's left-back Ritchie Humphreys and sending a shot flashing beyond the far post midway through the half.

Jeered off the pitch by their own fans at the interval, Wednesday's hopes of a second-half revival were boosted when the Forest goalkeeper Barry Roche, starting a game for the first time, began to betray signs of nerves.

A routine Alan Quinn shot squirmed through his legs and was hacked to safety before being charged down by the substitute Gilles de Bilde. The richochet almost brought Wednesday level. But there were also warning signs from the visitors and Lester twice came close to putting the issue beyond doubt, heading inches wide before placing a shot too close to Pressman.

Sheffield Wednesday (4-4-2): Pressman; Stockdale, Westwood, Walker, Humphreys; Hamshaw, Haslam (Crane, 78), O'Donnell (Sibon, 69), Quinn; Booth, Di Piedi (Di Bilde, h-t).

Nottingham Forest (4-4-2): Roche; Louis-Jean, Edwards, Vaughan, Doig; Prutton, Bart-Williams, Johnson, Rogers; Lester, Harewood.

Referee: T Jones.

webTitle: Uefa Cup: Rapid Bucharest v Liverpool

fields.headline: Owen may be quicker than Rapid
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier and Anghel Iordanescu spent part of the summer together watching matches at Euro 2000 as members of Uefa's technical delegation. Tonight they face each other in Bucharest.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier and Anghel Iordanescu spent part of the summer together watching matches at Euro 2000 as members of Uefa's technical delegation. Tonight they have the chance to pit their tactical wits against each other in the first round of the Uefa Cup as Houllier's Liverpool team travel to the Romanian capital to meet Rapid Bucharest.

Iordanescu, the former Romanian national team manager, admits he is worried by Michael Owen's pace and he is planning special tactics to try to stop him. Owen has scored six times in Liverpool's five Premiership games this season, as well as for England against France in Paris.

"Owen seems to be in great shape, scoring key goals and making a decisive contribution to his team-mates' goals," Iordanescu said. "He is the No1 danger for us and we've tried to plan special measures to temper his actions." The Romanian international Adrian Iencsi is expected to mark Owen in the first leg at the Giulesti arena.

Houllier knows that anything other than safe passage through into the second round will reduce to untidy rubble the belief that he has, at last, fashioned a team of substance. Rapid, runners-up in the Romanian league last season, were eliminated from the Champions League in the second qualifying round 12 months ago by Skonto Riga of Latvia and things have not been going well so far this term either: two league wins and mid-table anonymity.

"We take nothing for granted," said Houllier. "They can play, we know that. They will be anxious to take something forward into the tie's second leg at Anfield. All we can do, all we can ever do, is to approach the game in a thoroughly professional manner."

Although some of that professional manner did return to Liverpool's football last Saturday when Manchester City were beaten, albeit fortuitously, Houllier remains concerned about the holes that have opened up in a defence which was the Premiership's meanest last season.

The arrival of the respected German Markus Babbel at right-back has seemingly unhinged the thin red line and the Merseysiders' cause will hardly be helped this evening by the continued absence of the injured Sami Hyypia.

Houllier is again ruing the inability of Steven Gerrard to negotiate two games in seven days; the England international will be missing with a recurring groin problem.

Robbie Fowler has travelled but will warm the substitutes' bench, possibly alongside Emile Heskey who may be sacrificed to enable Houllier to stiffen his midfield by including his latest signing Christian Ziege on the left.

Nick Barmby is likely to win favour wide on the right, which would represent a first-ever appearance in European club football for a player who has played top-flight football for four different clubs.

"It's a little strange really because whilst I've played at the very highest level for my country I have never represented any of my clubs in Europe," said Barmby. "It's what I want; this is one of the reasons I decided to leave Everton for Liverpool. I'm an ambitious man."

webTitle: Uefa Cup: Leicester v Red Star Belgrade

fields.headline: Leicester fear a Red mist
fields.trailText: Leicester return to European action tonight after a three-year absence looking more cussed than ever and hoping there are no hard feelings with Red Star from the fuss over the return leg in a fortnight, which Uefa decreed this week will not be in Belgrade.
fields.body:
Leicester return to European action tonight after a three-year absence looking more cussed than ever and hoping there are no hard feelings with Red Star from the fuss over the return leg in a fortnight, which Uefa decreed this week will not be in Belgrade.

Peter Taylor, their new manager, is not the enigmatic verbal gymnast his predecessor Martin O'Neill is but he has no trouble playing the diplomat. "It's not our fault," he said of Uefa's decision to switch the second leg to a neutral venue, "and it's probably not theirs either."

Taylor is well aware, though, of what happened when England's European Under-21 Championship match against Yugoslavia was moved from Belgrade to Barcelona in March. "The Yugoslavs were very physical that night," said Taylor, a former manager of England Under-21s. And a number of that Yugoslav side are in Red Star's ranks tonight. "If they are not disciplined," he added, "we hope we can take advantage of it."

The new manager is entitled to talk positively. Leicester, who fell at the first in 1997 when they similarly qualified through winning the League Cup and then lost both legs to Atletico Madrid, lie second in the league, unbeaten in five games. Though they have scored only four goals - and may need to step that up - Tim Flowers has been beaten only once, and that by a penalty.

They were condemned last season by at least two managers (Arsène Wenger of Arsenal and Aston Villa's John Gregory) and a chairman, Chelsea's Ken Bates, who had more reason to envy their spirit than criticise their style. With Matt Elliott sweeping and marshalling they have become devilishly difficult to penetrate, let alone rattle, despite wing-backs, Andy Impey and Steve Guppy, who are clearly more wings than backs.

For all that, their crossing, chiefly from the right, has not been good and they have let themselves down with their final ball. Guppy needs to get more often to the byline and the midfield has yet to exploit the startling pace of Ade Akinbiyi, who is still trying to link with Darren Eadie, let alone fathom Stan Collymore.

Flowers, who will play, suffered a slight groin strain on Saturday and the reserve keeper Simon Royce has a bruised foot, which may mean "one of the kids on the bench," said Taylor. But his main worry is Neil Lennon, who started the season with a suspect groin and had to be substituted at half-time on Saturday when a shoulder injury sustained the previous day in training played up. He had an injection before training yesterday and a decision on his fitness will be made today.

fields.headline: Cole hat-trick gives United lift-off
fields.standfirst: Cole 15, 49, 71, Irwin 30pen, Sheringham 41 | Koller 54
fields.trailText: Andy Cole completed a hat-trick last night as Manchester United spread their wings in a soaring start to their latest mission in the Champions League.
fields.body:
Andy Cole completed a hat-trick last night as Manchester United spread their wings in a soaring start to their latest mission in the Champions League.

Cole scored one of the three goals which had virtually settled the contest by half-time and, after accepting the gift of a second soon after the interval, looped a header beyond the Anderlecht goalkeeper's reach in the 74th minute from David Beckham's cross to the far post.

For United the Champions League is now a matter of routine, though not so much so that they could afford the assumption that the visit of the Belgian champions represented a straightforward home win. Nothing in football, let alone European football, is ever that simple.

Yet so impressive has been United's start to the season that it was difficult to see where and how Anderlecht were going to deny them a comfortable victory. For that to happen United needed to have a bad night.

In the absence of Jaap Stam, forced to sit on the bench because of a sore achilles tendon, Ferguson switched Gary Neville to central defence and played Denis Irwin at right-back with Mickael Silvestre on the left. With the height and power of Jan Koller, Anderlecht's Czech striker, an obvious threat, much depended on Ronnie Johnsen assuming Stam's air of authority in the middle.

Koller was more than just a target figure in the Anderlecht attack. Often he would drop deep to gather the ball and open up opportunities on the flanks for Bertrand Crasson or Bart Goor.

United seemed momentarily disconcerted by this, losing possession once or twice in their own half. Nevertheless the ability of Silvestre or Ryan Giggs to turn Anderlecht's defence on the left was evident from the outset and eventually produced a goal just before the quarter-hour. Giggs's centre found the defence moving up too late for offside, leaving Cole all alone to head firmly past Filip De Wilde.

Going forward Anderlecht lost nothing in determination but many of their crosses or final passes lacked the wit and accuracy seriously to trouble United's defence.

For United the game was far from won. In midfield Roy Keane and Paul Scholes were maintaining parity with Yves Vanderhaeghe and Walter Baseggio without really dominating them. Yet, whenever Giggs or Cole took on the defenders for pace, United promised another goal.

When United did increase their lead, therefore, the source was predictable. After half-an-hour Giggs, collecting a pass from Scholes, set off on an audacious run in the inside-left position which took him through several attempted tackles and into the penalty area being brought down as he was about to shoot.

Irwin's penalty gave United a comfort zone to which Beckham should soon have added an extra cushion. Giggs's centre found him unmarked to the right of goal and, although Beckham had time and space to measure his shot, he dragged the ball wide.

Fabien Barthez briefly teased Anderlecht by nearly giving a goal to the pacy Tomas Radzinski as he boldly tried to dribble the ball past the Canadian in front of the United net. But by half-time the contest had virtually been decided.

In the 40th minute United scored again, and again the goal sprang from their command of the wings. This time Beckham, found in space by Sheringham's header, delivered a low cross from the right-hand byline back to Sheringham, who failed to beat De Wilde at the first go but coolly scored from the rebound after the goalkeeper had blocked his initial shot.

Farce started to take over five minutes into the second half. As Lorenzo Staelens went to deal with a long ball from Neville there was a fearful mix-up in the Anderlecht defence which saw Cole gain easy possession and lob United's fourth goal gently past a stranded De Wilde.

Not that United's defence was immune from bathos, Koller forcing the ball past the onrushing Barthez to score for Anderlecht despite Johnsen's attempt to backheel the ball off the goal-line. While they were winning comfortably United could ill-afford to give away such sloppy goals.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin, G Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Sheringham.

Anderlecht (4-4-2): De Wilde; Crasson, Staelens, De Boeck, Dheedne; Van Diemen, Vanderhaeghe, Baseggio, Goor; Koller, Radzinski.

Referee: T Hauge (Norway).

fields.headline: Rapid Bucharest 1 - 0 Liverpool
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Rapid Bucharest: Lucescu, Stanciu, Frasineanu, Buta, Ifdovi, Constantin, Maldarasanu, Pancu, Mutica, Iencsi, Isaila. Subs: Radulescu, Chirica, Constantinovicr, Radu, Buga, Bundea, Schumacher.

Liverpool: Westerveld, Song, Henchoz, Babbel, Ziege, Barmby, Carragher, Hamann, Diomede, Owen, Heskey. Subs: Arphexad, Fowler, Murphy, Heggem, Meijer, Traore, Kippe.

Referee: N Volquartz (Denmark)

4 The early minutes see both sides trying to establish an advantage in the sweltering heat of a spookily misty stadium. Both teams look up for it and start in lively fashion. Rapid present a couple of early scares (most notably when Pancu cuts into the area, rifles in a cross-cum-shot from a shoking angle and Song clears of the line) but Liverpool take little time to settle into their rhythm.
15 Rapid come close to opening the scoring with a long range effort the narrowly clears the bar.
16 Liverpool give away their third corner of the game as Gerard Houllier's men seek to get a grip on the game. Corner comes to nothing.
18 Liverpool start to put together some good moves as Heskey feeds Diomede on the edge of the Rapid area; he lets the ball run to Owen on the right but his cross is poor.
20 Liverpool free-kick; Barmby takes and launches the ball towards Heskey, but his header flies over the bar
22 Liverpool have their best chance yet as Owen, in space 25 yards out, feeds the advancing Barmby, but his blistering drive from the edge of the area flies of the woodwork
27 The game hits a lull before Rapid attack with Maldarasanu on the right and after some scrappy passing Ziege finally gets the ball out to Heskey.
29 GOAL Rapid Bucharest 0 - 1 Liverpool Michael Owen the man of the moment, but not the scorer, as he shimmies into the area and turns two defenders before spurning the shot and sliding the ball through to Barmby on the right side of the six-yard box. Barmby makes no mistake - roof of the net.
33 A huge clearance by Westerveld finds Diomede just outside the area but he is unable to find Owen on the right.
35 Substitution Murphy on for Heskey, who took a knock early on.
37Liverpool throw to the right of the Rapid area, Murphy takes and Liverpool win a corner. Rapid clear and break with Pancu on the right, he finds Constantin but the move breaks down.
41 Frasineanu tries a long-range shot but it finds only the stand.
43 Rapid free-kick deep into the Liverpool area; the clearance finds Song out on the right. Rapid regain possession and don't give up, but the attack ends when Constantin races to beat Westerveld to the ball just inside the LIverpool area... and Westerveld wins.
45 Rapid free-kick 25 yards out square on to goal. Pancu takes straight at the wall and then hits the rebound straight into the crowd. Half-time.

47 Liverpool finished the first half looking the more likely of the two teams to walk away with the points and have the best of the early possession in the second 45.
48 Barmby gets in a cross from a Song throw but there is no-one there to meet it.
49 Another long Song throw to the edge of the area but Liverpool fail to capitalise.
51 Hamann works his way through midfield and into the area but his shot his blocked early. Barmby latches onto the rebound and hits the side netting.
52 Owen looking lively as he is fed on the edge of the Rapid area; Lucescu charges out to block as Owen tries to lift it over. Rapid not looking much of a threat so far in this half.
54 First decent move from Rapid this period as Schumacher finds Frasineau on the edge of the area, but, not for the first time, his shot is way off target.
56 Barmby tries a one-two with Murphy and wins a corner. Comes to nothing.
57 Schumacher leads the counter but Barmby gets back well to clear.
59 Liverpool pressure the Rapid half as Owen finds Barmby on the right, but Rapid keep their shape and clear.
60 Substitution Radu on for Constantin.
62 Liverpool in firm control of this game at the moment as Rapid are restricted to the counter.
63 Great move by Liverpool. Hamann, with a long clearance to Barmby on the right, sets up a sweeping break; Barmby centres and Owen shoots from the edge of the area - great save by Lucescu to tip over the bar.
66 Ziege feeds Diomede near the right by-line; the cross finds Owen in front of goal, but he fumbles his shot.
70 Booking Henchoz for foul bang on the right corner of the area. The free-kick is sliced wide of the far post.
73 Substitution Buga on for Iftovi.
75 Booking Lucescu, after he headed the ball out of play to avoid Barmby and then held on to it to prevent a quick throw.
78 Rapid free-kick after Barmby decks Schumacher; comes to nothing.
81 Substitution Fowler on for Owen. Robbie's back, looking trim.
82 Booking Radu for a blatent dive on the edge of the Liverpool area. Lucky for Henchoz as he was the player pressuring.
84 Substitution Traore on for Ziege, who looks like he has a groin strain.
87 Rapid corner from the left, but Westerveld holds comfortably.
89 Late chance for Liverpool as Murphy breaks on the right but the move breaks down after a poor cross.
90 Three minutes of stoppage time to play as the home fans start to drift away. All very scrappy now, not surprisingly, as Rapid try in vain for an equaliser and give away free-kicks. Few fans left in the stadium which is surely a sign that Liverpool have completed their task. Full-time.
Rapid Bucharest 0 - 1 Liverpool

fields.trailText: Geoffrey A Moore, 53, believes in the net. He remained bullish during the recent "corrections" in the e-economy and, on the publication of his book Living on the Fault Line, he had a few words for the traditionalists. "Old economy companies cannot use the recent sell-off [of hi-tech stocks] as an excuse for writing off the internet," he told the Wall Street Journal in July.
fields.body:
Geoffrey A Moore, 53, believes in the net. He remained bullish during the recent "corrections" in the e-economy and, on the publication of his book Living on the Fault Line, he had a few words for the traditionalists. "Old economy companies cannot use the recent sell-off [of hi-tech stocks] as an excuse for writing off the internet," he told the Wall Street Journal in July.

As managing director of the Chasm Group, a Silicon Valley consultant, Mr Moore has been an expert (or in its preferred parlance "guru") on the new economy since its inception. His first book, Crossing the Chasm (1991), introduced the idea of a gap or "chasm" which innovative companies must cross to reach the lucrative mainstream market. The sequel, Inside the Tornado (1995), shows how to capitalise on the potential for "hypergrowth" beyond the chasm.

Before founding the Chasm Group in 1992, Mr Moore was a partner at hi-tech marketing company Regis McKenna, and in the 1980s was a sales and marketing executive at three different software companies. On his way to the new economy he took bachelor's degree from Stanford University and a PhD from the University of Washington (both in literature) and served as an English professor at Olivet college.

He is a frequent speaker and lecturer at industry conferences and his books are required reading at Stanford, Harvard, MIT and other US business schools.
