fields.headline: Charles Kennedy - left-leaning realist
fields.standfirst:
Parliamentary biographer Andrew Roth looks at how a Labour supporter from Inverness became the Liberal Democrats' leader
Talk to Charles Kennedy live online today at 2pm
fields.trailText: Parliamentary biographer Andrew Roth looks at how a Labour supporter from Inverness became the Liberal Democrats' leader.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy takes his politics seriously, if not himself. Disguised by his disarmingly genial manner, he has emerged as the most realistic politician to have led the Liberal Democrats, if we accept politics as the art of the possible.

At prime minister's question time, Paddy Ashdown could bark out sharper questions at Tony Blair. But unlike Ashdown, or party grandee Lord (Roy) Jenkins, Kennedy is not gullible about which private promises Tony Blair can deliver against the massed ranks of his cabinet, most Labour MPs and the party machine.

He knows that Labour's partial concessions on proportional representation in Scotland and Wales have provided as much as the Lib Dems can expect, much as he would like Blair to fulfil Labour's manifesto promise of a referendum on voting reform.

Instead of chasing the Lib Dems' elusive holy grail, he prefers to identify with Labour in regenerating the NHS. His lieutenant, health spokesman Nick Harvey, has collaborated closely with the health secretary, Alan Milburn. This illustrates Kennedy's crucial strategy: that Lib Dems are friendly rivals of Labour, but deadly enemies of the Tories. "William Hague's Conservatives in government would be an absolute and unmitigated disaster," Kennedy has said.

It was this unstated strategy which underlay the Lib Dems' escape from the minor-party laager in May 1997 and remains the basis of the Labour-Lib Dem coalition in Scotland. It is only on this basis that Kennedy hopes to persuade Labour-haters in his party that they can better defend their expanded bridgehead of 46 seats against the increasingly Europhobic Tories.

His "friendly rivalry" with Labour does not prevent occasional shin-kicking in public (for example, over benefit cuts for the disabled and the financing of the London Underground) or in private (saving Alun Michael's bacon in Wales).

The Europhile Kennedy knows he has no alternative to an alliance with Labour if he wants to achieve entry into the euro and closer EU ties.

His critics claim he is tardy and indolent, taking a taxi rather than walk a quarter mile. But he has won two crucial contests - that of president of the party in 1990 and its leader in 1999 - with the most gruelling campaigns ever on the Lib Dems' "rubber-chicken circuit" stretching from Cornwall to Skye.

Kennedy was born in Inverness, the son of Ian Kennedy, a crofter, engineering draughtsman and semi-professional fiddle-player to the leadership of Britain's third party.

A successful student, he made his way from Lochaber high school in Fort William - where at 15 he joined the Labour party - to Glasgow University. There he joined the Social Democratic Club, a debating society, and became president of the union in 1980. He won an honours degree and a Fulbright scholarship to Indiana University in the US. He seemed set for a career as an amusing lecturer in some obscure American or Scottish university.

But Roy Jenkins's first, failed 1982 attempt to win Glasgow Hillhead ignited his enthusiasm for Europe and the new Social Democratic party. His first act for the SDP was to spend a very wet day outside a polling booth warning voters about a candidate who had changed his name by deed poll to "Roy Jenkins".

Young Kennedy was selected by the SDP for "hopeless" constituency of Ross, Cromarty and Skye where previously the Liberals had only won 9% of the vote. He thought victory was so unlikely that he flew off to the US immediately the polls closed. But, at 23, he had scored the most famous of the six seats the SDP won, ousting the Tories' former minister Hamish Gray. That September a standing ovation greeted him at the Salford conference of the SDP for a mature speech on poverty and welfare reform.

Arriving at the Commons, he hit the ground running, as the SDP spokesman on social security, Scotland and health. In 1987 the Tories disclosed he had voted four times as frequently for Labour as for them.

Initially the only one of the five SDP MPs to favour a merger with the Liberals, he stood aside as a potential interim leader of the SDP's pro-merger faction to back Robert Maclennan, ruling himself out as well as a possible leader of the newly merged party. When the Liberal Democrats was formed he scorned the tendency of ex-Liberals to formulate detailed policies, as if on the eve of taking over the government.

And he was unable to take seriously Ashdown's sudden embrace of Tony Blair and his belief in Blair's promise that he would give Lib Dems two cabinet seats if Labour won in 1997. Kennedy had long favoured working with a "healthy modern Labour party", but he objected to secret deals. This clash explains Ashdown's petulant demotion of him, after the Lib Dems had won 46 seats in 1997, to agriculture spokesman.

Although that yielded more time for television appearances and his perceptive columns in the Scotsman newspaper, it ignited an atypical smouldering resentment. This led him to renew his attack on the rubber-chicken circuit with the enthusiasm needed to beat the hyperactive Simon Hughes by 28,425 votes to 21,833 to become leader of the Liberal Democrats aged 40.

fields.headline: Queues,  Bruise, and  Latest news
fields.trailText: CAMACHO COMIN'ATCHA
fields.body:
CAMACHO COMIN'ATCHA

Day three of the Chelsea manager crisis and things are getting serious. A mob of managerial candidates has swarmed around Stamford Bridge, refusing to move until they are granted a multi-million pound contract that could be cancelled at any moment depending on the whim of Ken Bates. Huddling around flaming motorcars, and singing crude chants - "Who do we want? Jose Antonio Camacho! When do we want him? By the end of the month so he can prepare for the second round of Euro-Vase!" - the mob claims it has the complete support of the British public. And God help Tony Blair if he gets in their way.

Not really, folks: one earth-shaking crisis is enough for this week. But, nevertheless, the field of candidates for the Chelsea job is getting ever wider. Spanish coach Camacho is the hottest name at the moment, not only for his impressive record in charge of Spain, but for the intricacies of his contract which make him easy to poach. A representative of the Spanish FA confirmed: "It is public knowledge that a pact exists between ourselves and Camacho, stating that he can leave if he is no longer happy in his position." Other new names to be touted about are Johan Cruyff, currently unemployed, and former Celtic coach Wim Jansen - ditto.

One candidate who looks like dropping off the list is Fiver favourite Terry Venables. Top of the bookies' charts only yesterday, Tel popped his own bubble when he confessed: "According to my sources, Chelsea are going to appoint a foreign coach." But despite being foreign, Ruud Gullit doesn't expect to get a call. The former Chelsea boss, not on the best of terms with Vialli when he left the club, talked to his pals at the Mirror this morning. "People ask me if I have any sympathy for Gianluca Vialli," he said. "The blunt answer is no."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EMERGENCY WARD FIVER

After a couple of weeks when serious injuries have hogged the headlines - Luc Nilis's shattered leg, Harry Kewell's problem Achilles, Gianluca Vialli's bruised ego - the Fiver is glad to finally have the chance to relay some better news. Lucas Radebe, who last night collided with Michael Duberry as his Leeds team were being thrashed out of sight by Barcelona in Big Cup, has been given a clean bill of health despite sustaining what looked like pretty serious neck knack.

After the aforementioned collision, Radebe remained motionless for several minutes before being carted off the pitch in a neck brace, and initial dark whispers suggested the Leeds captain had broken his neck. Happily, however, x-rays found no serious damage and the Leeds captain will be available for this Saturday's Premiership match against Ipswich. "Although he took a blow to the head and was disorientated," a Leeds spokesman said, "the good news is he has no concussion so he will today travel home with the rest of the squad."

And the happy news doesn't stop there, either, because shortarsed hedonist Diego Maradona also managed to survive a car crash in Cuba late last night. The jeep he was driving along a badly-lit and rainy road collided head-on with a tourist bus and, despite the driver's side being badly damaged, the chubby little trickster escaped with only bruises to his knee and ankle. "Fortunately, he's fine," said friend Guillermo Coppola. "He's a bit shook up by the impact but it's nothing important." Even his septum was not shaken out of place. Amazing.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We can play so much better" - Frank De Boer after Barcelona's 4-0 thumping of Leeds. Let's face it, nobody does arrogance better than the Dutch.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

UNCOMFORTABLE RINGS

It's all go at the Olympics today. IOC head honcho Juan Antonio Samaranch (think of him as a thinner, and even more upstanding Sepp Blatter) has revealed he is in talks with Fifa about changing the rules for the Olympic football competition. The plan is to abandon current age limits which allow countries to have only three players aged 23 or over in their squad. This has already alerted the organisers of the Scarborough Seniors six-a-side tournament who worry they could lose many of their star attractions to future Olympic games.

Of course, a relaxation of the rules would in effect mean the creation of a new international tournament to rival the World Cup, European Championships, Copa America etc. The possible consequences could also be sizeable. Nigerian experts predict that Nwankwo Kanu would be involved in so many tournaments worldwide that he would actually spend his entire life on a plane. Meanwhile, Dean Windass is said to be considering petitioning parliament for the creation of a Great British team so that he and Trevor Sinclair could get an international cap.

With all that news a-going on, we had no time to contact Toadfish (again) and so we are forced to use the official report on today's matches (again). "The banana boys of Brazil goaled their way to an opening 3-1 victory against the Slovs of Slovakia this evening/morning/afternoon. Goals from Arsenal friend Edu and Parma pal Alex were enough to make coach Wanderley Luxemburgo breathe another breath of victory. Elsewhere, Chile were hot as they burnt Morocco 4-1 with a three-goal flamer from Ivan 'to score more goals' Zamorano. Big up the back of the net!"

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Barcelona are considering buying 21-year-old Uruguayan defender Fernando Carreno from Penarol - just so they can use him to prise Rio Ferdinand from West Ham. Planet Football claims Carreno would be loaned out to the Hammers on a long-term basis if they agree to part with the £14m-rated Ferdinand.

Coventry have targetted 26-year-old Honduran defender Milton Reyes. A deal will be struck providing Jairo Martinez and Ivan Guerrero, the two Hondurans already at Highfield Road, have no trouble obtaining their work permits.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The coach of Nigeria has criticised Arsenal in the wake of his team's poor start to the Olympic Games. "A team like Nigeria has no chance if Fifa are prepared to let the big clubs get away with flouting the rules," Jo Bonfrere said after the current holders of the Olympic title drew 3-3 with unfancied Honduras. "Kanu promised us he would play here and that was the case until the very last moment when Arsenal put pressure on him. They put him in a position where it was impossible for him to play for us. The club are selfish and won't even look at the big picture. We were counting on Kanu."

Manchester City have announced that their match against Middlesbrough will go ahead on Sunday despite the current fuel crisis.

Gregory Vignal, a 19-year-old former French Under 18 international full back, has joined Liverpool from Montpellier for £467,000.

Newcastle goalkeeper Shay Given has signed a new three-year contract with the club.

Bradford full-back Andy Myers is out for six weeks after pulling his hamstring in the 1-1 draw with Arsenal at Highbury on Saturday.

Galatasaray midfielder Gheorge Hagi could miss the Turkish side's Big Cup game against Rangers after being sent off against Monaco for allegedly elbowing an opponent. Uefa will decide whether to give him a two-match suspension tomorrow.

Roberto Baggio has signed a two-year contract with newly promoted Serie A club Brescia. The former Italian international, who joins on a free transfer, has been out of contract since the end of June after a two-year spell with Internazionale.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.25am) Open your eyes, then your mind.

Channel 5: Uefa Cup Football - Live (6.45pm, 4.15am) Join Liverpool as they embark on another epic journey to the third round of a European competition.

Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.45am) AN AWFUL LOT OF SHOUTING AND HOLLERING.

Dutch Football (1.15am) Burnside is better at shouting anyway.

Argentinian Football (2.45am) And he nicks lowlife scum.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 11.30pm) Which is more than Jonathan Pearce does.

Spanish Football (8pm) Burnside would be better at commentating as well, given the chance.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am) The pain of missing Burnside on Thursdays still doesn't mask the pain of watching McCaff. Nothing masks the pain of watching McCaff.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1) If you're sitting next to someone who has just come out of a ten-year coma, please be thoughtful enough to explain what the hell has happened to Fulham.

Sky Sports 3: Classic World Cup Football (10pm) The Soviet Union thrash Belgium in the 1970 finals. See, kids, communism can work!

British Eurosport: Uefa Cup Football - Live (6.45pm) Partizan Belgrade take on Porto while you watch something on the other side.

Uefa Cup Football (9.15pm) Featuring Liverpool's latest step on their "return to greatness" (no.15 in a series of 639).

Olympic Games Football (11.15pm) Don't pretend you care.

Sky Sports Extra Dot Com Slash Extra Sport Dot Sport: Chelsea v St Gallen (7.30pm) Pay us now.

u>direct: HJK Helsinki v Celtic (5.45pm) Go on, give us your money.

Leicester v Red Star Belgrade (7.30pm) Come on, cough up before we hit you.

ONsport 1: Manchester United v Anderlecht (6.20pm) The bloke who plays Burnside is the author of a number of kids' books, you know.

PSV Eindhoven v Dynamo Kiev (8.10pm) Fiver reader Ben Southall told us that his mum met him at a publisher's do.

AC Milan v Besiktas (10pm) "She didn't get nicked, though," he says. We're not surprised - the tough-talking cockney copper is every inch a gent, after all.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7pm) We can't remember whether the BBC has the rights to commentate on the Uefa Cup or not.

Talksport: Football First Uefa Cup (7pm) But something tells us Talksport are certainly allowed.

fields.headline: The art of buying art
fields.standfirst:
If you like it, buy it. Mark Irving offers some advice for the first-time collector

Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you like it, buy it. Mark Irving offers some advice for the first-time collector
fields.body:
The trouble with art is that the act of buying something to hang on your wall, put on your shelf or install in your garden has, for centuries, been encoded by the art world into a language that mystifies the work and its significance. Not its meaning - we've long been told how this isn't necessarily important anymore - but its significance, something far more important and the one issue that many curators and dealers of contemporary art find difficult to answer. Or if they do answer it, they often do so in a language delighting in obscure post-modern jargon ("challenges conventions", "transgresses boundaries", "questions notions of . . .") that forms a protective cocoon around the art work itself. No wonder, then, that many people get flustered and defensive when asked what it is they like about art.

So what is a first-time collector to do? Probably the best advice is to ignore the label next to the work in question, put aside the exhibition catalogue and just look at the piece carefully. What does it do for you? If your feelings about it aren't immediately forthcoming, try coming back to it later.

People have got into the idea that there has to be something behind the work, some intention, motivation, or point of origin, when in fact it might be at the very surface of the piece that its power lies. Alternatively, don't be taken in by appearances alone: forced casualness of execution - so very fashionable right now - often hides a lack of talent or imagination, just as a highly-worked intricacy in a work of art can, in some instances, suggest an inability to see the wood for the trees.

There aren't any easy answers for the would-be collector. Anthony Reynolds, who has sold work by many of today's leading contemporary artists from his gallery in London's West End, says that he finds his best artists by "not looking for anything in particular. It is usually quite surprising when I find something I like. You never know when it's going to hit you."

Reynolds, who launched the careers of artists such as Steve McQueen, Mark Wallinger, Richard Billingham, Keith Tyson and Georgina Starr (whose new exhibition, "The Bunny Lakes are Coming", is on show at his gallery until the end of this month), says "it's important to remain open to any possibility. By seeing a lot of work at shows, you get a measure of what's going on and you can then make your judgements accordingly."

For Reynolds, meeting young artists and talking to them about their work is vital to him forming a view about them. For buyers, however, meeting an artist whose work interests them can be both rewarding and difficult. The romantic notion of visiting an artist in his or her own studio - seeing them in their element, poised with paintbrush in hand - is appealing, but most artists dread open studio events, says David Gilmour, director of Delfina Studios, Bermondsey.

"It can be so dispiriting if they have to sit in their studios waiting for someone to poke their head around the door, who then sniffs and walks away. The artists at Delfina decided to stop the open event we once ran. People still like coming around to see an artist they've got to know, or whose work they've bought, but they shouldn't think it'll cost them less than it would through an art gallery, since artists are loyal to the gallery. After all, it's in their own interest to be so."

The Whitechapel Open, a regular annual event which coordinated public access to a large number of artists' studios around the east end and south London, has now ended - "it always got slated by the press and it wasn't very professional," says Gilmour - and will be replaced by the London Invitational, a new collaboration that is due to start next year. Commercial gallery owners will be invited to show work by previously unexhibited artists selected by the Whitechapel Gallery, which will have its own curated show serving as the hub of the event. Visitors to the gallery will be provided with a map indicating the location of these commercial galleries, so that art enthusiasts will be able to explore new artistic talent with ease.

Whether this project will succeed remains to be seen, but it is evident that few artists - Tracey Emin, and Sarah Staton whose Supastore project sold artworks by a variety of artists direct to the public, are among the exceptions - find they have the time or necessary skills to publicise and sell their work outside the gallery system. Although large numbers of artists show at the ACME Studio spaces across London, for example, it is very difficult to find out what they are doing or if you can come and view their work, as the artists are poorly coordinated. With so many contemporary art spaces now open in London, first-time buyers are probably best advised to brave the system and trawl around the galleries.

But there are alternatives: you could visit the end of year degree shows held by most of the art and design colleges in your area - they will be happy to supply you with the dates. Much of the work is for sale, and you can enjoy the thrill of being a key early patron of an artist you believe in.

Art fairs provide another useful survey of new work, often at a range of prices from the affordable to the mortgageable, and tend to show a broader range of styles of work than you would find in the fashionable contemporary spaces. Advertised in art world publications such as Art Monthly and the Artist's Newsletter, and in local papers, these fairs often mix craftwork with paintings, drawings and sculptures. There are international art fairs (in Berlin, Basle and Kassel) showing the latest in contemporary art, and the Art Fair held every January at the Business Design Centre in London brings together a large number of dealers showing a very wide spectrum of art works.

But remember: however much something looks fantastic on a display stand, you might feel differently when it gets home. Any decent dealer will let you try a piece out at home first, if required. When all is said and done, if the work doesn't move you at that point, then think hard about proceeding any further. After all, you have to be able to live with the works of art you buy.

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.trailText: . . .a camera case
fields.body:
. . .a camera case

Generally speaking, people tend to worry more about losing their camera than the case. But if the case in question happens to be of the Mulberry mock crock variety, designed exclusively for the new Olympus digital camera (a snip at £129.99), then you might think differently. A recent addition to that burgeoning luxury sector, the business accessory, this case is made from cow hide embossed with a crock-like print, rather than genuine crocodile skin. So the only dilemma is choosing between the Congo, the core Mulberry print; the Quill, embossed with an ostrich print; or Pernge, metallic in bronze. At 12cm long, 3cm wide and 7cm deep, the case fits snugly around the camera and has a strap for those who prefer to explore their photo opportunities hands-free. First seen draped over celebrities rubbing shoulders at the Fashion Acts charity event, you can snap up your own from Mulberry for £115.

For details contact Mulberry: 020-7491 3900

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: While the fashion pack heads off to New York for the launch of the spring/summer 2001 collections, the rest of us are starting to think about our winter wardrobes.
fields.body:
Womenswear

While the fashion pack heads off to New York for the launch of the spring/summer 2001 collections, the rest of us are starting to think about our winter wardrobes.

www.net-a-porter.com is a virtual boutique which has everything the "high end consumer" will need, which, roughly translated, means "don't go there unless you've got serious amounts of cash to spend." Presented in the style of a magazine, with runway photography and an editorial, all you do is click on the pictures and you're taken directly to the order page. Which means that getting your hands on the Luella "Daddy, who were the Clash" jacket (£1,080) and the Andrew GN gold studded coat (£1,785), has never been easier - provided of course that your credit card is up to it.

Another site boasting an impressive list of designers is www.luxlook.com, which went live in the US earlier this month and will launch in the UK in November. The site will feature the full range of accessories from 12 designers including Dolce & Gabbana, Paul Smith, Valentino and Versace. All prices are the same as you would pay in the store and there are no additional charges for delivery.

An altogether smaller affair, what www.bagladies.co.uk lacks in size and sophistication - the well-heeled shopper has to complete an order form and calculate the total cost plus postage and packaging - it makes up for with Lavi & Sally "Kelly" and "Birkin" style bags, made from fine Italian leather (starting at £245).

If, however, you aspire to designer brands, but don't quite have the income to afford them, try www.haburi.com which has discounts of 25 to 75% off a small selection of items from big names.

webTitle: Thieves get away with online fraud

fields.headline: Thieves get away with online fraud
fields.trailText: Most thieves get away with online credit-card fraud, according to a survey of online retailers published today.
fields.body:
Most thieves get away with online credit-card fraud, according to a survey of online retailers published today.

Experian UK, a credit and business information company, questioned 800 firms about their attitudes to online fraud. It found that only 57% bothered to report fraud cases to the police - and of these, only 9% of cases led to prosecution.

And while 60% said fear of fraud was a serious barrier to online trading, most either did no checking or relied almost totally on manual fraud prevention measures.

Almost half said they did not use external data to verify a customer's name and address, and two-thirds said it took more than a month before a credit-card crime was detected.

"By this time the thief has got away with it," said Richard Fiddis, Experian UK chief executive, "And not just once - but in 40% of cases, several times on the same website.

"In effect, the internet is becoming the first choice for thieves that, in another age, might have just been petty shoplifters or locker room pickpockets," Mr Fiddis said.

Useful links

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst:
Despite Blair's promises, Sir Humphrey and his friends must be celebrating the departure of Alex Allan, the e-envoy
Net news
fields.trailText: Richard Sarson: Despite Blair's promises, Sir Humphrey and his friends must be celebrating the departure of Alex Allan, the e-envoy
fields.body:
The Prime Minister, fresh from his hols, has reaffirmed his determination to get 100% of Government services to the citizen online by 2005, and has offered £1bn to achieve it.

This is a boost to the spirits for the flagging e-government workers, cast down by last week's resignation of Alex Allan, the e-envoy, to care for his ailing wife, after only nine months in the job. They badly needed this boost. The whole move of modernising government, e-government or joined-up government seemed to me to be running into the sand.

I was becoming more and more convinced that the canker came from within, that Sir Humphrey Appleby was out to scupper it all.

My first suspicion came from the e-envoy's monthly reports to Tony Blair on how the UK is becoming the best in the world at e-commerce and e-government. These reports, published on the web, were very bullish, with ministries announcing new e-government initiatives each month. But one of the tasks assigned to Alex Allan, when he started work in January, remains obstinately uncompleted after eight months. This was to set up a management board, "bringing together a small core group of departments with major e-commerce and e-Government responsibilities."

It should have been a simple task, to find a few forward-looking fellow spirits at a very high level in the ministries. Only in this way could he effect the necessary culture shift in the Civil Service. If he had any difficulty in recruiting, he could wave this prime ministerial instruction in their face and, one might have thought, they would have accepted this great challenge with enthusiasm. Their careers would take off if they were to join this great enterprise, and they would be assured of a knighthood.

But no. After six months no one rose to the challenge, and Alex Allan was still on his own, with no board to help him hack his way through the cross-departmental jungle. He claimed that individual ministries all "bought in" to the joined-up government agenda, but I became more convinced that he was being stitched up by Sir Humphrey and his pals.

My suspicions were confirmed by the absurd reason given for the task being behind schedule. This went: "The office of the e-envoy are considering further how best to rationalise the various existing groups and to involve key departments and industry representatives." This strikes me as a choice example of Humphreyesque gobbledygook. What on earth have these things to do with appointing a management board? In fact, I can't see how the e-envoy on his own can possibly "rationalise existing groups". That surely would be a task for the board, once it was set up.

But then, all became clear. I saw Sir Humphrey, Sir Frank and Jumbo, deep in their arm chairs at the Athenaeum, with large brandies in their hands, discussing the threat posed by this young chap Allan to the God-given independence of their individual ministries. "The damned chap knows all about these computer thingies, and wants to put them between us and the man in the street. Where does that leave us? You won't catch me on his management board." But, because Blair has been talked into this "modernising government" nonsense by some spin-doctor, the Athenaeum Three know they had to be careful. The best strategem is the old Whitehall trick of stalling.

"So, let's tell Allan that we are, of course, desperate to join his show, but before we do, he really must define more carefully what all the various departments are supposed to do, and how we are all to interact with each other. That should take about nine months. That should see us out to the next election." At this, the three of them fall about laughing. So, Alex Allan remained without a management board.

Imagine the glee that the three must have felt when they got the news last week that Alex Allan had resigned, and that his successor would be appointed by a public selection procedure. Another three or even six months wasted.

Two months ago, I heard a senior member of the Central IT Unit, the e-envoy's technical powerhouse, tell a meeting of the Parliamentary IT Committee that a new plan will put joined-up IT strategies "on the mental agenda of very senior people in Whitehall". But, surely, senior people in Whitehall like Sir Humphrey should have had electronic government on their mental agenda for nearly four years, ever since November 1996, when the Tory government published the "Government.direct" green paper. This first propounded the idea of putting citizens at the centre of government processes, so that if they married or went bankrupt they would only have to fill in one form, preferably on a screen, rather than several for many different ministries. At the time, I remember Roger Freeman, then minister for the cabinet office, say: "we have got Sir Humphrey terrified".

After May 1997, Tony Blair accepted the message of Government.direct, and followed it up with a White Paper called Modernising Government in May 1999, and numerous strategy documents have followed. So, there are only three reasons why Sir Humphrey should not have e-government on his mental agenda. Either he is not prepared to accept it, or he, with his Oxbridge-Arts background, has not the mental apparatus to understand it.

A third, more Machiavellian, interpretation, confirming my Yes Minister scenario, is that Sir Humphrey has had e-government very firmly fixed on his mental agenda since 1996, and, with his chums, has devoted his energies to stalling it for four years.

To help Sir Humphrey, constant cabinet reshuffles have injected at least a year's delay, from David Clark to Jack Cunningham to Mo Mowlam. So we have had a minister who lost the confidence of Tony Blair, an "enforcer" who could not enforce, and a much-loved lady who confesses she is bored by her joined-up job. This is no way to change the way the whole civil service operates. Ian McArtney and Pat Hewitt, the e-ministers responsible, know what has to be done, but you need a big beast of the jungle to stop Sir Humphrey messing it all up. Such big beasts, other than Tony Blair, are not around.

Last Monday, Tony Blair also released Alex Allan's annual progress report and swan song as e-envoy. I note that the idea of a management board has vanished. Clearly, Allan has realised that any dream he might have had of achieving joined-up government as a partnership between the reformers and those to be reformed has gone. Instead, the report plays hard-ball. It emphasises the "strategic role" of the office of the e- envoy by "releasing funds to departments and agencies only on condition that departments have drawn up detailed, e-business strategies, and the e-envoy has confirmed to the Chief Secretary that these are aligned with the Government's overall strategic vision". No more Mr Nice-guy. Sir Humphrey depends on the future e-envoy for his cash.

This is rough stuff. But Tony Blair has still to find someone tough enough and subtle enough to play hardball with Sir Humphrey. And then, even if he/she does win the battle of educating or silencing the senior people in White hall, when will they get around to training the rank and file? In 2002 or 2003? I keep reading surveys of civil servants, which show they do not believe that Blair's target of 100% e-government by 2005 is feasible. With Sir Humphrey still at the helm, e-government could yet turn into the mother of all public-sector computer disasters.

I saw Sir Humphrey, Sir Frank and Jumbo, deep in their arm chairs at the Athenaeum, with large brandies in their hands, discussing the threat posed by this young chap Allan to the God-given independence of their individual ministries. "The damned chap knows all about these computer thingies, and wants to put them between us and the man in the street. Where does that leave us? You won't catch me on his management board." But, because Blair has been talked into this "modernising government" nonsense by some spin-doctor, the Athenaeum Three know they had to be careful. The best strategem is the old Whitehall trick of stalling. "So, let's tell Allan that we are, of course, desperate to join his show, but before we do, he really must define more carefully what all the various departments are supposed to do, and how we are all to interact with each other. That should take about nine months. That should see us out to the next election." At this, the three of them fall about laughing. So, Alex Allan remained without a management board. Imagine the glee that the three must have felt when they got the news last week that Alex Allan had resigned, and that his successor would be appointed by a public selection procedure. Another three or even six months wasted. Two months ago, I heard a senior member of the Central IT Unit, the e-envoy's technical powerhouse, tell a meeting of the Parliamentary IT Committee that a new plan will put joined-up IT strategies "on the mental agenda of very senior people in Whitehall". But, surely, senior people in Whitehall like Sir Humphrey should have had electronic government on their mental agenda for nearly four years, ever since November 1996, when the Tory government published the "Government.direct" green paper. This first propounded the idea of putting citizens at the centre of government processes, so that if they married or went bankrupt they would only have to fill in one form, preferably on a screen, rather than several for many different ministries. At the time, I remember Roger Freeman, then minister for the cabinet office, say: "we have got Sir Humphrey terrified". After May 1997, Tony Blair accepted the message of Government.direct, and followed it up with a White Paper called Modernising Government in May 1999, and numerous strategy documents have followed. So, there are only three reasons why Sir Humphrey should not have e-government on his mental agenda. Either he is not prepared to accept it, or he, with his Oxbridge-Arts background, has not the mental apparatus to understand it. A third, more Machiavellian, interpretation, confirming my Yes Minister scenario, is that Sir Humphrey has had e-government very firmly fixed on his mental agenda since 1996, and, with his chums, has devoted his energies to stalling it for four years. To help Sir Humphrey, constant cabinet reshuffles have injected at least a year's delay, from David Clark to Jack Cunningham to Mo Mowlam. So we have had a minister who lost the confidence of Tony Blair, an "enforcer" who could not enforce, and a much-loved lady who confesses she is bored by her joined-up job. This is no way to change the way the whole civil service operates. Ian McArtney and Pat Hewitt, the e-ministers responsible, know what has to be done, but you need a big beast of the jungle to stop Sir Humphrey messing it all up. Such big beasts, other than Tony Blair, are not around. Last Monday, Tony Blair also released Alex Allan's annual progress report and swan song as e-envoy. I note that the idea of a management board has vanished. Clearly, Allan has realised that any dream he might have had of achieving joined-up government as a partnership between the reformers and those to be reformed has gone. Instead, the report plays hard-ball. It emphasises the "strategic role" of the office of the e- envoy by "releasing funds to departments and agencies only on condition that departments have drawn up detailed, e-business strategies, and the e-envoy has confirmed to the Chief Secretary that these are aligned with the Government's overall strategic vision". No more Mr Nice-guy. Sir Humphrey depends on the future e-envoy for his cash. This is rough stuff. But Tony Blair has still to find someone tough enough and subtle enough to play hardball with Sir Humphrey. And then, even if he/she does win the battle of educating or silencing the senior people in White hall, when will they get around to training the rank and file? In 2002 or 2003? I keep reading surveys of civil servants, which show they do not believe that Blair's target of 100% e-government by 2005 is feasible. With Sir Humphrey still at the helm, e-government could yet turn into the mother of all public-sector computer disasters.

webTitle: Lorraine Heggessey on her new role

fields.headline: Clocking on
fields.standfirst: Lorraine Heggessey on her new role as controller of BBC1
fields.trailText: Lorraine Heggessey on her new role as controller of BBC1. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Lorraine Heggessey, 43, the new controller of BBC1, declared today that her aim is to make the channel the most popular in Britain. The first woman to head the channel said she wanted to make it more popular than ITV. "My job will clearly be to arrest the ratings decline, if not reverse it."

She said that BBC1 needed to be more ambitious, and develop more strong drama series like Clocking Off and Warriors. "I'd rather be ambitious and fail, than not take risks and succeed." Ms Heggessey said that she expected staff at the BBC to work harder than ever in the drive to improve BBC1. She denied that her lack of experience in drama and entertainment would be a disadvantage: "You take advice and you use your instinct."

Unlike her boss Greg Dyke, she said that she is an "avid viewer" of Channel 4's TV hit Big Brother, and she named ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire as one of her favourite non-BBC programmes. BBC1 had to produce more big hits like these she said. "There is always a danger in being the second or third, or even fifth or sixth at something. More and more we have to be the first."

In a surprising comment, the new controller said she had harboured ambitions for the job for the past "seven or eight years". A woman's perspective would be advantageous, she added. "I think women are better than most men."

webTitle: Better deal for refugees demanded at TUC

fields.headline: Better deal for refugees demanded at TUC
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's trade unions yesterday urged the government to end the "humiliating and stigmatising" system of food vouchers for asylum seekers and to relax the stringent conditions forced on refugees.
fields.body:
Britain's trade unions yesterday urged the government to end the "humiliating and stigmatising" system of food vouchers for asylum seekers and to relax the stringent conditions forced on refugees.

Bill Morris, Transport Union leader and self-proclaimed son of a Jamaican economic migrant, denounced the voucher system after accompanying Pedram, an Iranian asylum seeker, on his weekly shop in central Glasgow.

Pedram, a 30-year-old GP and religious refugee from Tehran who entered Britain in June, has been surviving on £26.34 in food vouchers and £10 in cash a week and on charities.

"I am single but many of my friends are married and some are being forced to live on even less than I get," he said. "They wonder whether they should leave Glasgow and get a job on the black market in London in order to survive."

Displaying the cheap, "value" goods in his shopping bag, some of them reduced because they were close to their sell-by date, he said the vouchers put a barrier between asylum seekers and the rest of the community.

"Sooner or later we will be members of the community so we have got to know the rules, especially as we tend to come from non-democratic countries ... we don't seek people's mercy but just their help and we don't deserve their hatred and contempt which this system of vouchers intensifies."

Mr Morris, who later electrified the congress with a call to stamp out racism, including within unions, condemned the system under which asylum seekers got no change from their vouchers.

He also criticised the system whereby refugees got £8 in exchange for a £10 voucher on the black market. "Whoever dreamed up the voucher system should be forced to live on it for a year."

He said: "We have got a government which is subsidising Tesco, Asda and Sainsbury's, and that's not the redistribution of wealth I voted for on May 1 1997. This voucher system degrades our humanity and should be scrapped now."

Jonathan Ellis, an Oxfam campaigns manager, said: "It is outrageous that supermarkets are allowed to make a profit from one of the most vulnerable groups in our society."

Mr Morris said Pedram (not his real name) could not afford to buy fresh fruit and vegetables, relying instead on tinned goods. At the check-out he was constantly looking over his shoulder to see who was watching him. "The staff try to be friendly but this system is inherently stigmatising."

Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the British Refugee Council, said: "Every single day, asylum seekers are ringing us describing incidents of harassment and racism, children bullied at school, people being beaten up, houses being fire-bombed."

Later, delegates were warned by John Monks, TUC general secretary, that they had a mountain to climb to combat racism within their own ranks. They reacted with shame and disgust as actors from the Theatre Royal, Stratford East, east London, read out harrowing accounts of discrimination given over the TUC's racism hotline.

Mr Morris, introducing a motion condemning opposition leaders for fanning the flames of racism and demanding government action to abandon provisions of the 1999 Immigration and Asylum Act, won a standing ovation for his impassioned plea for the government to give asylum seekers full human rights and to work for a greater understanding of the plight of refugees.

"When I hear the words bogus and flooding it sends a shiver down my spine. When I hear the words economic migrant, I think of my mother who came to Britain 46 years ago after the death of my father.

"She was an economic migrant. We were a family of economic migrants. As I look back I hope we have contributed more than we have taken from our great country," he said.

Glenroy Watson, a London Underground worker and RMT rail union delegate, said he was an economic migrant too. "My mother didn't come here for the lovely weather but to improve her standard of living - and human beings have the right to seek improvement."

The TGWU-led motion, which the union is to submit to Labour's annual conference later this month, demands the scrapping of the plan to impose a £10,000 bond on those seeking UK entry from certain countries as "morally wrong and inherently racist".

fields.headline: BBC confirms Heggessey as new BBC1 controller
fields.standfirst: Heggessey talks to Matt Wells
fields.trailText: The BBC today ended weeks of speculation when it announced the appointment of Lorraine Heggessey as the new controller of BBC1. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The BBC today ended weeks of speculation when it announced the appointment of Lorraine Heggessey as the new controller of BBC1.

Heggessey, previously the BBC's head of factual programmes, becomes the first female controller of BBC1 in the corporation's history. She begins her new job on November 1 replacing Peter Salmon, who was yesterday confirmed as director of sport at the BBC.

Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, said: "Lorraine has tremendous energy and a fierce commitment to the future of BBC1. As well as many outstanding achievements in current affairs, science and other factual programmes, she reinvigorated BBC Children's programming - which is effectively a channel in microcosm. She is a programme-maker through and through and has a great knack of recognising the original idea and making it work. I think she will build on Peter's many achievements with skill and imagination."

Heggessey added: "The lure of running a flagship channel like BBC1 is irresistible to any programme-maker. The challenge - which cannot be underestimated - is to set the standards with BBC1 in a multi-channel world. The bonus is a better funded channel and a renewed emphasis on giving viewers the best from the best. It's the job I have always wanted and I'm determined to surprise and delight the audience."

webTitle: Eastoe steps down at Trinity Mirror

fields.headline: Eastoe steps down in Trinity Mirror shake-up
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror's group managing director, Roger Eastoe, has suddenly resigned from the UK's largest newspaper publisher in a shock management clear-out.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror's group managing director, Roger Eastoe, has suddenly resigned from the UK's largest newspaper publisher in a shock management clear-out.

The boardroom shake-up has also claimed Mike Masters, group managing director of UK and Ireland publishing, who has taken early retirement. Both have been employed at Mirror Group since well before the arrival of new chairman Victor Blank.

Their roles will be replaced by an as-yet-unfilled senior executive position, which will cover strategic and operational responsibility for all Trinity Mirror titles.

Philip Graf, chief executive, said: "This new role marks an important evolution in the development of our senior management team. I would also like to thank Mike for the key role he has played in the success of Trinity over many years and for his help and unstinting commitment latterly at Trinity Mirror, and to Roger for his 25 years of outstanding work on the national titles."

The news overshadowed the group's half-year results, with pre-tax profits rising from £91.1m to £104.5m.

webTitle: Rising from the flames of E-women

fields.headline: Rising from the flames of E-women
fields.trailText: September 14: The breakaway founders of E-women are already planning their next venture - a new women's forum called phoenix-network.
fields.body:
The breakaway founders of E-women are already planning their next venture - a new women's forum called phoenix-network.

The three co-founders, who walked out on E-women last week after a disagreement with fellow founder Kathryn Bullock, said they still planned to continue providing the networking events for women in new media. They plan to set up a new online e-group at www.egroups.com/groups/phoenix-network, where women can post comments, ideas and messages.

Jenny Nabben said phoenix-network would be contacting the original E-women members and asking if they wish to be kept on the database and moved over to phoenix-network.

"We will be a not-for-profit organisation and seek to continue to offer women a high-level networking opportunity. We believe in the idea of collaboration and a collegiate ethos. We are also open to the notion that the network will evolve and may open up to include men working in new media at some point in the future - which is why it will be branded as phoenix-network," said Nabben.

Phoenix-network expects to hold its first event in October and from then onwards run monthly events.

The E-women.org site was closed down yesterday.

fields.headline: Averbuch leaves Yahoo to travel the world
fields.trailText: September 14: Yahoo UK & Ireland's longest serving employee, Ralph Averbuch, is departing to take time out of new media and travel the world.
fields.body:
Yahoo UK & Ireland's longest serving employee, Ralph Averbuch, is departing to take time out of new media and travel the world.

Averbuch, head of business development, joined Yahoo in 1996 as UK producer and worked his way up the ranks to become a strong force behind developing new business at Yahoo UK & Ireland.

He was the public face of the company in the early days and was widely acknowledged to have been instrumental in getting the business off the ground.

Asked about his reasons for leaving, Averbuch said: "I've just got itchy feet to go travelling for a bit - till the end of the year - then back into the fray."

Averbuch was a print journalist in Scotland before moving into new media in 1994 when he worked as senior editor for the now-defunct Europe Online.

Yahoo has been aiming to bolster its business development team for some time and the departure of Averbuch will come as a huge loss for the web portal-cum-search engine.

webTitle: Empty docks in China's graft trials

fields.headline: Empty docks in China's graft trials
fields.trailText: The first trials in China's biggest corruption scandal began yesterday under a veil of secrecy intended to minimising the Communist leadership's embarrassment.
fields.body:
The first trials in China's biggest corruption scandal began yesterday under a veil of secrecy intended to minimising the Communist leadership's embarrassment.

Court officers in Fujian province confirmed that proceedings had begun in the 50bn yuan (about £4bn) smuggling case believed to involve up to 600 government officials, several of whom are likely to be sentenced to death.

Some of the key figures in the scandal have fled overseas and there is widespread scepticism that others, who have close links to the leadership in Beijing, will be charged.

The case centres on the smuggling of fuel, tobacco, cigarettes and rubber by the Yuanhua Group of Hong Kong, in cooperation with corrupt police, customs and party officials.

The court building in Xiamen, one of the five centres where the trials are being held, was closed to everyone without official passes yesterday, including most of the court staff, in an effort to keep the proceedings secret.

Internet chatrooms were buzzing with discussion of one of the country's biggest news stories of the year, but the mainland media were warned not to report the case without official approval.

A duty officer at another court, in Zhangzhou, said it seemed "very mysterious".

"I heard that if they tried one person a day they would never get through this case in a year," a resident of Xiamen, Chen Changjian, said.

So far the courts have confirmed very few prosecutions: six in Xiamen and a further 12 in Putian. They include Cao Xinghai, general manager of the Orient Group in Fujian, which is accused of providing the smugglers with trading documents in return for a nearly £2m annual payoff.

The head of Yuanhua, Lai Changqing, who is alleged to have spent heavily on official protection, fled China before he could be arrested and took refuge in either Burma or Canada, according to Hong Kong press reports. The deputy mayor of Xiamen, Lan Fu, reportedly made it to Australia.

Other suspects seem to enjoy the protection of powerful patrons. When website reports linked the Beijing Communist party chief and politburo member Jia Jinglin, who is politically close to President Jiang Zemin, to the corruption investigation, the state propaganda machine was quick to clear him.

There is no sign of any of the senior officials detained, including a former head of military intelligence, General Ji Shengde, and the immigration chief, Xu Ganlu, being brought to trial. There are unconfirmed reports that Beijing has decided to limit the political fallout by focusing on middle-rank provincial officials.

Beijing has launched a highly publicised crackdown on corruption in recent months. President Jiang said it represents a "life and death" struggle for the party.

In July a former vice-chairman of parliament, Cheng Kejie became the most senior official ever to be sentenced to death, and yesterday the state media reported that a corrupt cadre in Sichuan province had also been condemned.

The Beijing Youth Daily predicted this week that 10 more would be executed after the latest trials. Other reports suggest that only four will face the death penalty, including a former Xiamen customs chief and a former provincial deputy director of police.

Such an outcome will only increase the popular suspicion in China that lower-level officials are being made the scapegoats for the crimes of more senior leaders politically too well connected to be brought to justice.

Nevertheless there is hope in Fujian that the trials will finally let the relatively prosperous province, which has benefited greatly from closer economic links with Taiwan, put away the scandal that has tainted its name.

"One thing I would like to stress is that Xiamen is not relying on smuggling to get rich," the city's new deputy mayor, Chen Conghui, said yesterday.

"If you cut off a branch infected with insects the health of the whole tree improves."

Beijing has launched a highly publicised crackdown on corruption in recent months. President Jiang said it represents a "life and death" struggle for the party. In July a former vice-chairman of parliament, Cheng Kejie became the most senior official ever to be sentenced to death, and yesterday the state media reported that a corrupt cadre in Sichuan province had also been condemned. The Beijing Youth Daily predicted this week that 10 more would be executed after the latest trials. Other reports suggest that only four will face the death penalty, including a former Xiamen customs chief and a former provincial deputy director of police. Such an outcome will only increase the popular suspicion in China that lower-level officials are being made the scapegoats for the crimes of more senior leaders politically too well connected to be brought to justice. Nevertheless there is hope in Fujian that the trials will finally let the relatively prosperous province, which has benefited greatly from closer economic links with Taiwan, put away the scandal that has tainted its name. "One thing I would like to stress is that Xiamen is not relying on smuggling to get rich," the city's new deputy mayor, Chen Conghui, said yesterday. "If you cut off a branch infected with insects the health of the whole tree improves."

webTitle: Online transactions must be tightened up

fields.headline: Online transactions must be tightened up
fields.standfirst:
The net is a huckster's playground and the current credit-card set-up is only making things easier for them, says Neil McIntosh
Thieves get away with online fraud
fields.trailText: The net is a huckster's playground and the current credit-card set-up is only making things easier for them, says Neil McIntosh.
fields.body:
Online thieves are getting away with their crimes, a survey published today has claimed. Almost half of e-retailers are not taking precautions like verifying customer's names and addresses before clearing transactions, and only 9% of fraud reports lead to a prosecution.

That will surprise some internet consumers, who might have assumed that the very fact you are ordering via computer over a secure system would mean that it would be simple to cross-refer your details in some way. Not so, it seems.

Like many surveys of this kind, of course, there is a hidden agenda. In this case the report was commissioned by Experian UK, a company which likes to describe itself as a "global information solutions company", but which will be most familiar to many of us as credit reference agency. It's one of the companies most likely to benefit if we all start demanding better "back office" checks on online transactions.

But we should be thankful to the survey for highlighting, again, the potential to commit crime on the internet. It is easy for an internet user with only moderate experience, a little imagination and no conscience to defraud an online retailer. And, yes, the lack of verification that the number belongs to a valid card, in the hands of its rightful owner, makes things even easier.

But is it the retailers' fault? Experian UK might be suggesting so, but really we should be looking to the source of the problem: credit-card companies themselves.

Consider our flexible friends for just a second: they have barely evolved in decades, maybe a holographic anti-fraud sticker there, a fancy new bit of graphic design there, but otherwise not much has changed. The principal means of card checking are physical - one, that you actually have the card in your hand; two, that you can match the signature on the back; three, that the magnetic strip on the card is valid.

Using mail, telephone or internet shopping, those physical checks are replaced by just two weaker substitutes: the card number (which can be made up by one of those number generators) and the expiry date (the simple month/year format of which can be easily guessed).

As Anthony Abraham, of Canadian-based watchdog Fraud Watch, has been pointing out for years, credit cards just weren't designed to be used over the net - only between people in the same room. He still acknowledges that credit cards are still the best way to shop online, but only because because the consumer is at least only hit for the first £50 of any fraud. It's the retailers who take the financial brunt of any misuse.

So what is the way ahead? Should we demand retailers take greater precautions, as Experian UK suggests? We could - but, in fact, such checks could be a pain. It's often useful, for instance, to order books on Amazon to be delivered to a friend's address for their birthday, or to buy computer parts which can then be delivered and signed for at your place of work, rather than home. Such checks could mean everything has to go direct to the cardholder.

No - what we need is the credit card companies to come up with a way to modernise their old-fashioned bits of plastic. Some are trying - American Express last week announced it was creating a way to use "disposable" credit-card numbers which are valid for only one purchase. So if a retailer's security is breached, hackers will not be able to use any credit numbers they find.

It is a great idea, but with retailers picking up most of the fraud bill, other card issuers are not in a rush to come up with similarly smart schemes. More simple advances could take years to arrive in our wallets.

fields.headline: Clever Trevor fuels ITV ratings victory
fields.trailText: The return of Tonight with Trevor McDonald on Wednesday night proved that the popularity of the veteran newsreader has not waned. The combination of Trev's star appeal and the insatiable demand for news on the fuel crisis helped the ITV show to attract higher ratings than Channel 4's Big Brother, broadcast at the same time.
fields.body:
The return of Tonight with Trevor McDonald on Wednesday night proved that the popularity of the veteran newsreader has not waned. The combination of Trev's star appeal and the insatiable demand for news on the fuel crisis helped the ITV show to attract higher ratings than Channel 4's Big Brother, broadcast at the same time.

Unofficial overnight figures show the programme attracted 6.7m viewers, giving it a 37% share of the total audience from 10.15-11pm. And overall ITV emerged as the peak-time ratings champion, taking a 35.9% share between 6pm and 10.30pm.

Big Brother continues to draw in the viewers, with 4.6m people tuning in at 10pm to watch the show in its final week, giving Channel 4 a 21% share. But Channel 4's Ally McBeal at 10.30pm suffered from being broadcast against the ITV News at 11pm and BBC2's Newsnight at 10.30pm, pulling in just 2.3m viewers - almost a million down on last week's episode.

The petrol crisis schadenfreude continued last night, with viewers once again tuning in to the news broadcasts in their droves. The BBC's Nine O'Clock News attracted a whopping 8.5m viewers, even better than on Tuesday night, giving it a 36% share.

And BBC1 held on to its late-evening lead by broadcasting a special "Britain Running Dry" report at 9.30pm in place of the scheduled 999. Nearly 8m people stayed with the channel for more on the fuel crisis.

Overall, ITV came off well last night with its Big Match broadcast of the Manchester United versus Anderlecht game at 7.30pm attracting 7.6m viewers. And the highest viewing figures of the day went to Coronation Street, which racked up an impressive 9.9m viewers giving it a 43% share in spite of its later-than-usual 9.45pm slot.

fields.headline: Luke Johnson
fields.standfirst: Read Luke Johnson's column in the Sunday Telegraph
fields.trailText: Luke Johnson, 37, is the founder of an investment trust, Intrinsic Value, and chairman of Belgo Group - the business behind high-profile London restaurants such as The Ivy, Le Caprice and the Belgo chain.
fields.body:
Luke Johnson, 37, is the founder of an investment trust, Intrinsic Value, and chairman of Belgo Group - the business behind high-profile London restaurants such as The Ivy, Le Caprice and the Belgo chain.

Sometimes called a "playboy millionaire", he began investing in public and private companies in 1989 after several years working as a stockbroking analyst at Kleinwort Benson. Successes to date include Topps Tiles, the UK's leading tile retailer (the shares have risen from 50p to over 250p since the company went public three years ago) and American Port Services. The London-listed group was sold for £100m to Associated British Ports in June 1998, showing a return of more than 250% on its 1995 issue price.

Johnson is a non-executive director of many companies including logistics business Nightfreight, venture capitalists VCT, internet incubator fund NewMedia Spark and tea retailer Whittards of Chelsea. As an executive he has seen the Belgo group's share value multiply eightfold since the start of his involvement in 1996 and, previously, was at the helm when Pizza Express's shares rose from 40p to 800p between 1992 and 1999.

However, Johnson gives credit where it's due. In a recent column in the Sunday Telegraph he spent a week as a waiter at his group's Belgo Centraal restaurant in London. It was an "eye-opening experience," he wrote, and concluded that "the success of the restaurant is entirely down to the staff's efforts".

fields.headline: Shareholders blast stock exchange chief
fields.standfirst: The issue explained
fields.trailText: The chairman of the London Stock Exchange today faced a barrage of criticism from shareholders over the failed merger with Germany's Deutsche Borse.
fields.body:
The chairman of the London Stock Exchange today faced a barrage of criticism from shareholders over the failed merger with Germany's Deutsche Borse.

At the group's annual meeting, shareholders expressed their anger with the recent decisions made by the board. They voted by a show of hands against re-electing chief executive Gavin Casey - and his future at the exchange was being decided by a poll vote to be announced later today.

Don Cruickshank's position as chairman was passed, but it is also subject to a further vote. During the meeting Mr Cruickshank vigorously defended his position after this week's collapse of the merger which would have created an exchange called iX.

On Tuesday it pulled out of the merger plans to concentrate on defending itself against the £808m hostile bid from Sweden's OM Gruppen.

Mr Cruickshank told shareholders that the OM bid would offer "exceptionally poor" value and would fail totally to satisfy its customers. The LSE would be preparing a detailed defence over the next 10 days.

Mr Cruickshank added: "In the meantime, we shall continue to work on communicating better and on building trust between the company and its shareholders and customers.

"Warm words will not do. It's about delivering what we said we would do - whether it's something directly in management's control, like improving the efficiency of our markets, or whether it's not directly within management's control, like cross-border settlement costs."

In withdrawing from the merger, the LSE had been responding to concerns about the impact the exchange would have on customers' business, he said.

Mr Cruickshank said the LSE's markets had grown by 18% during the last decade. Group turnover had increased by 10% over the last three years from £146m to £176m. Pre-tax profits had grown sixfold in the same period from £8m to £49m. On the alternative investment market the number of trades by August 2000 was already double that for the whole of last year, he said.

But shareholders were highly critical of the LSE board. One said: "In the last few years the management and strategy errors have seemed to accelerate." Another said: "A board which makes so many errors cannot expect to retain the confidence of shareholders."

fields.headline: Stock exchange mergers
fields.standfirst: As the iX merger between the London Stock Exchange and Frankfurt's Deutsche Boerse collapses, Mark Tran explains the ructions on the world's money markets.
fields.trailText: As the iX merger between the London Stock Exchange and Frankfurt's Deutsche Boerse collapses, Mark Tran explains the ructions on the world's money markets.
fields.body:
What is OM Gruppen?
The group, which owns and operates the Stockholm exchange, is a global leader in developing the software programmes needed to design and run electronic exchanges. It built the platform for the International Securities Exchange, the first electronic options exchange in the US, which started in May. The system can handle about 5,000 transactions per second, according to OM. The Swedish company argues that stock markets will cease to be national institutions and become just an icon on a trader's screen - accessible anywhere, any time.

Why does OM want to take over the London Stock Exchange?
It believes it can run the exchange more efficiently and produce greater returns using the latest technology. It says it is making its £800m bid for the LSE - the first hostile takeover attempt of a bourse - not simply to stop the merger between London and Frankfurt, but to provide an alternative. In May, the LSE and Frankfurt, Europe's two largest exchanges, decided to merge to create a body called iX.

Why are exchanges so keen to merge?
Stock markets are looking for combinations around the world as investors demand lower costs and easier access to other markets. In response to such pressures, the Paris, Amsterdam and Brussels exchanges are combining to create Euronext. The Swiss Exchange and Tradepoint Financial Networks of the UK are setting up an electronic market. And Madrid and Milan are considering joining LSE-DB. Nasdaq, the exchange focusing on technology companies, was planning to join iX as a joint venture partner, with a view to a full merger. The overriding goal of these combinations is to attract investors by making it cheaper to buy and sell shares.

What do City investors think of iX?
The idea behind iX is that trading would be most efficient if it were concentrated in several large traditional exchanges - perhaps eventually one - that could deliver economies of scale and flexible markets. But iX has many critics.

What are the key reservations?
The most important questions are how London and Frankfurt would reconcile their different regulatory regimes and how the two clearing and settlement systems operate together in the short term. Moreover, many LSE shareholders believe think they are getting the raw end of the deal as the 50:50 merger does not take into account LSE assets such as surplus cash and property worth an estimated £267m.

Would investors see a fall in transaction fees under iX? Supposedly, the merger should make it cheaper to buy and sell shares. The biggest cost in trading shares across borders comes in the form of transaction fees charged by companies that settle trades after they have been agreed.

How expensive is it for British investors to buy foreign shares?
According to Don Cruikshank, the LSE's chairman, a British investor buying shares in a German telecommunications company currently pays an average of £100 in transaction charges, compared with £1 to £15 for trading a UK stock. The quickest way to lower costs is merging the settlement companies. But there are no plans to bring together the settlement firms - Crest in London and Clearstream in Frankfurt, which is 50% owned by the Deutsche Börse. However, both are reluctant to give up their independence.

fields.headline: Jennifer Laing quits Saatchi's
fields.trailText: Saatchi & Saatchi New York chief Jennifer Laing has resigned at "the end of an era", reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Jennifer Laing, the high-profile British chairman and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi New York, has resigned to return to the UK.

Laing, who has headed the US operation for the past three-and-a-half years, cited the company's takeover by French advertising group Publicis as her reason for leaving. She views the deal as "the end of an era".

Laing is credited with playing a major role in the survival of Saatchi's following the departure of founders Maurice and Charles in 1995. She set up her own agency, Laing Henry, but was subsequently called back to Saatchi's by the then chairman Charles Scott to stabilise the client list and replace business during the confidence crisis days following the split.

To secure her return, Cordiant Communications, then owner of Saatchi's, bought Laing Henry and brought Laing and her partner, Tony Dalton, back to the helm of the London agency.

Dalton, who had followed Laing to New York as vice-chairman, has also resigned.

The two will remain at Saatchi until November 30, when an eight-strong management partnership will take over the day-to-day running of the North American agency.

Saatchi's worldwide chief executive, Kevin Roberts, said: "[Laing] has spent 30 years loving, nurturing and protecting the Saatchi brand. She will be missed."

The move follows Saatchi's decision to move its global headquarters from London to New York.

webTitle: Stock market embraces reshuffle at Trinity Mirror

fields.headline: Stock market welcomes Trinity Mirror's management reshuffle
fields.trailText: The stock market has welcomed Trinity Mirror's management clear-out, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The stock market welcomed Trinity Mirror's shock management clear-out, but analysts warned it may prove unsettling for the share price in the short term.

Trinity Mirror, the UK's biggest newspaper publisher, overshadowed its improved half-year results by announcing that Roger Eastoe, the group managing director, had resigned and Mike Masters, group managing director of UK and Ireland publishing, had taken early retirement. The group's shares rose 9.5p to 539.5p in early trading, on the back of the news and a 7% rise in first-half turnover.

Paul Sullivan, analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "A lot of the old senior Mirror management have left, so they are bringing in new blood, which may not be a bad thing. But in the short term, any management change is unsettling. The results themselves are relatively reassuring, but nothing spectacular."

Philip Graf, Trinity Mirror chief executive, thanked the pair for their service to the company. Graf added that a new senior executive post will also be created. The group has identified who they want to fill the role and negotiations are nearing the final stages.

This is the latest in a number of changes made by the group after it was formed last year through the merger of Trinity and Mirror group newspapers. John Allwood, group deputy chief executive, resigned in July.

The shake-up in personnel at Trinity Mirror overshadowed first-half results which beat many analysts' expectations. Pre-tax profits rose from £91.1m to £104.5m, on a turnover which climbed from £521.4m to £559.9m.

The revenues for national papers rose 6% from £253.2m to £268.9m, with regional titles up by the same percentage from £231.1m to £245.3m. Despite pulling out of the bidding for Yorkshire Post owner Regional Independent Media, the group is still interested in acquiring an unspecified number of its titles.

The jury is still out on the group's new media ventures, which include the ic24 internet service provider and the icshowbiz central portal. The ic24 service has 540,000 active subscribers, leaving it with some work to do before it catches up with Freeserve's 1.9m membership.

The stock market welcomed the management change and results, marking the Trinity shares up 9.5p to 539.5p.

The stock market welcomed the management change and results, marking the Trinity shares up 9.5p to 539.5p.

fields.headline: Big-Mouths.com scoops four accounts
fields.trailText: Big-Mouths.com has doubled its client portfolio with the addition of four clients, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Eleven-month-old new media PR agency Big-Mouths.com has doubled its client portfolio with the addition of four accounts.

The new additions include WeddingGuideUK.com, recruitment agency Price Jamieson, Tombola, the UK's first online scratchcard website, and Recipero.com, a lost property service for mobile phones and laptops.

Big-Mouths.com's existing accounts include Virgin Mobile, ic24, Virgin Radio and Ginger Online.

The company was founded in October 1999 by Lisa Hulme, former head of PR at Virgin Net, and Victoria McQuade from Text 100.

webTitle: Newspaper distributors ask government for petrol supplies

fields.headline: Newspaper distributors lobby government for priority petrol
fields.trailText: Newspaper distributors lobby the government for preferential treatment in the petrol shortage.
fields.body:
Newspaper distributors are continuing to lobby the government for preferential treatment in the petrol shortage, amid fears that a let-up in the crisis has come too late.

Steve Oram, director of the Newspaper Publishers Association, said that renewed optimism following the ending of the lorry drivers' blockade could be unfounded, with petrol supplies taking too long to trickle through.

"We rang the Department of Trade and Industry and told them about the gap between our current position and what it will be like when supplies eventually get through. We do not know how much fuel the hauliers have left," said Mr Oram.

An emergency meeting between national newspaper circulation departments and newspaper associations was held this morning to draw up contingency plans for distributing weekend editions. Mr Oram would not reveal the emergency plans, but ruled out dropping magazines and supplements from the editions.

David Newell, director of the Newspaper Society, which represents regional and local titles, is hoping the government will review its decision to give fuel priority to emergency services only.

"The situation will be containable provided the fuel gets through to distributors tomorrow," said Mr Newell.

fields.headline: Noah's Ark
fields.trailText: As explorer Robert Ballard finds evidence of an ancient flood of Biblical proportions, we give you the online lowdown on Noah, the Ark and all things floodlike
fields.body:
1. Robert Ballard, oceanography's "own Indiana Jones", has hit on another pearl in Davy Jones's locker. Having previously located the Titanic and the Bismarck, he's managed to find evidence of Noah's Ark.

2. Obviously, as anyone who paid attention in RE will know, the ark stayed afloat. Ballard's not hit on the boat itself, but intriguing hints of the flood itself.

3. Using sonar technology, he's found pre-Greek settlements under the Black Sea whose inhabitants' lives, at some point, got considerably wetter.

4. Geological evidence suggests that, around 7,000 years ago, sea levels in the Mediterranean rose, turning the Bosphorus into a gargantuan, raging cataract, spilling into the Black Sea.

5. Is this one and the same flood? No one's sure, but there are allusions to something big, watery and frightening in several ancient cultural sources. The Babylonian epic of Gilgamesh, the Roman and Greek legend of Deucalion and Pyhrra and, of course, Genesis, all agree on that.

6. As for Noah's party boat itself, it's traditionally supposed to have berthed itself, thanks to its deity-powered, dove-guided homing system, on Mount Ararat in eastern Turkey.

7. The Bible, as is His wont, is slightly reticent on the subject, simply stating that it came to rest in the "mountains of Ararat" in Genesis 8:4. Some folk reckon this could also be Iran.

8. Such nebulousness has, of course, piqued curiosity and, with the break-up of the Soviet Union reducing the danger of over-zealous border guards strafing the ageing timbers, various expeditions were mounted to find the boat in the 80s.

9. Some say it's lodged in a glacier, people have returned with "authentic" wood, but the bottom line is that no one's found substantial evidence. The Lord's doing that mysterious thang again.

10. So did the story take place? Well, as Noah's supposed descendants, you might say that the only evidence is us and buy into deluge chic anyway. Whatever, er, floats yer boat.

fields.headline: Virgin Radio lands net rights to blockbuster movie
fields.trailText: Virgin Radio has clinched the online rights to new blockbuster movie Me, Myself & Irene.
fields.body:
Virgin Radio has clinched the online rights to new blockbuster movie, Me, Myself & Irene, in a deal believed to be the first of its kind in the UK.

Virgin is hosting the film's official website, located at Memyselfandirene.co.uk, and will promote it from September 18 in an on-air campaign. The official website will also be heavily promoted through banners and links on VirginRadio.co.uk.

Kieran Breen, marketing director at 20th Century Fox, said: "Virgin Radio has an excellent pedigree in producing online promotions and events and, like Fox, is always looking to do something new and different.

"Its audience profile of young, internet-savvy, entertainment fans makes it an ideal partner for a gross-out comedy like Me Myself & Irene."

Both Virgin Radio and Fox refused to give details about whether money changed hands.

Me, Myself & Irene opens in the UK on September 22, after already taking more than $90m (£64m) at the US box-office.
