webTitle: Bogus caller demands: Show Me The Money

fields.headline: Bogus caller demands: Show Me The Money
fields.trailText: A group of internet bulletin board tipsters have boasted they knew which stock would be recommended by Channel 4's Show Me The Money, reports Neil Hume.
fields.body:
A group of internet bulletin board tipsters are believed to be at the centre of a stock exchange investigation after boasting online that they knew which stock would be recommended by Channel 4's Show Me The Money the next day.

One poster, who appears under the cyberspace name of Wideeye, posted the message: "I fancy them to tip Screen and for it to rise by about 20% by 12.55pm. Just one of my hunches of course!!!!???"

The hunch, though, could prove a little too well informed. Suspicions were aroused after it emerged that Sun business editor Ian King, who had been planning to tip shares when he appeared as a guest on the show yesterday lunchtime, was duped into revealing what he intended to pick by a phone caller pretending to be from the show.

Around 2pm on Tuesday a man claiming to be a researcher for Princess Productions, the company behind the show, called Mr King asking him to pass on the company details.

"Somebody did ring Ian, claiming to work on the show and asked him to name his tip for the day," said Richard Hastings, series producer of Show Me The Money.

"He did give the tip, which of course was changed."

Shortly after Mr King was tricked into naming the stock, the news leaked out to the internet and shares in Screen, which makes security products, shot up 25%. "It was amazing. The phones on the dealing desk just lit up. They all wanted to buy Screen," said one market-marker.

Screen shares eventually came off the boil to close 1.5p higher at 15.5p, leaving dealers moaning that a false market had been created in the shares.

Mr Hastings, however, was unrepentant: "We are quite glad it happened. It shows the lengths people will go to."

fields.headline: Press cuttings go online
fields.trailText: An online search engine and cuttings service hits the net today, hoping to cash in on the proliferation of media sources on the web.
fields.body:
An online search engine and cuttings service hits the net today, hoping to cash in on the proliferation of media sources on the web.

The tool - customised for companies, public relations groups and government departments - will allow users to go online to find out quickly what is being said about them or their clients in the press or on radio and television.

Bmcnews.com, which is being launched today by the Broadcast Monitoring Company, claims to be the first high speed service that can deliver newspaper cuttings, radio and television clips and internet articles directly to clients' computers.

"Clients will be able to receive online a totally comprehensive account of what has been written or said about them or their industry in print, on the internet, on radio or television internationally," said Dan Levin, chairman of BMC.

The world of media monitoring is growing fast because of the exponential growth in media content from new radio and television channels and the internet. BMC already employs some 500 people.

The online version of the monitoring system provides a search facility where every word is scanned and key words picked up. The system is "intelligent" enough to connect terms where the search consists of more than one word.

The system can also provide succinct summaries of news. But people will not become entirely redundant because of the advent of this system, John Gordon, chief executive of the company, says.

The computer is not intelligent enough to deal with issues so there is a need for a dual service - skilled people who understand sectors and concepts will have to work alongside the new system.

fields.headline: C5 aims for 10% audience share
fields.trailText: RTL, the television and radio group which has a controlling stake in Channel 5 yesterday said plans to substantially increase spending on programming would lift the station's audience share to 10% within two to three years.
fields.body:
RTL, the television and radio group which has a controlling stake in Channel 5 yesterday said plans to substantially increase spending on programming would lift the station's audience share to 10% within two to three years.

Didier Bellens, RTL's chief executive, said the company was working with the channel's management to agree on the levels of investment it would need. Channel 5 has a budget of £130m, and he said a figure of £200m would not be inconceivable.

The station, which launched in 1997, commands a 6% share of the UK audience.

RTL is keen to shift the channel away from its cheap and cheerful image and to tone down some of the broadcaster's more prurient programming. The station, which shows soft porn late at night and caused controversy with the show Naked Jungle featuring a nude Keith Chegwin, has been dubbed "channel filth" by the Daily Mail.

Richard Eyre, director of strategy and content at RTL said the "mix will change", with a greater emphasis on original content. He said there would be particular emphasis on drama to attract viewers away from the BBC and ITV.

webTitle: End to EU's Austrian sanctions cheers pro-euro Danes

fields.headline: End to EU's Austrian sanctions cheers pro-euro Danes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Danish leaders yesterday breathed a sigh of relief after 14 European Union governments agreed to lift sanctions against Austria - one of the issues seized upon by anti-euro campaigners who are hoping to persuade Danes to reject adoption of the single currency in a crucial referendum in two weeeks' time.
fields.body:
Danish leaders yesterday breathed a sigh of relief after 14 European Union governments agreed to lift sanctions against Austria - one of the issues seized upon by anti-euro campaigners who are hoping to persuade Danes to reject adoption of the single currency in a crucial referendum in two weeeks' time.

With the latest polls confirming steady support for the "no" campaign, the long-awaited removal of the sanctions cheered "yes" supporters even as the plummeting value of the euro emerged as their biggest worry.

Many Danes saw last January's decision to impose a quarantine on Austria after the far-right Freedom party joined its coalition government as bullying by bigger nations. This is a sensitive issue in a small country that has always been ambivalent about European integration.

The prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, had been pressing fellow EU leaders to act quickly after last weekend's long-awaited report by three "wise men" gave Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel's government a clean bill of health, while condemning the Freedom party, formerly led by Jörg Haider.

The Danish leader also made it clear that he had opposed French demands for the creation of a permanent mechanism for monitoring Austrian observance of human rights.

But he was criticised by the leader of the opposition Liberal party, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, who said: "If some people want to bestow honour on the prime minister it would be like honouring an arsonist for putting out a fire he started himself."

If the Danes rejected the single currency on September 28, it would be another blow for the faltering euro.

It would also make it much less likely that the British and Swedish governments would embark on their own referendums.

This week the euro registered new lows against the dollar, despite insistence by the European Central Bank that the euro-zone's economic fundamentals are sound.

Yesterday's polls produced a mixed but still worrying picture for the yes camp: Gallup for Berlingske Tidende newspaper found 45% voting for no and 40% for yes. Vilstrup for Politiken found a dead heat at 41 % each side. Greens for Boersen reported 48% in favour and 44% against.

The foreign minister, Niels Helveg Petersen, urged euro supporters to try harder to present the facts - not least of which is the assessment that staying out of euroland would isolate Denmark and could prompt heavy speculation against the krone.

Opponents of the euro have repeatedly accused the government of trying to scare the electorate into voting yes.

fields.headline: What the world's papers say
fields.standfirst: The rest of the world is turning its eye to the UK's petrol crisis. Here's how newspapers across the globe are reporting the news
fields.trailText: The rest of the world is turning its eye to the UK's petrol crisis. Here's how newspapers across the globe are reporting the news
fields.body:
Sydney Morning Herald
Australia's biggest morning daily chose to highlight the deepening political problems the situation has created for the prime minister. It said Mr Blair had been forced to "put his leadership on the line" by pledging to bring chronic fuel shortages to an end within 24 hours. It went on: "But the dispute - which has caused the cancellation of elective surgery and non-emergency ambulance services, left shops short of food and forced the closure of remote schools - has damaged the government. Opinion polls show 90% of Britons siding with truckies and farmers demanding cuts in fuel taxes."

The New York Times
The fuel blockaders have won a "moral victory" after forcing the issue into the spotlight, according to the US broadsheet. "Fuel tax protesters whose demonstrations had dried up tanks at British gas stations called off a slew of key blockades Thursday," it said, adding that the victory would have turned sour and led to a loss of public support had they continued.

Le Monde
France's national daily has its tongue firmly in its cheek when it says Tony Blair might privately be blaming the French for setting an example with its fuel protests earlier this month. It describes the protesters as "paralysing" Britain and says the government is on the verge of calling in the army to ensure delivery of supplies.

Straits Times
This daily Singapore broadsheet reckons it's good old-fashioned people power that is the key to the protest. "Petrol stations will lose millions of pounds in sales as motorists stay away in protest against British petrol costs which are still the highest in Europe, despite the price falls over the past week. Over 40% of all British drivers have told organisers of the boycott that they will not be buying petrol today - and then every Monday from next week, as part of their protests," it says.

fields.headline: Schröder defends German fuel tax
fields.trailText: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, defended Germany's petrol taxes today, as criticism mounted in the country's parliament and on the streets.
fields.body:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, defended Germany's petrol taxes today, as criticism mounted in the country's parliament and on the streets.

Hundreds of farmers, truckers and taxi drivers tied up traffic around Germany, demanding relief from high prices.

More than 500 vehicles brought traffic to a halt in central Hanover, while a similar convoy to the statehouse in Magdeburg, in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt, caused jams there.

Lorry drivers maintained blockades set up early this week at border-crossings between Germany and Belgium for trucks. Passenger cars were being allowed through at some crossings, but only with considerable delays, police in Aachen on the Belgian border said.

Deliveries were being blocked from two refineries in the northern German cities of Lingen im Emsland and Wilhelmshaven by around 70 farmers on tractors, local authorities said.

The demonstrators were demanding the repeal of the "ecology tax", which was introduced by Mr Schröder's government, adding a few pennies to the price of a litre of petrol each year.

Mr Schröder told ARD television on Wednesday night that the proceeds of the tax were needed to reduce labour costs and fight high unemployment.

However, some form of targeted relief for those whose livelihood was threatened by the rise in energy prices was being considered, he continued.

Labour Minister Walter Riester told parliament during a debate today that two thirds of the DM25bn (£7.8bn) that has been collected so far has gone to financing reductions in the contributions employees and companies have to make for pensions, with the rest going to shore up the system itself.

Mr Riester said that the government was sticking "openly and honestly" to the tax, calling it "indispensable".

But Horst Seehofer, a member of conservative opposition Christian Social Union party, accused the government of breaking its word by raising the pension contributions next year anyway.

The European Central Bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, warned European countries against letting appeals for relief from high fuel prices pull them away from their goal of fiscal discipline.

"Higher oil prices place a burden on the economy as a whole," he said. "Any attempts to shift that burden inside an economy from one sector to another - be it by government, special interest groups, truckers, pilots - does nothing to affect the fact that the burden is still there."

webTitle: Has Blair got the stomach to win?

fields.headline: Has Blair got the stomach to win?
fields.standfirst: The real shock of the petrol crisis has been the way the government has proved powerless to stop it, says Julian Glover
fields.trailText: The real shock of the petrol crisis has been the way the government has proved powerless to stop it, says Julian Glover.
fields.body:
The last week must have bewildered those who are convinced that the government is a hotbed of control-freaks.

A prime minister who normally slaps down the humblest backbencher for slipping slightly off-message and who writes memos demanding that "I personally" be associated with government action seems to have been able to do nothing about Britain's fuel crisis.

Petrol is now more easily available in Freetown, Sierra Leone, than in central London: an astonishing turnaround.

But is this the prime minister's fault? Not really, is the answer. In theory, Blair should be able to get the trucks moving again at a click of his fingers.

This country has no written constitution; the government's authority derives from the crown and, despite our democratic traditions, it is almost unlimited (give or take the odd distraction such as Magna Carta).

Bill Clinton has expressed his envy at the prime minister's power: he can order the army into battle, dictate the budget, bully the home secretary the options appear endless.

In reality, this power is highly constrained. Prime Ministers arrive in the job full of ideas as to what they will be able to do. These hopes do not last long.

Prime Ministers must cajole, persuade and campaign: they can rarely order.

So what options are open to Tony Blair in the present crisis?

First, he commands immense personal authority. Phone calls from the Number 10 switchboard are never refused and he can drag even the most senior oil company executive from his bed in the small hours of the morning.

Likewise, he can make repeated personal statements on television - a tactic Blair has used to good effect in his efforts to turn the mood against the blockades.

Nobody doubts that Blair has the skills a prime minister needs in this area. But the strikes continue. So what else can he do?

His second area of strength is his command over the whole government machine: ministers answer to him and civil servants standby to put his policies into action.

Since parliament is not sitting, the prime minister's powers in this area are all the greater. The opposition can only challenge him in the TV studios.

The trouble is, the crisis is not one that can be solved by a change of government policy, at least not in the short term now that Blair has set his face against caving in to demands to cut taxes.

This leaves a third area of power as his only real option: the right to take emergency measures such as calling in the army.

Such powers have already been used to set aside fuel supplies for the emergency services. But there is a limit to the lengths the prime minister will be prepared to go in this area.

After all, he has an election to win soon; the sight of troops on the streets will not help him with this - and anyway, the army, at full stretch around the world, is far from able to sustain Britain's massive fuel supply network.

In 1974, Ted Heath found that he could not prevent the three-day week. In the 1980s, Margaret Thatcher could not prevent the coal miners striking for almost a year.

In the end, Heath lost, Thatcher won. But the result was decided not by the strength - or otherwise - of the government's formal powers but by the character of those running it.

This dispute, too, will come down to one question: which side blinks first.

fields.headline: Global oil market rudderless
fields.standfirst: With little sign of worldwide oil prices taking a downward turn, there seems to be no much-needed economic masterplan to sort out a damaging situation, says Terry Macalister
fields.trailText: With little sign of worldwide oil prices taking a downward turn, there seems to be no much-needed economic masterplan to sort out a damaging situation, says Terry Macalister.
fields.body:
Oil prices could remain above $27 (£19) per barrel over the next 12 months, more than 50% higher than the average over the last decade, and be characterised by high levels of volatility, some experts are warning.

This is bad news for motorists unless the government reduces petrol taxes in the aftermath of the country's biggest civil disturbances since the 1970s. A really cold winter and price peaks of up to $40 (£28) per barrel are highly likely.

A top economist from blue chip US investment bank Goldman Sachs said in London earlier this week there was a 5% probability prices could even reach $67 (£48) per barrel. But another US finance house, Salomon Smith Barney, says to expect prices in the region of $28 (£20) for the remainder of this year and $24 (£17) in 2001.

The reason for the continuing high price of crude oil is growing demand from recovering economies in Asia and the continuing strength of the business climate in America and Europe.

Supply remains curtailed by cuts made in investment two years ago under the impact of low crude prices and plummeting profits. This pushed many producing nations such as Saudi Arabia and Venezuela towards financial crisis, because their economies are so dependent on crude export revenues. It also badly hit the shares price of the corporate sector and forced them to cut exploration and field development.

It is difficult to believe that barely 18 months ago North sea crude was being sold on the open market at less than $10 (£7) per barrel and there was speculation it could move toward $5 (£3.50). So what has happened over the intervening period? Opec came under intense pressure from the US government to reduce output in order to force the crude price up.

Washington was worried then about its own domestic oil industry, which was being driven out of business. Texas is still a state packed full of "nodding donkeys", onshore rigs which produce a few barrels of oil a day for small proprietors. Millions are employed in the wider oil industry there and the world's biggest corporations, such as Exxon (which trades as Esso in Britain), exercise huge political muscle.

Even though many Opec nations were frightened that cutting production would reduce their income further, the cartel, led by its biggest producer Saudi Arabia (which has close political ties with the US), agreed to president Clinton's demands.

New production quotas were introduced in April 1999 and by June output had fallen dramatically. Oil prices recovered dramatically and by the start of this year were over $30 (£21) per barrel.

Since then Opec has been under pressure to increase output to try to lower the price and on three successive occasions has agreed to put more crude on the market. To little avail: prices have dipped briefly following Opec actions, but they bounced back as traders fretted about rising demand and low stock levels in refineries.

Now Opec says it might be willing to put an extra 2m barrels onto the market and the US might leak some of its emergency supplies onto the market in a bid to help lower prices. The bellwether October Brent futures contract fell nearly a dollar on this news, but remained at $32.10 (£23) at the end of last night's trading.

This has left everyone scratching their head about what the oil markets really want. Professor Peter Odell, a world-regarded petroleum expert from the London School of Economics concludes: "There is no vestige of economic rational in the present oil price situation. What we appear to have is the result of market manipulation and political pressures."

fields.headline: U-turn over petrol price hike
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the petrol war

 Esso's about-turn
 BNP infiltrates demos
 More emergency meetings at Downing Street
 Prince of Wales cancels engagements
fields.trailText: Oil giant Esso tonight announced it was reversing its decision to up the price of petrol after it recognised the raise was "against the spirit" of the current fuel shortage crisis.
fields.body:
Oil giant Esso tonight announced it was reversing its decision to up the price of petrol after it recognised the raise was "against the spirit" of the current fuel shortage crisis.

Earlier, the company had come under fire after plans emerged for a hike in petrol prices at the height of the fuel crisis and amid a drop in the cost of crude oil.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, said he could not understand why Esso had announced price increases when Shell and BP had kept theirs static. He had said: "I really cannot understand that Esso decision. I mean, the world oil price, as far as I'm aware, has actually come down in the last few days."

Mr Blair was expected to raise the issue when he met oil company bosses later today - but a statement from Esso this evening pre-empted those discussions..

Earlier, the far right British National party claimed to have infiltrated the fuel protests. Its national chairman, Nick Griffin, said members had been involved in various parts of the country and had used the opportunity to recruit new members.

The price of Brent Crude has fallen from a high last week of $34.60 (£24.57) a barrel and was trading at $31.82 a barrel today, having opened this morning at $31.70 a barrel, according to the International Petroleum Exchange.

Esso, which supplies 1,600 service stations nationwide, announced increases in the cost of unleaded petrol by 2p per litre and diesel by 4p per litre.

The move was attacked by motoring organisations as "insensitive" and protesters who had earlier lifted their picket at Coryton, Essex, reinstated their blockade following the news.

Petrol retailers have already warned that an end to the fuel crisis is still weeks away - and the pockets of resistance which remained at some sites, where diehard pickets refused to give up, looked like regrouping.

Meanwhile, the problem has hit the Prince of Wales who has been forced to cancel royal engagements. The prince turned down an offer of petrol from the police, saying he was not an emergency service.

The first signs that the protests were crumbling came at the Shell refinery at Stanlow, Cheshire, shortly after 5am.

Soon afterwards, protesters at Grangemouth, Scotland's only refinery, and the giant Avonmouth plant near Bristol also voted to call it a day.

Brynle Williams, spokesman for the protesters who arrived at Stanlow a week ago, said: "It was pure common sense to end the protest. We have made our point to the government and the British public have supported us 100%.

"But we decided after seven nights to stand down while we still have the moral high ground."

Mr Williams, a north Wales farmer who is widely regarded as the instigator of the nationwide revolt, added: "I'm hoping that this will end this protest nationally."

The developments came as the armed forces deployed oil tankers across Britain in case they were needed as the fuel crisis deepened.

The government turned to the military after Mr Blair admitted the country faced a national crisis with "lives at risk" as the emergency worsened.

And again today the Conservative leader, William Hague, called on Mr Blair to apologise for "a problem of his government's making".

Mr Hague added: "This has been a catalogue of arrogance, complacency and broken promises. The government is simply not listening to the people. If they really want to listen, they would have parliament back in session.

"They are seriously out of touch with the burdens they put on the hard-working families of this country."

Ministers were due to meet later today, with businesses up and down the country crippled by the shortages, the NHS on red alert and thousands of pupils kept at home as the stand-off paralyses school bus services.

Supermarkets have reported a run on food stocks, the Royal Mail has been warning it will be hit by the crisis, and the Premier League and Football League were deciding today whether to cancel any weekend football matches.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, said he would "listen" to people's concerns over the level of taxes on fuel. But he insisted he would not allow public protests or fluctuations in the world oil price to determine his taxation policies.

The Transport and General Workers Union said it welcomed today's developments and officials believed it was now safe for tanker drivers to resume fuel deliveries.

The union has been expressing concern all week about the safety of drivers following reports that lorries were being "cut up" on roads and even attacked by some protesters.

The general secretary, Bill Morris, said: "I am now confident that the conditions exist for all our drivers to resume normal working."

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today denied he had been scaremongering by placing the NHS on red alert. "We will continue to listen but there's a responsibility on those who are organising these illegal pickets, this intimidation and violence," he told GMTV.

"They have got a duty to listen. If they don't want to listen to me fair dues, but what they must do is listen to the doctors and nurses and the managers who are warning them that in all parts of the country the situation can only get worse in the national health service if they don't lift the blockades."

webTitle: Key Players: The oil men at No 10

fields.headline: Key Players: The oil men at No 10
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's crisis talks around the cabinet table yesterday were with nine of the men who really run Britain.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's crisis talks around the cabinet table yesterday were with nine of the men who really run Britain.

The prime minister read the riot act to representatives of six oil giants and a tanker fleet operator to urge them to get supplies out of refineries and onto forecourts - fast.

BP, which operates 1,600 petrol stations in the UK, sent its group vice president John Manzoni and policy head Nick Butler, once a Fabian Society leading light and a force behind the pro-EU Centre for European Reform, who is close to New Labour.

The Shell chief executive Malcolm Brinder was present as were the senior Mobil executive Ansel Coudray, David Cod of Texaco and Conoco's Greg Gough. Total sent Charles Henderson and Malcolm Jones into the prime minister's firing line.

The P&O executive chairman, Lord Sterling, whose firm runs a huge fleet of tankers, was also at the meeting. An ardent admirer of Lady Thatcher, Lord Sterling bussed strike breakers through picket lines more than a decade ago during a ferry dispute in Dover.

webTitle: Protest in capital foiled but northern rush hour hit

fields.headline: Protest in capital foiled but northern rush hour hit
fields.standfirst:
Police pen convoy in Park Lane
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Police yesterday acted to thwart a convoy of scores of lorries from paralysing central London. The truckers had planned to drive through the capital, choking streets and causing gridlock.
fields.body:
Police yesterday acted to thwart a convoy of scores of lorries from paralysing central London. The truckers had planned to drive through the capital, choking streets and causing gridlock.

But Scotland Yard penned the lorries in a half-mile stretch of Park Lane up to Hyde Park Corner, and prevented them from driving to Parliament Square where they had wanted to stage a demonstration.

Protest leaders claim 200 trucks took part, police put the numbers at 60.

The drivers had been planning their tactics since Tuesday lunchtime, using mobile phones to organise meeting points. One of the protest leaders, Terry Rogers, warned of bigger shows of strength if the government failed to meet its demands: "If we wanted to bring London to a standstill, we could.

"The whole idea of today is to cause disruption. If Blair is adamant, the next one will be a do-or-die situation, we'll bring London to a total standstill, we'll block every road."

Mr Rogers said he wanted 2p cut off the price of a litre of fuel, which the government says would cost £1bn.

Like other truckers, Paul Davie said he did not know which other public services should suffer the resultant spending cuts, other than saying that millions should not have been spent on the Millennium Dome.

Mr Davie, an owner driver, said fuel price hikes meant it cost him £200 to fill his tank with diesel compared to £130 two years ago: "It's costing me £300 a week. It's crucifying us."

He said he takes home £450 for a 75-hour week, the same as two years ago.

Deputy assistant commis sioner Andy Trotter, who was in charge of policing of the protest, denied claims that his officers were going soft on the truckers. "Its a matter of balancing the right to demonstrate against public safety," he said.

webTitle: New-style action takes old order by surprise

fields.headline: New-style action takes old order by surprise
fields.standfirst:
Protesters: All sections of the community have united to keep the blockade solid
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: It was three-quarters of the way through the 24 hours which a grim-faced Tony Blair had given for the fuel situation to be getting back to normal, and nothing outside the Elf terminal here had changed. Half a dozen policemen were lolling in their van or strolling around beside it, chatting to protesters. Eighteen lorries, their windscreens and engine cowlings covered with "Fair Play on Fuel" stickers, were parked on the verge where the terminal's access road meets the highway.
fields.body:
It was three-quarters of the way through the 24 hours which a grim-faced Tony Blair had given for the fuel situation to be getting back to normal, and nothing outside the Elf terminal here had changed. Half a dozen policemen were lolling in their van or strolling around beside it, chatting to protesters. Eighteen lorries, their windscreens and engine cowlings covered with "Fair Play on Fuel" stickers, were parked on the verge where the terminal's access road meets the highway.

Determined hauliers and their wives stood nearby, ready to move out on to the road at the sight of any tanker trying to leave the refinery. Most ominously of all for the government, virtually every private car which drove past hooted in support or gave the thumbs up. Occasionally one would stop to hand out sandwiches or even an urn of tea.

The New Normality of a protest which seems to have united all sections of the community, at least in this part of south Wales, is winning out over the Old Normality which the prime minister is desperately trying to restore. Maybe it is that with their own tanks full thanks to last weekend's panic buying people can afford to let the protest go on a bit longer. Genuine inconvenience down here seems to be minimal, in spite of all the London talk of the country being paralysed, and the campaign for lower fuel taxes is certainly popular in a rural area where life has come to depend on the car.

Thirteen tankers rumbled out of the terminal here shortly after dawn yesterday, but this was no different from the first day of the protest. "We check the drivers' dockets and make sure they are going on emergency business for ambulance depots, the fire service, hospital generators and the like," said Philip Knight, a spokesman for the protesters. "This is what we've been doing all the time. There's no change there."

He had just emerged from a meeting in the Elf terminal with its security staff and the police. "This is a peaceful protest in full cooperation with the police. The police just wanted to discuss the state of affairs. Were we happy with the way they're handling things? We said yes," he explained. A police sergeant confirmed that Mr Blair's speech had brought no shift in tactics. "Our strength here is still the bare minimum. The hauliers are making their case peacefully", he said.

Mr Knight acknowledged that some tanker drivers were "wary for themselves and their vehicles" if they tried to drive out on a non-emergency fuel run. "There's no problem here in the vicinity, but you don't know what might happen further away and to get a police car to follow a tanker is a big thing," he said.

The populist direct action by small business which this protest represents may be new for Britain but it has many traditional ingredients of trade union militancy - a feeling that politicians, whether they call themselves left or right or Third Way, don't really care; that the media distorts their case; and that employers or in this instance the government fails to negotiate unless pressure is applied through withholding services or labour. "It's never been so hard to make ends meet. I've been up to London twice for demonstrations and to lobby Parliament," said John Jones, who runs five lorries. "We've been fighting for a reduction in fuel tax for two years, and got nowhere."

No future

"There's no future in this area," his wife, Shirley, chipped in. They have spent four nights outside the terminal, sleeping in the cab of their lorry. "Our son, Gareth, is doing a university course in chemistry. We've encouraged him not to come into the business. Family businesses are dying out."

Tackled on the argument that if the government gives in and lowers fuel taxes, there will be less money for schools and hospitals, her friend Kim Lewis snorted. "They're not even keeping schools open," she said. "They closed Bwlch-y-groes primary school, a perfectly good thriving school, in July because they want to amalgamate it. Schools are the hub of a village, like churches used to be. We fought to keep it open. As for hospitals, waiting lists are getting longer."

Other hauliers insist that all they want is a "level playing field" with fuel taxes brought down to the European average so that they can compete. They see French lorries coming over to nearby Fishguard with full tanks of diesel, delivering a load of goods, then working for local British companies for a week until the fuel runs out, and then going home. But their animosity is not ethnically directed against the French. They worry about unfair competition.

Across the road sits Michael (he would not give his real name), an owner driver who has only one vehicle. "I voted Labour last time, but won't do it again unless they kick Tony Blair into touch and let someone negotiate with us. All this talk of intimidation is government spin. You can see this is a peaceful protest. Some owner-drivers are in the Transport and General Workers' Union. Others are not. But this isn't a union thing. It's a business. At the beginning they said single-lorry owners wouldn't take part in this protest because we would have to keep on working. But we're in it alongside the bigger companies. There's no gain without pain."

Many protesters say they were inspired by the success of the French hauliers protests a week ago, though they point out their grievances are long-standing even if their tactics are new. Many also say they found Mr Blair's tough talk of intimidation and not giving in both offensive and a challenge. The scandal of the Millennium Dome is also regularly mentioned as a sign that the government has got its priorities wrong.

The fuel protest has brought in farmers and fishermen. Dai Jones, a lobsterman from Cardigan, was sitting by the road. "I have an eighteen-footer which runs on petrol. I've been fishing for 15 years but will have to pack it in unless the price goes down." Steve Glover, who shoes horses for a living, was radicalised by the countryside protests in favour of hunting and enjoyed the big demonstration in London. Now he was in a yellow reflecting jacket beside the hauliers.

Support

Admitting he voted Conservative because of the hunting issue, he is looking forward to protesting at the Labour party conference in two weeks' time. "I'll be there. I'm getting the hang of it," he laughed. But at 39 and with two small children, he is not really a tearaway. "We watched Blair on TV yesterday. He fired us up. To say that in 24 hours everything would be normal. That's a big promise. We only decided to come down here last night when we heard some people were disbanding. We wanted to show our support".

Away from the front line the protest has strong backing, especially as emergency services are not being affected. "We are working normally," said George Oulton, control manger for ambulance services in Pembrokeshire, in his office at Withybush hospital in Haverfordwest. "I've not heard anyone here who doesn't support the protesters." A hundred yards away the Murco petrol station got new supplies from Elf yesterday. It allowed hospital staff and other emergency workers to fill their cars on production of an identity card.

Two housekeepers in uniforms emerge from the hospital's main entrance. "I'm in favour of these protests. They've started now. We've got to support them," said Diane Roberts. "I voted Labour, but Blair is trying to be a Thatcher. It's not true there is intimidation."

The rhetoric is tough and the sentiments sincere but there is still an amazing amount of good humour about these protests. Community solidarity helps and the feeling that real hardship has not yet arrived. "We're all in support as long as it's not really affecting us", laughed Edith Whitby. "Ask me in a fortnight's time when I haven't got any petrol left."

For the government, especially now that it has put a short deadline on its hopes of ending it, the protest is not going to be so easy to handle.

fields.headline: Cabbies slow traffic to crawl
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Manchester's morning rush-hour traffic was brought to a   near standstill yesterday as 150 black cab drivers staged a go-slow protest calculated to cause maximum disruption to commuters.
fields.body:
Manchester's morning rush-hour traffic was brought to a near standstill yesterday as 150 black cab drivers staged a go-slow protest calculated to cause maximum disruption to commuters.

More than 70 black cabs travelled under police escort from Manchester airport to the city, driving four abreast and slowing early morning traffic to a 10mph crawl. The protest caused lengthy tailbacks on the M56 into the city.

They were later joined by a second convoy which started from Manchester City's football ground and made a tour of the city before dispersing peacefully.

Some taxis had been painted with slogans reading Enough is Enough and Fair Deal, not Raw Deal. Many had stuck banners to their windows demanding a fuel price cut.

But the protest was not as disruptive as organisers had hoped, since traffic into the centre of Manchester was comparatively light. The main convoy from the airport was also held back until the worst of the commuter traffic had passed, though police denied this was an attempt to sabotage the protest.

"It doesn't matter if it is the tax on fuel or the fuel companies' charges, but fuel is costing me £180 per week. My wages have gone down and down and the price has gone up every week."

Mr Maguire said he now works 13 days out of every fortnight, from which he makes around £200 per week before tax. "Something had to be done," he said. "We can only take so much."

"If I worked a 40-hour week I would be bankrupt," said another taxi driver, who did not want to give his name. "You have to put in a 70-hour week just to be able to survive."

The station ran out of fuel on Saturday and long queues formed as soon as the tanker was spotted on the forecourt. No rationing policy was introduced and managers estimated that tanks would be dry again in 10 hours.

He put 35.08 litres into his tank and headed for the motorway.

webTitle: How the oil men faced down a furious PM

fields.headline: How the oil men faced down a furious PM
fields.standfirst: Rush of activity as cabinet tries to get a grip
fields.trailText: The sun streaming through the cabinet room windows yesterday produced one of the few bright spots in the Downing Street bunker as the petrol crisis threatened to wreck the economy and Tony Blair's political credibility.
fields.body:
The sun streaming through the cabinet room windows yesterday produced one of the few bright spots in the Downing Street bunker as the petrol crisis threatened to wreck the economy and Tony Blair's political credibility.

Sitting in his normal seat in the middle of the polished cabinet table for an emergency meeting, the prime minister's mood was grim as he addressed not his ministers but nine men he believes could get Britain moving again.

The oil industry senior executives who filed in at 10.30am had been summoned for what turned out to be a 70-minute dressing down by Mr Blair, who read the riot act.

Flanked by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the home secretary, Jack Straw, and with forecourts continuing to run dry the day after he told the public the crisis would ease within 24 hours, the prime minister's frustration was clear.

Sir John Evans of the Association of Chief Police Officers promised that routes would be cleared through demonstrators and escorts provided. The oil men replied that drivers had been intimidated and were afraid to take out tankers. But Mr Blair wanted answers not excuses and left them in no doubt about what he expected.

"I couldn't have made it any clearer this morning," he said last night. "I expect these fuel supplies to be delivered and there is no reason why they should not be."

For once, talk of Mr Blair's "worst week" cannot be dismissed by No 10 spindoctors as hype or exaggeration as new Labour struggles in 2000 to deal with a crisis that threatens more disruption than the 1978-79 winter of discontent that led to the defeat of old Labour.

Ministers had worked until midnight on Tuesday, talking to the oil executives and individual refineries as well as to police, with Mr Blair personally telephoning chairmen and chief executives to pressure them into acting. However, it had become clear as Mr Blair went to bed in the flat above the "shop" that the blockades had not been lifted.

He decided first thing yesterday morning to call in the oil executives for a face to face meeting to demand they order their drivers to start delivering fuel, especially to essential services.

Sitting opposite him, however, were stony-faced oil men, employees of huge global corporations who gave only limited assurances with a statement read out on the steps of Downing Street by the Shell chief executive, Malcolm Brinder, falling short of the guarantee to resume supplies that No 10 had wanted.

One executive said: "We were in listening mode, but we pointed out we would not force drivers out if they felt intimidated."

The civil contingencies committee chaired by Mr Straw met twice - once in the morning and once in the afternoon - to review the position and hear news of severe runs on food, the possibility of mail services coming to an end and reports there would be serious job lay-offs by the weekend.

Mr Blair met the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and then spoke to him a couple of times over the phone as the government struggled to get a grip.

Government sources by mid-afternoon betrayed their despondency, one pointing the finger of blame at the oil moguls and darkly hinting of unspecified reprisals. "The plain fact is that the oil companies keep making promises that something is about to happen at particular refineries and then we wait and nothing happens. It's fair to say our patience is beginning to erode," he said.

No 10 officials admitted, however, that Mr Blair could do little more than plead or try to shame oil companies into delivering fuel because he has little leverage to use on some of the biggest multinationals in the world.

As the day wore on and it became increasingly clear the hoped-for breakthrough was not emerging, government strategic planners - meetings had stared at 6am and continued throughout the day - started to work on more drastic options.

Some sources said Mr Blair was being pressed to use troops by the weekend, although others pointed out that the army was "not full" of service personnel capable of driving petrol tankers.

As the contingencies unit was reviewing its possibilities, the government was also considering the public relations battle with the demonstrators.

It became clear that the press secretary, Alastair Campbell, had decided he needed to highlight a possible crisis in the NHS to try to reduce public support for the protesters.

Mr Prescott had fumed on early morning television, Mr Brown had promised to "listen" at lunchtime and last night Mr Blair was defensive as he warned that the protesters were putting lives at risk and urged an end to the blockades.

Discussions were also held about a recall of parliament. Some ministers argued it would exacerbate the crisis, harden picket line opinion and give a platform for the Tory leader, William Hague, to claim the taxpayers' revolt represented a political earthquake. Others argued it would highlight the importance of parliamentary democracy.

Drivers had threatened to blockade Mr Blair in Downing Street until the police halted a convoy at London's Hyde Park Corner, triggering huge traffic jams.

The TUC stepped up its condemnation of the action when John Monks, the union's general secretary, recalled that drivers helped Gen Pinochet topple President Salvador Allende 27 years ago in Chile.

"Let me remind you of another occasion when trucks and lorries were used by the self-employed and the far right to attack democracy," Mr Monks said at the annual TUC congress in Glasgow. "That was in 1973 in Chile and it started a chain of events which brought down the Allende government. That is why we call on Britain's trade unionists to work normally and to take no part in this bosses' blockade."

As he sits in his Downing Street bunker, Mr Blair could be forgiven for thinking of Harold Macmillan's edict on the greatest enemy of governments: events.

fields.headline: Opec offers price cut hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The 11-nation organisation of petroleum exporting countries last night threw a lifeline to embattled western governments when it held out the prospect of pumping an extra 2m barrels of crude a day to help prevent a further escalation in world prices.
fields.body:
The 11-nation organisation of petroleum exporting countries last night threw a lifeline to embattled western governments when it held out the prospect of pumping an extra 2m barrels of crude a day to help prevent a further escalation in world prices.

Ali Rodriguez, Venezuela's oil minister and the president of Opec, said that the cartel - blamed by Britain for triggering the current crisis - would respond if a tough winter in the rich countries of the north boosted demand for oil and sent prices spiralling towards $40 a barrel.

The announcement prompted an immediate decline in the price of oil in the world's financial markets, which had shrugged off a decision by Opec at the weekend to raise production by 800,000 barrels a day as inadequate. Brent crude fell by more than 50 cents to $31.58 a barrel - its lowest for two weeks.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, said Britain was determined to find an international way out of its domestic problems. "The correct way to deal with this [fuel crisis] is to put pressure on the oil producing nations and that we will continue to do."

Stung by criticism that it risks sending the world into recession and killing off the demand which has sent the price of crude soaring from under $10 a barrel to a 10-year high of $34.50 last week, Opec is now trying to push the cost of oil back below $30 a barrel.

fields.headline: Emergency health measures drawn up
fields.standfirst:
NHS alert Milburn warns of pressures on hospitals
Special report: the petrol war
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Alan Milburn, the health secretary, last night put the NHS on an emergency footing for the first time since the ambulance drivers' dispute 11 years ago.
fields.body:
Alan Milburn, the health secretary, last night put the NHS on an emergency footing for the first time since the ambulance drivers' dispute 11 years ago.

He instructed local man agers to draw up contingency plans for running an emergencies-only service. They are expected to be ready at a moment's notice to cancel all elective surgery, concentrating available staff and resources on urgent cases.

Decisions on whether to invoke an emergency will be taken at local level. If necessary, hospitals will be expected to withdraw dining facilities for staff to conserve food stocks for patients, a department of health spokesman said.

Liam Fox, the Conservative health spokesman, accused the government of exaggerating the impact of the fuel crisis on the NHS. The National Blood Authority described reports of blood shortages as "scaremongering".

A list of examples of pressures on the NHS issued yesterday by the Department of Health included problems of blood supply in Oxford and Southampton. "Central blood stocks will last for four days," it warned.

But the authority said stocks were above average and moving through to hospitals without difficulty. "We are meeting all hospital demand...A four-day stock is healthy for us," a spokesman said.

References to scaremongering were directed at reports of blood shortages in the media and not at the minister, he added.

Mr Milburn said: "Those involved in this blockade need to know the very serious effect their actions are having on the NHS...Doctors, nurses and NHS staff - people who deliver essential services - are being prevented from doing their job for patients.

"Staff are unable to get to work. Patients are unable to get to hospital. Operations are being cancelled. Drugs, food and medical supplies are now running short. The NHS is increasingly unable to do its job properly.

"I'm afraid slowly and surely that the NHS is going to grind to a halt."

His assessment was supported by Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, representing health service managers.

"The position has deteriorated in the last 24 hours. If it continues to deteriorate in the same way for another two or three days, we will have parts of the NHS working on an emergency-only basis," he said.

Dr Fox said: "Unfortunately, it seems the last thing we can expect to get from the Department of Health is the truth. The government is all too keen to blame other people for its own incompetence and exploit this situation for its own ends."

The health department's list of NHS problems included a lack of stitches for use in operations at the Royal Hull hospital.

A spokeswoman said: "We are monitoring the situation but we have not run out of anything and we have stocks of sutures."

webTitle: Supply line:  Situation across the country

fields.headline: Supply line:  Situation across the country
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: What it takes to keep Britain moving
fields.body:
What it takes to keep Britain moving

 There are 13,500 filling stations nationwide, supplying approximately 100,000 litres of petrol to motorists every day

 According to Shell UK, a typical filling station comprises four 45,000-litre tanks containing premium unleaded, unleaded, four star and diesel fuel

 A motorway service station requires a 33,000-litre tanker delivery to each of the four tanks every day. A smaller filling station requires two deliveries a week to each tank

 On a typical day, there are 3,000 tanker deliveries in the UK. Each tanker can carry up to 36,000 litres

 According to the Retail Motor Industry Federation it would take three weeks to fill all stations

Scotland

BP Refinery
Three tankers had got through in total by the early evening. Earlier in the day three tankers were allowed to leave after demonstrators stopped them and checked their delivery papers. Normally, the refinery supplies 90% of Scotland's fuel and dispatches 300 trucks carrying 2m gallons a day.

Depots
Inverness: Four tankers left during the day. Aberdeen: Two tankers departed during the day.

North-east

Refineries
Lincolnshire: Conoco Humber refinery. Peaceful petrol blockades at the Conoco oil terminal, in Immingham. Sixteen 30,000-litre tankers left the site to essential users mainly in agriculture. These were carrying gas, oil diesel and kerosene.
Grimsby: Fina's Lindsey refinery in Killingholme. Six tankers left yesterday carrying fuel for essential users.
Middlesbrough: Wilton refinery, belonging to Phillips-Imperial petroleum. Six tankers left the site to deliver diesel for emergency use.

Depots
Sunderland: 11 tankers left. Eight tankers were escorted through angry protesters by police, who had dogs and helicopter support, while three more were allowed through for emergency services.
Jarrow: Two tankers bound for hospitals made it out of the gates which were blocked by trucks and tractors.

North-west

Refineries
Cheshire: Shell's Stanlow refinery, Ellesmere Port. Fifty tankers departed as 150 protesters maintained a protest. At 6pm a convoy of more than 50 articulated lorries and trucks drove past the blockaded terminal in a go-slow protest timed to coincide with the passing of 24 hours since Tony Blair's claim that the situation would have improved within a day.

Depots
Manchester: 20 tankers left.
Cumbria: Two tankers left.

London and the South

Refineries
Esso's Purfleet refinery, Essex: 36 tankers left under heavy police escort as protesters reacted angrily to a heavy police presence.
BP's Coryton refinery, Essex: 24 tankers, apparently bound for the emergency services, were allowed through the blockade.
Esso's Fawley refinery, near Southampton: Nine tankers left

Depots
Poole: Two tankers for commercial purposes got through under a heavy police presence after police arrested two protesters.
Brighton: One tanker
Buncefield, Hertfordshire: 12 tankers
Hamble, Southampton: Seven tankers
West London: Six tankers

Midlands

Depots
Kingsbury, Warwickshire: By the early evening more than 40 tankers had left the depot compared to between 300 and 400 movements on a normal day. Earlier, 11 tankers, marked with makeshift "emergency delivery" signs, were applauded through the gates by 50 protesters
Nottingham: Eight tankers for essential use escorted through the gates by police

Wales

Refineries
TotalFinaElf Oil's Milford Haven refinery, Dyfed: 25 tankers bound for the emergency services were allowed through, heading for Withybush hospital, a lifeboat station and various county council sites
Texaco's Pembroke refinery, Pembroke Dock: By last night two tankers carrying 25,000 litres of fuel had left the site, carrying supplies for the emergency services, one to a designated petrol station, one to an emergency council facility. Sixty lorries and their drivers are at the site

Depots
Cardiff: 14 tankers left the docks, seven bound for the emergency services and seven for industrial use

South-west

Depots
Avonmouth: 22 tankers left the docks under police guard, 5% of the normal volume of tankers. Eighteen were bound for essential services, while a further 10 turned back at the request of protesters
Plymouth: Eight tankers made it through, but police later cleared protesters away from the entrance

fields.headline: Protests bring Belgium to standstill
fields.standfirst:
Europe: Poland latest country to be hit as truckers plan go-slow

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Cargo containers were last night rapidly piling up at Antwerp, Europe's second largest port, as angry Belgian truckers stepped up their nationwide protest against fuel prices and blocked access.
fields.body:
Cargo containers were last night rapidly piling up at Antwerp, Europe's second largest port, as angry Belgian truckers stepped up their nationwide protest against fuel prices and blocked access.

Action also looked set to spill over into eastern Europe for the first time as furious Polish truckers demanded that the government slash fuel prices and vowed to stage a massive nationwide go-slow on Friday with 22,500 trucks. One of the country's biggest unions said it would organise blockades, too.

Elsewhere in Europe, German haulage firms met in Frankfurt to plot their next move despite the fact that Chancellor Gerhard Schrö der has categorically ruled out making any concessions.

On a visit to Schwerin in northern Germany, where he was giving a speech to a business group, Mr Schröder was jeered by truckers and farmers. Several hundred protesters blockaded the city centre with trucks and tractors as Mr Schroeder arrived by helicopter. He accepted a note from the protesters urging him to lower gasoline taxes, but did not talk to them.

In his speech to local business leaders, Mr Schröder defended his government's plans to introduce the hotly disputed next stage of an "ecology tax on fuels on January 1. He blamed the rise in crude oil prices for the current problem. "I don't belong to Opec," he said.

He warned protesters to respect the borderline between "free expression of opinion and coercion" but stopped short of threatening action by the authorities should protests grow.

Dutch lorry drivers continued to block many roads along the Belgian border causing huge tailbacks and promised to demonstrate in the Hague on Friday.

But the worst disruption was in Belgium where the country's two largest truckers' unions threatened to bring about chaos and gridlock by the end of the week unless fuel taxes are lowered.

Much of Belgium was in any case at a standstill yesterday as truckers moved to sever border crossings with France, Germany, Luxembourg and the Netherlands and showed no signs of backing down.

The country's biggest oil depot has been cut off since Sunday and TotalFinaElf, the country's leading petrol supplier, said the action had halted 80 % of its normal deliveries.

Talks with the government limped on without result yesterday and the seriousness of the situation prompted the European Commission to ask the authorities whether they were still able to guarantee the free movement of goods in a move which can lead to legal action.

The centre of Brussels and the entire EU quarter remained a traffic-free zone as large articulated lorries straddled key arteries allowing only pedestrians, cyclists and moped riders to circulate.

fields.headline: Drivers 'told not to go out'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The big oil companies made no attempt to get their tankers moving out of the depots for the first four days of the fuel crisis, it emerged last night.
fields.byline: Peter Hetherington, David Ward  and  Seumas Milne
fields.body:
The big oil companies made no attempt to get their tankers moving out of the depots for the first four days of the fuel crisis, it emerged last night.

Drivers who contacted the Guardian despite being told not to talk to the press said both BP and Shell drivers had been explicitly ordered not to go out through the demonstrators even when police had control of the streets.

The attitude only changed after Tony Blair's live television appearance on Tuesday evening when he said he had been given assurances by the oil companies that the tankers would begin to roll over the next 24 hours.

Even then the companies left the decision on whether to get supplies running again up to the individual drivers.

One employee, who drives P&O Trans European tankers on a Shell contract out of the Coryton refinery in Essex, told the Guardian: "Both BP and Shell instructed drivers not to go out [on Monday]. But after Tony Blair spoke out on Tuesday, the company managers came down and tried to persuade the drivers to go out if it was safe to do so."

Another driver, who yesterday delivered an Esso tanker full of unleaded petrol from a terminal on the Trafford Park industrial estate to a filling station in south Manchester, said drivers had not been instructed to work but had been given the option. "We didn't have to come out and I would not have lost my job if I had refused," he said. "There was no question of that.

"The protesters have not bothered us. We have had no problems with them. We get paid just the same whether sitting in the yard or not - I wouldn't have lost my job if I refused. I'm quite in agreement with the principle of the protest. I'm like the next man - I want petrol to be cheap. It's been a weird week. I've been sitting around on my arse most days playing cards."

A senior transport official in the north accused the oil companies of prolonging the crisis. Mike Brider of the TGWU said the companies were being hypocritical.

"Had union pickets been outside depots this week, the companies would have acted far, far quicker and they would have made sure the police allowed free access and entry to their sites," he said. "But on this occasion they have chosen not to do anything like this."

An Esso spokeswoman said the company would not order any driver to take a vehicle out through lines of protesters, nor would it threaten to sack drivers who chose to stay away from their cabs. "Our concern is first and foremost for the safety of everyone involved in the situation," she said.

webTitle: Britain grinds to a halt as Blair's pleas are ignored

fields.headline: Britain grinds to a halt as Blair's pleas are ignored
fields.standfirst:
NHS put on emergency footing
Army ambulances deployed
Post, banks, buses, food threatened : Britain grinds to a halt as Blair's pleas are ignored

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: An increasingly desperate Tony Blair yesterday warned that lives will be lost if the fuel blockades are not quickly lifted and blamed picket line intimidation for the complete failure to meet his ambitious promise of Tuesday evening that supplies would start to return to normal within 24 hours.
fields.body:
An increasingly desperate Tony Blair yesterday warned that lives will be lost if the fuel blockades are not quickly lifted and blamed picket line intimidation for the complete failure to meet his ambitious promise of Tuesday evening that supplies would start to return to normal within 24 hours.

With Britain close to shutdown, Mr Blair sought to turn public opinion against the protest by putting the NHS on emergency footing for the first time in 11 years. Claiming jobs, mail and food supplies were also under imminent threat, he said it was an affront that picket lines were trying to determine what represented an essential service.

He was also forced to admit that only 500 deliveries went through the lines yesterday, probably 5% of the normal supply.

Mr Blair refused to rule out the use of troops or the recall of parliament, and last night about 80 military tankers were being deployed around the country should they be needed. In another sign of the deepening crisis, Whitehall will today designate categories of workers who are entitled to receive petrol. It has already earmarked 2,000 petrol stations for essential supplies. The cabinet will meet to discuss the crisis.

At a Downing Street press conference, Mr Blair said: "No government, indeed no country can retain credibility in its democratic process or its economic policy-making were it to give in to such protests. Real damage is being done to real people."

Trying to avoid accusations of arrogance, he added: "We will listen, but we will not be intimidated."

As doctors and health officials went down to the picket lines to appeal for the blockades to be lifted, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, used the NHS as a battering ram to try to turn public opinion against the blockades, saying the NHS was hour by hour closer to being forced to stop all but emergency operations.

The blood transfusion service initially denied a crisis in supplies, accusing Mr Milburn of scaremongering for political purposes, but later admitted it was experiencing difficulties. Mr Milburn pleaded with the pickets to go home. "The problem is going to get worse by the hour," he said. "The people who are meting out the violence have got to stop it." He also claimed that the oil company executives - who met Mr Blair and the cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson in Downing Street yesterday - "have got to up their game".

In the battle for public opinion, Downing Street has decisively shifted the focus of its attack from hints of collusion between pickets, oil companies and their drivers to intimidation by pickets. "Once the public gets to know what is happening on the picket lines, public opinion will start to change," said one aide.

The oil chiefs - who have been reluctant to answer media inquiries - also blamed intimidation for their inability to persuade their drivers to step up the deliveries.

Ministers also said protesters had threatened to post pictures on the internet of drivers who break the picket lines.

However, in private the government is deeply frustrated at the inability of the oil companies to deliver on their promises. Mr Blair himself pointedly said one oil company had managed yesterday to get a third of its normal supplies through, adding: "As today's developments show, where the determination exists, the supplies do get through."

The Conservative leader William Hague, sensing the possible collapse of the government's credibility, demanded the immediate recall of parliament. He said the revolt represented "an earthquake in the political argument about tax". Labour had miscalculated and would be on the wrong side of the argument over tax and spending in the election, he said.

Tory officials claimed that 90 minutes before Blair had said 500 tankers were making deliveries, Sky News put the figure at 171. Each carries 30,000 litres, amounting to 5m litres delivered - 3.8% compared with an average day's sale of 131m throughout Britain.

With signs of panic buying in the supermarkets and at least one - Safeway - introducing the rationing of bread and milk, agriculture secretary Nick Brown met food industry chiefs to discuss how to maintain supplies.

The CBI director-general Digby Jones said: "We need this sorted out fast. Some companies have today started reducing the size and scope of their operations." The London Chamber of Commerce warned the crisis is costing British business £250m a day.

The Royal Mail said it only had supplies for one more day of deliveries in some areas, while in some parts of the country schools have closed.

The petrol industry said it could be up to three weeks before supplies were back to normal as fuel tankers, many accompanied by heavy police escorts, trickled through protest lines.

By last night deliveries from refineries and depots remained sporadic as the blockades continued. Protesters were still persuading many tanker drivers not to cross their picket lines, while in other areas police officers moved in in force to break up the demonstrations.

Britain's main oil companies claimed fuel was beginning to get through, but BP said it was a "drop in the ocean" compared to normal. "We have only managed to get 22 tanker loads of fuel out of picketed refineries and terminals since last night with another 45 loads making their way from terminals not affected by the blockades," a spokesman said.

Demonstrators at the Grangemouth refinery in central Scotland voted to continue their protest despite a plea from the Road Haulage Association to end the picket. Normally the depot, which supplies 90% of Scotland's fuel, dispatches 300 truckloads carrying 2m gallons a day, but by last night only 13 tankers had been allowed through the picket line, all bound for emergency use.
