webTitle: BBC1 chief appointed director of sport

fields.headline: BBC1 chief appointed director of sport
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC ended weeks of speculation by naming the BBC1 controller, Peter Salmon, as its director of sport yesterday, paving the way for the first woman to take charge of its main channel.
fields.body:
The BBC ended weeks of speculation by naming the BBC1 controller, Peter Salmon, as its director of sport yesterday, paving the way for the first woman to take charge of its main channel.

Mr Salmon, 44, who has endured much criticism in his three-year tenure, will take up the new post in November. Lorraine Heggessey, the joint head of the BBC's factual and learning section, is expected to be named as his successor by the end of the week.

Greg Dyke, the director general, said Mr Salmon was the "obvious candidate" for the job at BBC Sport, although it is widely thought that a number of Mr Dyke's favoured candidates turned him down before he approached the BBC1 chief. Mr Dyke has been attempting to fill the new post since April.

The BBC was at pains to stress that Mr Salmon's new job was a promotion, pointing out that he will sit on the powerful executive committee.

Mr Dyke said: "Peter has done a good job in difficult circumstances at BBC1. This autumn's schedule, like last autumn's, is full of originality and quality and is testament to his commissioning skills. He will be a strong addition to our executive team."

Mr Salmon faces a tough job at BBC Sport, at a time when the corporation has lost many of its sporting rights to rival channels. Mr Dyke is determined to reinvigorate the department. Mr Salmon, a supporter of Burnley football club, is said to be "passionate" about sport.

In an interview with the Guardian's media website, Mr Salmon said he had "no regrets" about his time at BBC1, during which the channel was criticised by the BBC's board of governors for lacking ambition. Acknowledging it was a tough job, he said: "You have to take the brickbats as well as the bouquets. I've loved it and I'm going to take up my next job with the same relish. You can't do the big jobs without sticking your neck out, without gambling."

He identified the success of Walking With Dinosaurs, the dramas Clocking Off and Warriors, and the comedy series Dinnerladies as his high points. He admitted to being stung by the strength of ITV's gameshow, Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

Friends of Mr Salmon say he performed well at a time when BBC1 was starved of investment. He is well liked within the BBC, and is credited with preventing even worse decline at a time of intense competition. But the BBC1 ratings have slumped to several record lows during his time at the helm, and his critics say he was not imaginative or decisive enough. One said he was always looking over his shoulder, "commissioning by fear". He was vilified by some sections of the media for refusing to broadcast the Queen Mother's birthday pageant this year.

Executives are thrashing out final contractual details before announcing the appointment of Ms Heggessey. She has a strong populist touch - she was responsible for signing Rolf Harris to present Animal Hospital, against the wishes of some in the BBC - but has no background in drama. Mr Dyke has identified drama as the key battleground, and promised £100m extra for BBC1 next year.

Ms Heggessey will face a tough job clawing back BBC1's position. A number of key drama series have performed poorly recently. Drama output will have to improve drastically if Mr Dyke's plan to move the 9pm news to 10pm is to be a success. ITV suffered because it had not stockpiled enough strong shows for the slot vacated by News at Ten.

Interview with Peter Salmon at www.mediatheguardian.com

webTitle: New rules after 'name and shame' campaign

fields.headline: New rules after 'name and shame' campaign
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The press complaints commission is to draw up new guidelines on the identification of criminals in the community following the controversial "name and shame" campaign by the News of the World.
fields.body:
The press complaints commission is to draw up new guidelines on the identification of criminals in the community following the controversial "name and shame" campaign by the News of the World.

An extensive consultation exercise is to be launched, at the request of the probation officers' professional body. Newspapers, politicians, the home office and members of the public will be asked for their views.

The NoW campaign gained popular support, but was criticised by police and the home secretary after a number of vigilante attacks. Many professional bodies feared the potential for mob rule, and attacks on innocent people.

Following discussions, the newspaper ended its practice of publishing names, pictures and locations of known paedophiles. Police and probation officers decided not to make an official complaint to the PCC.

The NoW's campaign was not new - a number of local newspaper have run similar campaigns. Guy Black, director of the PCC, said it had raised a number of issues.

It is expected that the guidelines will clarify what rights to privacy a convicted paedophile can enjoy after being released into the community. They will also clarify what constitutes harassment. Mr Black said the consultation exercise would take some time

webTitle: £90m guarantee as dome chief's troubles mount

fields.headline: £90m guarantee as dome chief's troubles mount
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The millennium commission yesterday agreed to underwrite the dome with £90m of lottery money after the collapse of the Nomura deal put its future on a knife-edge.
fields.body:
The millennium commission yesterday agreed to underwrite the dome with £90m of lottery money after the collapse of the Nomura deal put its future on a knife-edge.

The Japanese-backed consortium pulled out of the £105m sale two days ago claiming the black hole in the dome's register of assets meant they could not be sure of the liabilities they would inherit when the attraction closed at the end of the year.

As talks started with the failed bidder, Legacy plc, which has already cut by a quarter the price it is willing to pay to turn the site into a technology and science park, property experts warned the government had few options left.

Keith Miller, chief executive of the Miller Group, the biggest privately owned property developer in the country, said the government had no real room for manoeuvre.

"The dome site has great potential, but that potential could take 20 years or more to realise. Canary Wharf, which was written off time after time, is a good example of what can happen in the fullness of time. However, there is a very limited number of institutions who can put down £100m and wait for that long for a return."

Nan Rogers, of City analysts Charterhouse, said she could well understand why Nomura took fright and said it could take a decade to make any money from the attraction. "Having its own Tube is fine but its road links are still not what they could be. It all depends on the density of development. The business park option would not maximise that."

Just when it seemed things could not get any worse for Lord Falconer, minister for the dome, Ken Livingstone's London assembly demanded he come before them to explain what is going on in Greenwich.

Trevor Phillips, the assembly's chairman, said he was confident Lord Falconer - who has resisted calls for his resignation - would appear. "Londoners want straight answers to straight questions about the management, the finances and the future of the dome. We want to be sure that the community and economy of the area surrounding the dome do not suffer in the confusion of rapidly emerging and rapidly changing information."

Lord Falconer is said to be considering whether to submit himself to the questioning.

The commission's last two bail-outs - £47m last week following £43m in July - were dependent on the Nomura deal going through, but yesterday it waived those conditions, admitting it was "unpalatable" to pay up but cheaper than closing the dome early.

Sources within the dome reaffirmed their belief that Nomura's last minute withdrawal was a bargaining ploy.

Peter Middleton, managing director of Nomura's bid, said it was not beyond the bounds of possibility that negotiations could be reopened.

webTitle: No warning over bomb attack on RUC station

fields.headline: No warning over bomb attack on RUC station
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissident republicans attacked an RUC station in Armagh yesterday as the inquest into the Omagh massacre was hearing details of the gruesome injuries caused by the bombing two years ago.
fields.body:
Dissident republicans attacked an RUC station in Armagh yesterday as the inquest into the Omagh massacre was hearing details of the gruesome injuries caused by the bombing two years ago.

No one was hurt in the rush-hour attack, which happened without warning, but up to 70 people were in the police station as the mortar bomb was fired into it. Scores of schoolchildren were in the area at the time of the bombing.

A pregnant woman was among those who narrowly escaped flying shrapnel.

Within hours of the attack Omagh suffered another hoax bomb alert, as it has done every week since the bombing of August 1998. The callers gave the same codeword used in the atrocity that claimed 29 lives.

The Armagh bombing is believed to have been the second dissident republican mission in 24 hours. A soldier escaped injury when an 80lb bomb partially exploded at a military training camp at Magilligan, Co Londonderry. Another device of a similar size was discovered nearby.

Bystanders said the mortar yesterday at Armagh was fired from a white van driven into the site of a £10m hotel complex beside the RUC station. After parking the vehicle, two men were seen moving away in a blue Ford Mondeo.

Derek Williamson, chief inspector, said: "It was an attack launched without warning in an absolutely indiscriminate fashion and at a time when the place was busy with schoolchildren and people going to work. That showed utter contempt for the lives of everyone in the area. It was an attack of murderous intent. It was all the more despicable because of the ongoing inquest into the Omagh bombing."

The attacks came as the loyalist feud on the Shankill Road in Belfast sparked renewed worries. Several homes were destroyed as the Ulster Defence Association and Ulster Volunteer Force stayed at loggerheads. Billy Hutchinson, of the Progressive Unionist Party, which is close to the UVF, caught the brunt of the UDA's campaign. A pipe-bomb exploded outside his home late on Tuesday.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, said: "We are going to bring this sort of activity to a halt, no matter how long it takes. We are not going to tolerate any action to disrupt and destablise the peace process."

The attack came as graphic and horrifying evidence of the Omagh bomb in 1998 was being presented to the inquest.

Rosemary Ingram, a traffic warden, faltered and then wept as she recounted being handed the dying 20-month-old Breda Devine, "black with debris" and with an open wound, to take to hospital. "The baby wasn't moving. It was stiff, but I [found]a strong heartbeat."

Going to the Tyrone county hospital in the town she fell while holding the baby. Her statement read: "My legs gave way beneath me. I fell on to my back still holding the wee baby. I shouted for some one to please take the wee baby, which somebody did."

Samuel James Owen Potter, an army doctor, told the coroner, John Leckey, that at the explosion on Market Street he "pronounced life extinct on 20 bodies, and one body part between 3.30pm and 4.10pm".

Captain Potter found Avril Monaghan, who was pregnant, dead. He turned her over to find her 18-month-old, Maura, also dead underneath her. Mrs Monaghan's mother, Mary Grimes, lay dead in shop doorway. The first two bodies he saw were two males "lying almost crossed over in a crucifix".

Some evidence at the inquest has upset family members. Stanley McCombe, who lost his wife Ann, said he thought they could have been spared the gory details.

fields.headline: Database links child abuse cases
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Seventy-five investigations into serial abuse of children at care homes, with allegations in many dating back to the 1960s and 1970s, are being pursued in England and Wales, police revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Seventy-five investigations into serial abuse of children at care homes, with allegations in many dating back to the 1960s and 1970s, are being pursued in England and Wales, police revealed yesterday.

A confidential list of suspected offenders has linked 36 people to abuse in more than one area of the country, suggesting paedophile rings operated undetected for decades.

More than 370 men and women are being investigated for a range of serious sexual abuses, and officers have compiled 1,700 names of suspected paedophiles for future inquiries.

The details were released yesterday by Chief Superintendent Ian Johnston of Gwent police, which has been instrumental in setting up the national historical abuse database. This was launched last October to help forces coordinate paedophile investigations and follow Gwent's exhaustive inquiry into the abuse of children at the Ty Mawr children's home near Abergavenny in west Wales.

By chance, officers found out that some of the people they were investigating were also being investigated by other forces, but there was no central list to which detectives could refer. Twenty-nine forces have so far contributed details of potential offenders to the new database in an effort to pool information.

Speaking at the Police Superintendents' Association's annual conference, Mr Johnston said most of the alleged offenders were teachers and some were still working in schools and care homes.

He said it was essential for forces to work together because of the difficulties of investigating allegations that went back many years. webTitle: Islay pioneers harnessing of wave power

fields.headline: Islay pioneers harnessing of wave power
fields.standfirst: Renewable energy: special report
fields.trailText: A few hundred tonnes of battered concrete nestling in the rocky bay of a remote Scottish island does not immediately appear to be the forefront of renewable energy technology.
fields.body:
A few hundred tonnes of battered concrete nestling in the rocky bay of a remote Scottish island does not immediately appear to be the forefront of renewable energy technology.

But engineers on Islay in the Inner Hebrides were yesterday putting the finishing touches to the world's first commercial scale wave power generator.

As the Atlantic ocean battered the concrete walls of the Limpet 500, a team from Wavegen, an Inverness-based renewable energy specialist, ignored the terrible weather get the freshest hope of the renewable power dream ready on time.

Since the 1970s, the drive to harness the power inherent in the world's waves has been subject to many false starts. Yet with the determination of small companies - and a little European and government help - within the next two months a bleak island outpost will finally utilise the power of the Atlantic ocean on a commercial scale.

"The Islay development is incredibly important because it shows that wave power can be viable. It is the start of proving that, with a bit of effort and a lot more government support, wave power can be an alternative to fossil fuels," said Rob Gueterbock, climate and energy campaigner for Greenpeace.

The potential of wave power is obvious: studies from the European Commission suggest Britain could generate all the electricity it needed if only 0.1 % of the energy around its coast was collected.

As an island state subject to pretty rough winter weather, Britain is, for once, at an advantage.

But with the technology still in its infancy, there are enormous hurdles to be overcome before Britain can start to make use of even a tiny percentage of the wave power around its shores.

After a lot of research, carried out in conjunction with Queens University in Belfast, the shore-bound Limpet 500 takes the first step towards overcoming the first of these problems: how to create a commercially viable generator.

"This is only the start of the journey and the technology and design will, of course, be refined once the Limpet is up and running," said Allan Thompson, managing director of Wavegen. "But this is the first commercial plant in the world - we will be connected to the grid and we have a 15 year contract with Scottish and Southern Energy."

When waves crash in from the ocean at a rocky gully near Portnahaven, on Islay, they are now met by the partially submerged concrete structure of the Limpet 500. As the water breaks against the Limpet, some of it rushes into a column behind the concrete shell.

The water entering the column compresses the air above it, driving it through turbine propellers which power electrical generators. But as waves crash against the shore, they also recede.

As the water flows out of the column sucks air back across the turbine propellers, so the Limpet 500 uses a special Well's turbine which self corrects for changes in the direction of air flow.

In comparison to fossil fuels - and some wind power plants - the 500kw of electricity produced by the new wave generator is expensive. Fossil fuel costs around 2p per unit, but the electricity generated on Islay is being sold for 5.9p. The difference in price is marked, but prices will fall as the technology is refined.

Electricity companies are about to have their minds sharply focused on renewable energy. The utilities bill currently on its way through Westminster stipulates that utilities must provide 10% of their electricity from renewable sources by 2010.

For companies which serve urban areas, this may be difficult.

These companies will be allowed to buy "green credits" from those based in rural areas who have greater scope for utilising renewables. Wavegen believes this may eventually help power a market for small rural communities running their own wave generators and exporting electricity.

There are, however, a great many problems - from the seasonal nature of wave power, to the need to update Scotland's national grid connection to its remote communities - before wave power can be advanced.

In the meantime, researchers are beginning to look at the next generation of wave generators: built off shore, far away from land.

fields.headline: Hockney lays into 'philistine' ministers
fields.trailText: David Hockney yesterday launched a savage attack on the country's cultural health, accusing the government of being "a load of philistines - a lot more philistine than the last lot".
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
David Hockney yesterday launched a savage attack on the country's cultural health, accusing the government of being "a load of philistines - a lot more philistine than the last lot".

The artist's remarks, in an interview in next month's Tatler magazine, swell a chorus of disapproval over a dumbed-down Britain, launched by Sir Vidia Naipaul and Doris Lessing, and taken up by BBC bosses turned arts administrators John Tusa and Sir John Drummond, who called Tony Blair "a professional philistine".

They in turn have been rubbished by Lord Bragg as "the foolish senior citizens of culture."

Hockney, who has been living in California for most of the past 30 years, risks being labelled a member of the senior cultural follies. But he shows no sign of mellowing, putting the boot in over cannabis, fox hunting and the Millennium Dome.

"The present government are a load of philistines," he told the magazine. "And that's not surprising. What is surprising is that they are a lot more philistine than the last lot. At least Edward Heath conducted choirs."

He rejects arguments that high art is elitist as irrelevant, saying it is a matter of choice whether to spend money travelling to a football match or going to Glyndebourne.

"I do believe in high culture - art for which you have to put yourself out a bit, make a bit of an effort," he said. "I have always known most politicians are philistines, simply because they are deeply interested in politics. Most people are not. They are interested in their lives."

Hockney expressed dismay at Mr Blair's refusal to consider legalising cannabis, for which the artist has campaigned since the 1960s. He said hearing the government proposing to criminalise fox hunting instead had turned him into a hunt supporter.

"I thought Blair and his government were meant to be the servants of the realm. I can see now that their kind of populism means they think they are doing what people want. They are not really working out anything. The dome must have come from that lack of anything serious or substantial."

Last night the arts minister Alan Howarth said: "There is a certain amount of ritual about this criticism, and I think if he is being interviewed in an arena like Tatler, Hockney is to be allowed a considerable degree of licence in going through with the ritual."

webTitle: New clue to why Scott's men died

fields.headline: New clue to why Scott's men died
fields.standfirst: Leaders page
fields.trailText: Captain Scott and four members of his Antarctic team might have died of starvation and thirst because the leather washers on their fuel canisters perished and allowed precious fuel to evaporate.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Captain Scott and four members of his Antarctic team might have died of starvation and thirst because the leather washers on their fuel canisters perished and allowed precious fuel to evaporate.

The fuel ran out and the exhausted, frostbitten men, on the march back from discovering that the Norwegian, Roald Amundsen, had got to the pole first, could no longer melt water or cook their remaining food.

Historians at the National Maritime Museum at Greenwich believe the scraps of leather, on view for the first time in an exhibition opening today, explain the deaths in 1912.

Scott used screw caps with leather washers. He recorded in his journal his dismay that when he collected fuel from supply dumps the cans were already half empty.

Amundsen, who had extensive Arctic training, sealed his cans with cork bungs, topped with metal caps which were soldered and cut open as needed.

Scott's journal, owned by the British Library, is in the exhibition South, which brings together hundreds of items from the Antarctic expeditions mounted between 1900 and 1916. The National Maritime Museum acquired the leather washers at an auction last year. The exhibition curator, Sian Flynn, said it was only as staff studied these that they began to wonder about their significance.

Scott's journals reveal his puzzlement about the fuel cans, but yesterday a new clue emerged which may mean he finally guessed the truth. His grandson, Richard Falcon, revealed that he had inherited the canvas journal wallet in which the explorer had carefully placed one of the leather washers.

webTitle: Evidence found of Noah's ark flood victims

fields.headline: Evidence found of Noah's ark flood victims
fields.standfirst: Ship probes land below Black Sea submerged 7,000 years ago and linked to biblical disaster
fields.trailText: Marine archaeologists have found the first evidence of a people who perished in a great flood of the Black Sea that has been linked with the story of Noah's ark.
fields.body:
Marine archaeologists have found the first evidence of a people who perished in a great flood of the Black Sea that has been linked with the story of Noah's ark.

Using robot underwater vehicles more than 300ft below the sea's surface, they have begun to map a rolling landscape, fed by meandering streams and marked with wattle and daub houses, that was flooded more than 7,000 years ago.

The discovery was announced yesterday by Robert Ballard, the scientist who discovered the wrecked Titanic.

The Black Sea was once a freshwater lake, well below sea level. About 7,000 years ago, according to geological evidence, the rising Mediterranean sea pushed a channel through what is now the Bosphorus, and then seawater poured in at about 200 times the volume of Niagara Falls. The Black Sea would have widened at the rate of a mile a day, submerging the original shoreline under hundreds of feet of salty water.

Nearly 100,000 square miles were inundated. Sea shells on the beaches of the modern Black Sea are of marine origin, but deep below the surface there are layers of shells of freshwater molluscs, mute witnesses to the shoreline of the ancient lake.

There are many myths concerning a great flood in the region. There was a first mention in the Epic of Gilgamesh, the Babylonian work. The Romans and Greeks had the legend of Deucalion and Pyrrha, who saved their children and animals by floating away in a giant box. The Hebrew book of Genesis most famously tells the story of Noah, who found grace in the eyes of the Lord, when all around him were wicked. Noah was warned of a forthcoming flood, and built a huge "ark" to hold his family and all the animals in pairs. Noah survived when all perished. Tradition has it that his ark came to rest on the slopes of Mount Ararat in Turkey.

Dr Ballard began exploring the Black Sea in the Hull registered ship Northern Horizon, and used side-scanning sonar to look for interesting shapes on the seabed over a 200-sq-mile area, 12 miles off the Turkish coast, near Sinop.

The instruments detected "targets" worth a closer look, so video cameras mounted on underwater robot submarines were put to use. "We found two ancient ships last night," said Dr Ballard speaking by phone from his research vessel yesterday. "What we were trying to do in our wildest dreams - which is exactly what happened - was find a structure that was evidence, not a sunken ship, not trash and not geology, but characteristic of human habitation."

They found it. Above an area submerged too deeply for human divers, the sonar instruments revealed details of the landscape. On September 9 they sent robot scouts down to objects which looked like beams and branches, debris that might have been the stiffening for wattle and daub homes.

They found a rectangular area up to 12ft by 25 ft, over which an ancient mud and wooden house had collapsed, and they found tools of highly polished stone, together with fragments of ceramics.

"What we are looking at is a culture that is definitely thousands of years old," said Fred Hiebert, an archaeologist at the University of Pennsylvania, who was also on the ship. "The flood is an event that is geologically known, and for us to find a structure in 150 metres of water means that these people were definitely living there before it flooded, so it is pre-Greek. It is a different world and it deserves a great deal of attention and years of study to help us truly identify who these people were."

Dr Ballard is perhaps oceanography's answer to Indiana Jones. As a marine scientist in the US, two decades ago, he took part in the dramatic discovery of communities of strange creatures living in submarine volcanic vents two miles below the ocean surface. He also found the submerged liner Titanic, and tracked the wreck of the German battleship, Bismarck, and the fleet which the US navy lost off Guadalcanal in the Pacific.

He formed his own exploration institute in Mystic, Connecticut, before going on to lead National Geographic expeditions to probe the mud of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea for lost treasures - and now a lost world.

But he does not claim to have found the landscape of Noah. " We really cannot say in any way, shape or form that this is the biblical flood. All we can say is that there has been a major flood, that people were living here when it happened. We prefer to stick with the facts -and who knows where those facts will lead us."

webTitle: New dilemma arises over conjoined twins

fields.headline: New dilemma arises over conjoined twins
fields.standfirst: Weaker baby grows as court agonises over separation
fields.trailText: The case of the conjoined twins Mary and Jodie took a disturbing twist yesterday when it emerged that the baby doomed to die seemed to be growing at the expense of her healthier sister.
fields.body:
The case of the conjoined twins Mary and Jodie took a disturbing twist yesterday when it emerged that the baby doomed to die seemed to be growing at the expense of her healthier sister.

Surgeons treating the five-week-old girls believe that Mary, who is severely disabled and relies on her sister for oxygenated blood, could be drawing nutrition from her twin.

The worrying turn of events came on the fourth day of the appeal from the girls' parents against a high court ruling that they should be separated, even though this would lead to Mary's death.

Adrian Whitfield QC, who has been arguing the doctors' case that the girls should be separated to save Jodie, said Mary was "growing normally" despite her having only a "primitive" brain. But Jodie, a "bright alert baby", was not growing.

Mr Whitfield said that the twist could have implications for the timing of the operation if it were sanctioned by the courts, although there was no immediate rush. Doctors have said the ideal time to operate would be after the twins were two months old.

Nicola Davies QC, for the attorney general, who is not a party to the action but is assisting the court, said: "The parents are facing a dilemma, the like of which few parents have ever faced. They are not having to deal with the difference between right and wrong but the difference between right and right. It is right to operate on Jodie. It is right not to operate on Mary."

She said that no doctor doing the operation, nor anyone assisting them, would be criminally culpable of murder.

The Catholic church, meanwhile, stepped into the thick of the case as Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, the archbishop of Westminster, received the go-ahead to make written representations to the appeal court. He is expected to argue that the girls should die rather than be separated.

The archbishop has already made clear his backing for the girls' parents, whose Catholic faith has led them to conclude that it is not God's will that the twins should be separated, though both will die if no operation takes place.

The archbishop believes that a "very dangerous precedent" would be set if the judges ruled it could be lawful to kill a person "so that good may come of it", and he is convinced that the wishes of the parents, who are from a remote European community, should be respected.

Yesterday the spotlight was put on the criminal law aspects of the case. The judges need to decide whether or not separation of the twins could be regarded as murder or manslaughter, since the doctors know that the operation will lead to Mary's death. They also need to establish whether not carrying out the procedure could be seen as criminal, because it would inevitably bring about Jodie's death.

Mr Whitfield argued that few people would say that the doctors involved in the case had a "murderous intent", even if they did take the view that the proposed separation was morally wrong or against the law.

He said it was possible to argue that Mary was dying of her own condition and that the withdrawal of external life support through separation from Jodie would not be the substantial cause of death. "It would follow that there was no criminal intent in the present case," he said.

As there was a conflict, the doctors had two choices, Mr Whitfield said. "They can do nothing, which is a derogation of their duty to Jodie, or they must operate." He also characterised the doctors as Jodie's "defenders".

Representing Jodie, Tim Owen QC argued that the judges had to consider the implications for the case of the European convention on human rights, which comes into force in Britain at the start of next month.

Counsel for the parents had quoted article two of the convention, which states: "Everyone's right to life shall be protected by law. No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally ..." Counsel said that that statement meant the operation could not take place.

Mr Owen said such an interpretation had profound implications for doctors. If the article were to be taken as an absolute, then doctors might not be able to carry out an abortion to save a mother's life. In the twins' case, it would mean that Jodie could not be saved as this would result in Mary's death.

Counsel also made the observation that if the court said the operation could go ahead, those representing Mary would take the case to the Strasbourg court. And if the court ruled against an operation, then Jodie's side would take her case to the court.

The twins, given the English names to protect their identity, were born joined at their lower abdomens at St Mary's hospital, Manchester, on August 8. Doctors believe that if no operation takes place both are likely to die within six months.

The judges' difficult task was starkly illustrated yesterday when they said they had contacted their counterparts in Australia, South Africa, and Canada to see if there were any similar cases to give guidance - but found none. It is thought the judges' willingness to hear representations from the archbishop of Westminster, and from a pro-life group, which will be allowed submissions, gives an insight into their uncertainty about the many ethical issues.

Nicola Davies QC, for the attorney general, who is not a party to the action but is assisting the court, said: "The parents are facing a dilemma, the like of which few parents have ever faced. They are not having to deal with the difference between right and wrong but the difference between right and right. It is right to operate on Jodie. It is right not to operate on Mary." She said that no doctor doing the operation, nor anyone assisting them, would be criminally culpable of murder. The Catholic church, meanwhile, stepped into the thick of the case as Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, the archbishop of Westminster, received the go-ahead to make written representations to the appeal court. He is expected to argue that the girls should die rather than be separated. The archbishop has already made clear his backing for the girls' parents, whose Catholic faith has led them to conclude that it is not God's will that the twins should be separated, though both will die if no operation takes place. The archbishop believes that a "very dangerous precedent" would be set if the judges ruled it could be lawful to kill a person "so that good may come of it", and he is convinced that the wishes of the parents, who are from a remote European community, should be respected. Yesterday the spotlight was put on the criminal law aspects of the case. The judges need to decide whether or not separation of the twins could be regarded as murder or manslaughter, since the doctors know that the operation will lead to Mary's death. They also need to establish whether not carrying out the procedure could be seen as criminal, because it would inevitably bring about Jodie's death. Mr Whitfield argued that few people would say that the doctors involved in the case had a "murderous intent", even if they did take the view that the proposed separation was morally wrong or against the law. He said it was possible to argue that Mary was dying of her own condition and that the withdrawal of external life support through separation from Jodie would not be the substantial cause of death. "It would follow that there was no criminal intent in the present case," he said. As there was a conflict, the doctors had two choices, Mr Whitfield said. "They can do nothing, which is a derogation of their duty to Jodie, or they must operate." He also characterised the doctors as Jodie's "defenders". Representing Jodie, Tim Owen QC argued that the judges had to consider the implications for the case of the European convention on human rights, which comes into force in Britain at the start of next month. Counsel for the parents had quoted article two of the convention, which states: "Everyone's right to life shall be protected by law. No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally ..." Counsel said that that statement meant the operation could not take place. Mr Owen said such an interpretation had profound implications for doctors. If the article were to be taken as an absolute, then doctors might not be able to carry out an abortion to save a mother's life. In the twins' case, it would mean that Jodie could not be saved as this would result in Mary's death. Counsel also made the observation that if the court said the operation could go ahead, those representing Mary would take the case to the Strasbourg court. And if the court ruled against an operation, then Jodie's side would take her case to the court. The twins, given the English names to protect their identity, were born joined at their lower abdomens at St Mary's hospital, Manchester, on August 8. Doctors believe that if no operation takes place both are likely to die within six months. The judges' difficult task was starkly illustrated yesterday when they said they had contacted their counterparts in Australia, South Africa, and Canada to see if there were any similar cases to give guidance - but found none. It is thought the judges' willingness to hear representations from the archbishop of Westminster, and from a pro-life group, which will be allowed submissions, gives an insight into their uncertainty about the many ethical issues.

fields.headline: Sports stars score again
fields.standfirst:
Fivefold rise for stock on first day of dealing
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Two of the entrepreneurs who transformed Sports Internet from a tiny cash shell into a £300m business in just over one year yesterday saw the shares in their latest venture soar to a fivefold premium on the first day of dealing.
fields.body:
Two of the entrepreneurs who transformed Sports Internet from a tiny cash shell into a £300m business in just over one year yesterday saw the shares in their latest venture soar to a fivefold premium on the first day of dealing.

Sports Resource, the new vehicle for Chris Akers and Rodger Sargent, placed its shares at 25p, saw them open at 90p and close at 152.5p.

Mr Akers and non-executive director Nigel Robertson, the Monaco-based founder of Scoot.com, each paid £875,000 for their 23.3% stakes in the company. By the end of the day each of the shareholdings was worth £5.34m. Mr Sargent, aged 28, owns 6%.

The trio plans to use Sports Resource's AIM listing as a way of bringing companies owned by leading sports agents and consultancies on to the stock market. They are targeting companies operating in football, Formula 1 and golf - the games in which wages, television revenues and sponsorship deals are largest.

IMG, the sports marketing group founded by Mark McCormack, is the sector's dominant player.

At the moment Sports Resource is a shell company containing £2.5m of cash. By the end of trading it was valued at almost £17m. Dealers said the disparity had been driven by demand from investors who were prepared to back the individuals to repeat their success with Sports Internet.

"This is a management team with a good track record attacking a growth market," one said.

Sports Internet was sold to BSkyB for £301m, or 850p per share in May, having been placed at 25p a year previously. Mr Akers and Mr Sargent are also the founders of InTechnology, the data storage firm in which Peter Wilkinson, the architect of Freeserve, is the largest shareholder.

It is one of the strongest performing shares of the year, rising from 23.5p to around 350p.

Mr Robertson is a former chief executive of Scoot.com, formerly Freepages Group.

webTitle: Rich and poor on Olympics' not so level playing field

fields.headline: Rich and poor on Olympics' not so level playing field
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: At just over five feet and weighing a little over seven stone, Paula Barila Bolopa, a swimmer from the Republic of Equatorial Guinea in west Africa, counts herself as one of the most fortunate athletes gathered in Sydney for the Olympic Games.
fields.body:
At just over five feet and weighing a little over seven stone, Paula Barila Bolopa, a swimmer from the Republic of Equatorial Guinea in west Africa, counts herself as one of the most fortunate athletes gathered in Sydney for the Olympic Games.

Standing at six feet nine inches and weighing almost 16 stone, Alonzo Mourning, professional basketball player from the United States, can count himself as the richest athlete of the 27th Olympiad.

While both can claim to be members of the Olympic family, there is little else these sporting cousins have in common, and the arrival of more than 10,000 athletes for the start of the games tomorrow has once again focused the spotlight on the massive discrepancies that exist between the haves and have nots of the sporting world.

While Mourning and other members of the United States basketball squad - known as the dream team - spent last night hidden away in five-star accommodation on the outskirts of Sydney after arriving in a private plane, Bolopa was still recovering from jet lag following an arduous three-day journey to the city. She left the country's capital, Malabo, last week in a bus.

After 14 hours on the road to Gabon, Bolopa - one of the four-member team from Equatorial Guinea, a former Spanish colony - boarded the plane to Paris for an eight-hour flight followed by a 13-hour flight to Hong Kong, where a different aircraft then took them on an eight-hour trip to Sydney.

The cost of the flights to Sydney for the team and three officials was paid by the International Olympic Committee.

Balopa, 18, is a part-time accountancy student who says she has no personal spending money for her two-week stay in Sydney and that her first priority is to find a job once the games are over.

Mourning, 21, who won a scholarship to Georgetown Washington university before turning professional, has signed a £75m contract with the basketball team Miami Heat.

For Balopa, a 50-metre freestyle swimmer, the dream of a gold medal is a distant one and the playing field is anything but even.

"I am not here to win," she said. "I know that I will never be able to win because I do not have the same facilities as athletes from other countries. I am here to do the best for my country and not let myself down. My spirit is strong. If your spirit is not strong in sport, then you are dead."

In Malabo there is no Olympic-size pool so Bolopa trains twice a week in a 20-metre pool in a local hotel. At times she cannot use it because there are too many hotel guests. During weekends she swims in the sea, watched over by her trainer and team coach, Bernardo Elonga Moliko.

"The hardest part of my training is swimming in the sea," she said. "My coaches have to watch me very carefully because the tide can be very strong and sharks are sometimes in the water."

Moliko, with £150 for the three-week stay, is the only member of the Equatorial Guinea team who brought spending money - but two days ago he discovered that some of his notes were counterfeit after the bank in the athletes' village refused toaccept them.

The Equatorial Guinea team has no uniforms and when Bolopa takes to the pool next week for her first heat in the 50-metres freestyle, she knows that another vital piece of clothing will be missing, affecting her slim chances of glory. She does not have one of the streamlined swimsuits specially designed for speed that will be used at the games probably by the richest athletes courtesy of their multi-million pound sponsors.

Bolopa's best time for 50 metres is about 30 seconds. The current gold medalist, Amy van Dyke, of the US, won in 1996 in 24.87 seconds.

"I don't think anybody will be interested in giving me a suit but there is no doubt that it would help me become faster," said Bolopa. "Athletes like me are already at a disadvantage before the event begins, how can I compete with someone who has the best equipment and coaching?"

Reflecting on the rich and poor gathered under the Olympic flag, Bolopa added: "I would love to meet Mr Mourning. It is beautiful that we are here at the Olympics together and he is lucky that he is so rich. Maybe he would like to sponsor me?"

A spokesman for the American Olympic team said that Mourning and other members of the US "dream team", current gold medalists, and favourites to win again, were not available for interview.

The spokesman added: "He does not need the publicity. He is here like any other American athlete to take the medals home."

webTitle: Vets call for swine fever 'killing zones'

fields.headline: Vets call for swine fever 'killing zones'
fields.trailText: Vets called for the destruction of pigs on scores more East Anglian farms yesterday to fight the worsening swine fever outbreak, which they fear could still threaten the entire British pork industry.
fields.body:
Vets called for the destruction of pigs on scores more East Anglian farms yesterday to fight the worsening swine fever outbreak, which they fear could still threaten the entire British pork industry.

They appealed to the government to introduce 3km killing zones around every farm where the disease has been confirmed - 12 so far with a further five suspected cases - to ensure that birds and wild animals did not help to spread the epidemic.

The Pig Veterinary Society said government controls, which include bans on moving pigs off neighbouring farms, were not enough to contain the disease. The society represents many vets working in Suffolk and Norfolk, and its drastic solution would cut a swath through agriculture in the two counties. Swine fever is not regarded as dangerous to humans, but the society warned Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, there were parallels with the BSE crisis.

"Reluctance to spend enough money on aggressive control measures at the start of that problem led to vastly escalated costs as the epidemic grew out of control," it said.

The society is supported by the National Pig Association, representing the industry, but the Ministry of Agriculture, advised by its own vets, refused yesterday to change its compulsory slaughter policy, which has so far led to the destruction of 25,000 pigs.

These have been animals on the infected farms, on others regarded as "dangerous contacts" where there may have been transport links before the first case was identified last month, and on a handful of farms within a kilometre of a cluster of four infected farms near Woodbridge, Suffolk.

"We are not going to carry out slaughter for the sake of it", a ministry spokeswoman said yesterday. "If we think there is a risk, we slaughter, if we don't, we don't."

Farmers whose animals are compulsorily slaughtered get far more compensation than those who have healthy stock but cannot sell them.

Mark White, senior vice-president of the veterinary society, insisted: "We are not looking to farmers getting a few more bob. East Anglia is being strangled by restrictions and if any [swine fever] leaks out within East Anglia, that is bad enough. But if it leaks out into central England, the south-east or north-east of England, that would be total disaster."

webTitle: Elephants are put on the pill

fields.headline: Elephants are put on the pill
fields.trailText: Efforts to protect elephants from hunters and habitat loss have been so successful that parts of Africa are in danger of being overrun with the animals, scientists have warned.
fields.body:
Efforts to protect elephants from hunters and habitat loss have been so successful that parts of Africa are in danger of being overrun with the animals, scientists have warned.

In an effort to control elephant numbers without culling them researchers have announced the completion of successful trials of an elephant contraceptive.

Writing in today's issue of Nature, a US-South African group said only 11 of 31 female elephants given the contraceptive had become pregnant.

The contraceptive is a vaccine that makes the elephant's immune system produce special antibodies. These antibodies lock on to proteins on the surface of the elephants' eggs, preventing sperm from fertilising them.

Kruger, one of a number of national parks with a surplus elephant problem, lies along South Africa's border with Mozambique.

About the size of Israel, it can support 7,500 to 8,000 elephants without threatening the survival of other species. But with no natural predators, elephants usually live to be 60, and the population grows by 7% to 8% a year.

Kruger has tried giving elephants away, but there are few responsible takers. So it has resorted to killing hundreds each year.

The alternative is to see the park suffer the fate of areas of Botswana and Zimbabwe which have been turned into wastelands, their dead trees stripped of bark, thanks to the depredations of elephant herds. A single elephant eats 300 to 600 lb of food a day.

A group of scientists from Germany tried a different elephant contraceptive technique some years ago when it fed oestrogen to females.

This proved disastrous. Two cows remained permanently on heat and were mobbed by bulls, with the result that two calves were trampled.

The US-South African team claims its contraceptive vaccine causes no such problems, and is easily reversible. "Elephants are intelligent and empathetic mammals, and culling is a last resort in controlling their numbers," the scientists said.

But the research, funded by US animal welfare groups opposed to culling, has drawn fire from African-based groups, who argue that it is an unnatural and selfish way to control elephant numbers.

Anti-contraception activists say it is folly to deprive wildlife parks and local people of the chance to earn money and grow food by harvesting ivory, hides and meat from surplus elephants.

webTitle: Palestine is on the verge of becoming a nation. But is it ready?

fields.headline: A nation waits
fields.standfirst:
Tomorrow, at the Olympic opening ceremony, two competitors will march proudly under the national flag of Palastine. But as the country at last stands poised on the verge of freedom, Matthew Engel asks whether it has the collective will to survive

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Tomorrow, at the Olympic opening ceremony, two competitors will march proudly under the national flag of Palastine. But as the country at last stands poised on the verge of freedom, Matthew Engel asks whether it has the collective will to survive
fields.body:
Friday evening: dusk has fallen over the Holy Land and a three-quarter moon is rising through a cloudless sky. Israel and Palestine are preparing quietly for their very different Friday nights: the start of the Jewish sabbath; the end of the Muslim equivalent. We are driving into the West Bank city of Ramallah.

Suddenly, there are the kind of noises that have made the Holy Land famous in our own time: what sounds like rocket fire, glass breaking and rocks being heaved on to the road. Drivers on the dual carriageway - their instincts honed by years of practice during the intifada - screech to a halt, manoeuvre frantically and accelerate away in the opposite direction. The sounds of shouting grow closer and the rock-throwing continues. Eventually, a group of Arab youths become visible, running down the hill towards the giant Marlboro ad by the city limits.

It takes a moment to realise that this can't be what it sounds like. There have been no Israeli soldiers in Ramallah for six years. "What's going on?" I ask a young man standing on the pavement. "Man," he says, "it's soooooo crazy. We get rid of the Israelis. Now we have all this shit."

"What's it about?"

"Football," he says with contempt.

The locals, he explains, have just played the team from the Balata refugee camp near Nablus. There is always bad feeling between the supporters. (And this was nothing, I discovered later, to what happened when a West Bank team played one from the Gaza Strip.) He stops. "Do you want anything, you know, stuff?" he asks. "Or are you straight?"

Giant Marlboro ads, football hooligans, dope dealers . . . welcome to the incipient state of Palestine, a place that in many respects is neither more nor less holy than most of the 190-odd countries which already exist.

Of all the weeks in the quadrennial calendar, the one with the Olympic opening ceremony is the one where shows of nationhood have most global resonance. Tomorrow in Sydney a lone athlete will carry the Palestinian flag; marching behind him will be just one swimmer. The two of them might have gone into the stadium emboldened by an official declaration of Palestine's independence. The day earmarked for this was yesterday: September 13. But the moment passed, under the pressure of world politics.

It would have been meaningless anyway. Notionally, the Palestine Liberation Organisation declared independence 12 years ago. And a declaration this week would have been equally ignored, not only by Israel, but also by world opinion, which is sympathetic to this Israeli government's efforts to do a deal.

But no one doubts now that independence is coming: somehow, sometime soon. The reality of impending Palestine is accepted by everyone except those on the wilder shores of Israeli politics - admittedly a fairly long stretch of coastline, but not one that any longer has the moral or physical strength to withstand the onrushing tide of historical inevitability.

There are no trivial times in the Middle East, but the months ahead - specifically, from the end of Israel's High Holyday season in late October until Bill Clinton leaves office in January - are now crucial. Palestinian sovereignty might - just might - come in triumph, with handshakes on the White House lawn, followed by the full-hearted consent of the Israeli and Palestinian people. It might happen amid terrible bloodshed. Things being as they are round here, it will almost certainly be a mess. The arguments about Jerusalem go on but it seems to me that something has changed crucially: Israel no longer has the moral certitude that would allow it to suppress Palestine indefinitely.

A nation-state is like an elephant: hard to define - but you know one when you see it. Every day Palestine looks increasingly like the rest of the herd, sometimes depressingly so. When Arafat returned from New York last Saturday for the meeting with his central council that took the decision to delay, he was greeted by the massed band of his security forces, headed by his personal swordbearer and half-a-dozen pipers who struck up The Road to the Isles with charming irrelevance. It could have been anywhere in the developing world.

Every week, there are other, quieter signs. Palestine now has its own web suffix: appropriately for a country which is the world's afterthought, it is "ps". A few days ago, the children went back to school. And some of them, for the first time, began learning according to a specifically Palestinian curriculum, rather than one borrowed from the Egyptians or Jordanians. A new international telephone code (970 instead of the Israeli 972) is said to be imminent. There are stamps, although the money value - in non-existent Palestinian fils - has to be blacked out if the letter is being sent to Israel.

In Gaza and the West Bank cities (excepting always Jerusalem, that most special of special cases), there is no longer any visible hint of a country under occupation. But this is in part an illusion. Arafat's jet flies in and out of Gaza airport by the grace and permission of Ehud Barak's government. And anyone else who wants to leave is allowed to do so only after checking in their self-respect with Israeli officialdom. Passengers from the airport have to be bused to the nearest Israeli border post to get an exit permit.

Dr Mahdi Abdul-Hadi, the head of Passia (the Palestine Academic Society for the Study of International Affairs), is regularly invited to speak at international conferences, sometimes with Jimmy Carter or even Bill Clinton. "If I want to renew my travelling document, I have to go to the Israeli ministry of the interior and start queuing at four in the mornings, sometimes two or three times, and it will cost me $150 to $200. This kind of humiliation is ongoing."

The political scientist Ghassan Khatib can go to Jerusalem, because his office is there. He cannot, however, invite his wife or mother to the city for dinner. "Dinner can only be a reason if you have good relations with the right Israeli officers." He needs another permit to cross Israel to visit Gaza, where the residents now complain they are currently being denied the right to go to Jerusalem even for prayer.

The Palestine that might have called itself independent this week looks like a Rorschach test on the map, reminiscent of the old, mad South African statelet of Bophuthatswana, which the apartheid regime created out of several, unrelated bite-sized chunks. In fact, it is even more complicated than that: the land is divided into A, B and C areas, depending on whether the Palestinians have control over both administration and security (A areas), administration but not security (B areas) or neither (C areas). Even on the most optimistic assessment - and the status of Jerusalem is irrelevant here - it will always be in two parts: the West Bank and Gaza, separated by the width of Israel.

Distances in these parts are surprisingly tiny. It takes only an hour to drive from Gaza to Jerusalem, if you don't have to endure obstructive border guards. Putative Palestine is a fraction larger than Oxfordshire. If the original Palestine had been the size of Australia or Siberia, no one would have had to fight anyone.

The history of non-contiguous countries is not an encouraging one: witness the fate of Pakistan. And there are already signs of the two wings developing different characteristics. But Palestine and Israel have many things in common, and one of these is the sense of overriding national destiny papering over a thousand underlying fissures.

This destiny, however, is created entirely by recent history. Less than 30 years ago, the Israeli prime minister Golda Meir could scornfully deny that the Palestinian people existed. Their sense of nationhood was barely visible before the 20s and was fully fashioned only amid the adversity of the refugee camps and the Israeli occupation. "Of course," he says. "We have cousins called Israelis."

But democracy has never flowered in the Arab world. Palestine is a cacophony of voices: the town of Nablus alone has nine TV stations. But journalists who shout too loud find that life can get difficult. "Officially, censorship does not exist," says journalist Khaled Abu Aker. The country does not feel like a dictatorship. Even the communists sit in Ramallah with the front door open and offer coffee to all-comers under a Che Vive! poster. However, their big hope is municipal elections, and these have been postponed - regularly, indefinitely and mysteriously.

Palestine's tortuous route to independence means that the country has endured the disillusionment that inevitably follows liberation without the cathartic joy of actually getting there. His voice is an unusually bitter one, but even the most optimistic scenarios for peace cannot solve Palestine's essential problem: how to make a living. "I used to take 2,000 shekels a day," says Abu Ibrahim, a draper. "Now it's barely 200." One of his few customers is Jasir um Mahmoud, a taxi-driver's wife and mother of 12. Life is tough the world over for mothers of 12, but that is not such an unusual figure in Gaza, which has the world's highest birthrate. I saw thousands of girls emerge from one narrow primary school gate - identically dressed in striped cotton dresses with jeans underneath for modesty, and ribbons in their hair for femininity. Arafat has talked of making the country "the Singapore of the Middle East." But if he is open for business, the customers are not yet piling in.

Palestine is still full of surprises. Ramallah has become a boom town because the West Bank administration is concentrated there; there is a casino in Jericho, which attracts the more louche kind of Israeli; Bethlehem will always be a nice little earner.

There are some surprisingly rich people around. Gaza City is far from the unmitigated hellhole of popular imagination, and the Mediterranean is as blue here as anywhere else, with the locals packing the beaches every Friday. The latest fashion accessory for the rich Gazan is a Sri Lankan or Filipino housemaid. You just can't get the staff, apparently . . .

But on the beachfront you have only to turn your eyes northward, and you can see - very clearly indeed - the harbour in the Israeli port of Ashdod. Palestine will be dependent on Israeli money and jobs for the foreseeable future.

Yet the suspicion between the two sides lingers poisonously. The latest idea for Jerusalem is that it should be declared to be under divine administration. "And does God empty the rubbish?" one Israeli commented. It is suggested that Gaza and the West Bank should be linked with a bridge over the full width of the desert so that no Palestinians have to touch Israeli soil. At the PLO flag shop in Gaza (which sells inflatable Arafats, of the sort sometimes waved at English football matches) you can buy little lapel pins with the Israeli and Palestinian flags intertwined. webTitle: Lecturer gets life for campus killing

fields.headline: Lecturer gets life for campus killing
fields.trailText: Steven Reid, the suicidal psychology lecturer who battered to death Elizabeth Stacey, a university colleague, so as to "have a friend in the afterlife", was yesterday given a life sentence for her manslaughter.
fields.body:
Steven Reid, the suicidal psychology lecturer who battered to death Elizabeth Stacey, a university colleague, so as to "have a friend in the afterlife", was yesterday given a life sentence for her manslaughter.

Reid, 34, described as lonely with a severe schizoid personality disorder, repeatedly bludgeoned Ms Stacey, 24, with a rolling pin at the University of Westminster on November 5 last year. Singling her out as a "warm, compassionate person", Reid, of Marylebone, west London, lured her to a research room to sort out a computer problem, before attacking her and leaving her for dead.

Passing sentence, Judge Fabyan Evans told Middlesex crown court in London: "This was a deliberate and planned killing. The tragic circumstances have left the whole academic community perplexed."

Two months ago, Jeffrey Pegden QC, had told the jury that, on balance of probabilities, Reid, who attempted suicide twice before being caught by police, had suffered from diminished responsibility. The jury returned unanimous verdicts of not guilty to murder, and guilty to manslaughter.

Yesterday Judge Evans told Reid: "Some doctors are of the view that there is a risk that you could kill again. Others say the risk cannot be ruled out." He said Reid's personality disorder, with the depression, led him to kill, and this combination could "detonate" again. A release recommendation was only possible after seven years.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Briton battered to death
A murder inquiry was under way yesterday after the battered body of a British woman holidaymaker was found dumped in a forest on the Greek island of Rhodes. Wendy Sullivan, 25, from Northwich, Cheshire, was believed to have had multiple injuries and to have been strangled.

Disease fear as vaccinations fall
Complacency among parents and "scare stories" about the side effects of vaccines could put children at risk of diseases all but eradicated the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry said yesterday. Vaccination levels have dropped, particularly for the MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) jab, but the association said the risks were very low.

More students take gap years
Record numbers of students are taking a gap year between school and university. Applications to defer entry had risen by 7.3% to just over 22,000, the universities and colleges admissions service said.

Customs hold Beatles' discs
Gold discs presented to the Beatles for the millionth sale of A Hard Day's Night which were seized by customs officials in the 60s in a dispute over unpaid import duty remain in the customs and excise library, it emerged yesterday.

Residents of Frinton-on-Sea, Essex, yesterday saw the town's first pub open. The Lock and Barrel was given the go-ahead despite opposition from locals who cherish the town's genteel traditions.

webTitle: High heal factor is feng shui in Choo's new shoes

fields.headline: High heal factor is feng shui in Choo's new shoes
fields.trailText: Feng shui is set to migrate to your feet. Jimmy Choo, British accessory designer of the year, in 1999, shoe couturier to the stars, and Buddhist, says he has created footwear with feng shui properties.
fields.body:
Feng shui is set to migrate to your feet. Jimmy Choo, British accessory designer of the year, in 1999, shoe couturier to the stars, and Buddhist, says he has created footwear with feng shui properties.

His Healing Soles shoes, with prices starting at £240 for a pair of sandals, carry crystals - rocks that for centuries and in ancient religions as well as New Age philosophies, have been credited with special healing and conducting powers.

Beatrix Ong, creative director at Jimmy Choo, said: "We pick out the crystals that are best for our customers and put them on the shoe in a beaded embellishment."

Rose quartz might be added to help on a relationship; amethyst and clear quartz to promote healing.

"The stones have an energy about them and it's like wearing a feng shui-ed necklace or karma beads," Ms Ong added.

webTitle: Shortage of pilots hits forces' front line squadrons

fields.headline: Shortage of pilots hits forces' front line squadrons
fields.trailText: The armed forces front line squadrons are severely under strength because of a shortage of trained pilots, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
The armed forces front line squadrons are severely under strength because of a shortage of trained pilots, according to a report published today.

The National Audit Office found that the RAF's fast jet squadrons - the cornerstone of the war efforts in Kosovo and the Gulf - were the worst hit, and are more than 100 pilots short of required strength.

The RAF has maintained operational commitments by pilots flying longer hours and having shorter breaks between tours of duty, reducing the planned ratio of pilots to aircraft and drawing on experienced pilots from other units to deploy on operations.

But the NAO warns if pilot shortfalls were to continue at current levels, there could be long term implications with "overstretch" affecting morale, leading to more pilots leaving the service early.

The report found the shortfall was not just confined to fast jets. The armed forces need 250 new pilots each year to fly helicopters for the army; helicopters and fast jets for the Royal Navy and helicopters, fast jets and multi-engined aircraft for the RAF.

In recent years the number of pilots entering operational service has averaged 205 - 18% fewer than required.

The Ministry of Defence has increased its target for training pilots to 290 in 2001 to try and make up for the shortfall. But according to the report even if the target is met it will still take 12 years before the fast jet squadrons are back to the strength the MoD believes necessary. During the study the NAO found there were 452 operational fast jet pilots.

According to the report, the main reason for the shortfall in jet pilots is an increase in the time taken to train them for frontline duty. The RAF aims to train a pilot in three years, but because of problems with equipment, closure of air bases and the need for experienced instructors to return to operational squadrons because of the shortfall, it currently takes nearer six years.

The NAO found that almost £42m of the £155m spent on training RAF fast jet pilots in 1998-99 was lost to wastage and delay in the training process.

Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, said: "The shortage of trained pilots is a cause for concern and on the department's own projections is likely to continue for some time even if targets are met for training new pilots."

Nick Cook, aviation editor of Jane's Defence Weekly, said the report was a grave embarrassment for the RAF and the MoD. "I would imagine this will effect the performance of the RAF considerably," he said. "This is a service that is deployed all over the world and it is already known that those deployments are putting an enormous burden on the air force. If we have a shortfall on top of that it is going to stretch them more and more."

The defence minister Lewis Moonie said the problems, which were based on a study between 1998 and 1999, were on the way to being solved.

The NAO found that almost £42m of the £155m spent on training RAF fast jet pilots in 1998-99 was lost to wastage and delay in the training process. Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, said: "The shortage of trained pilots is a cause for concern and on the department's own projections is likely to continue for some time even if targets are met for training new pilots." Nick Cook, aviation editor of Jane's Defence Weekly, said the report was a grave embarrassment for the RAF and the MoD. "I would imagine this will effect the performance of the RAF considerably," he said. "This is a service that is deployed all over the world and it is already known that those deployments are putting an enormous burden on the air force. If we have a shortfall on top of that it is going to stretch them more and more." The defence minister Lewis Moonie said the problems, which were based on a study between 1998 and 1999, were on the way to being solved.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 800 jobs for Tyneside yard
fields.body:
800 jobs for Tyneside yard

Former shipbuilding firm Swan Hunter has secured a contract which will create 800 jobs at the Tyneside shipyard in Wallsend, North Tyneside.

The contract, from American firm Kerr-McGee, involves building a floating production storage and offloading vessel for use in North Sea oilfields. Swan's Tyneside commercial director, Norman Brownell, described the contract as the largest in the North Sea this year.

"For the workforce it is great, and for the area it is great. We want to be able to provide regular work so we can give people more than one Christmas to look forward to. It shows the confidence in the area."

The contract involves building and installing equipment aboard a pre-built hull, providing 800 jobs to Swan Hunter and the companies involved in the North Eastern Marine and Offshore Cluster.

Stakeholder bid from TUC

The TUC yesterday launched Britain's first stakeholder pension scheme with the aim of attracting up to 5m members and becoming the market leader.

Its scheme will be run by the Prudential, which will provide three of its five managed funds, and is backed by Standard Life, which will provide the other two. It will carry an annual fee of 0.85%, well below the 1% maximum set by the government.

Byers fails on universal bank

The government's ambition to set up a universal bank via the Post Office stalled last night after Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, failed to provide banks with sufficient detail about his plans.

After meeting the chief executives and chairmen of the high street banks, he failed to pledge government financing for the project or give information about how the universal bank would operate. Bankers who attended the meeting indicated last night that they were not prepared to back the creation of universal bank.

BM sets up US flights fleet

British Midland is to launch direct daily services from Manchester to Washington and Chicago next spring with a fleet of eight Airbus A33Os in BM colours. Both services will be operated on a code share basis with United Airlines, allowing ticket swapping between airlines. It will be the first time Manchester has been served by direct flights from Washington.

Sir Michael Bishop, BM's chairman, said that it would introduce savings of 24% in business class and 32% for economy travellers compared with BA.

fields.headline: Kingfisher does the splits
fields.standfirst: Square Mile rewards beleaguered group's surprise move with 5% share price rise
fields.trailText: One of the City's best-known names, Kingfisher, yesterday surprised the Square Mile by announcing it was to split, spinning off Woolworths and Superdrug in a separate company from B&Q and Comet.
fields.body:
One of the City's best-known names, Kingfisher, yesterday surprised the Square Mile by announcing it was to split, spinning off Woolworths and Superdrug in a separate company from B&Q and Comet.

The move ignited shares in the beleaguered retailer which has struggled with its fortunes on the stock market since its failure to merge with supermarket group Asda last year.

The shares rose by 5% to 477.5p on speculation that the demerged operations would make it easier for the separate entities to be taken over.

Despite the rise, the company had bad news for the City, announcing the first fall in Kingfisher's profits in five years. The results were described by one leading analyst as "appalling".

Geoffrey Mulcahy, the chief executive, tried to play down the 10% fall in pretax profits to £204m in the six months to the end of July by insisting they had been knocked by investment in new businesses.

It intends to create more than 20,000 jobs in the next five years as "it opens new stores in its "general merchandise" business, the division of Kingfisher including Woolworths and Superdrug.

The general merchandise operation, which is likely to lose the Kingfisher name after the demerger, is to open 700 new stores, including 90 Big Ws, the large stores selling a variety of brands, and 400 Woolworths outlets.

Mr Mulcahy, who is to remain as the chief executive of B&Q and Comet after the demerger of Kingfisher, refused to name the management teams of the two business created by the demerger, which will take place in the second quarter of next year.

Analysts immediately described the demerger as clearing the decks for Kingfisher to buy up the part of Castorama - the French do it yourself business - it does not already own. There was also mounting speculation that Home Depot, the American DIY group, would step in to try to take control of B&Q.

One leading analyst said the demerger made "a lot of sense". "But whether they survive, without a takeover bid, is another story," he said.

Many analysts downgraded their profits forecasts for the remainder of the year after Mr Mulcahy acknowledged that profits may not show another rise until next year.

He denied the demerger was a knee-jerk reaction to the group's ailing share price and indicated that it been under consideration since Asda was snatched from its clutches by Wal-Mart last year.

Separating the two businesses, Kingfisher said, would allow them to grow more quickly in their markets. The general merchandise business - Woolworths and Superdrug - is concentrated primarily in the UK while the DIY and electricals operation is far more European, owning operations in France and Germany.

Kingfisher explained the fall in profit on a number of factors, including investment in new stores, e-commerce, technical accounting changes and the weakness of the euro.

Despite the fall in profits, the group reported record retail sales of £5.4bn and a 6.5% rise in like for like sales growth.

Woolworths and Superdrug are widely seen as operating a more competitive market than the DIY operations, although Mr Mulcahy insisted he believed "passionately" that the general merchanise business was capable of major growth.

However, many industry experts believe the demerger will allow Kingfisher to focus on the DIY market.

webTitle: Blair warns on sweat shop labour

fields.headline: Blair warns on sweat shop labour
fields.trailText: Rich western countries must help developing nations get rid of "sweat shop" conditions if they want them to embrace global free trade Tony Blair warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Rich western countries must help developing nations get rid of "sweat shop" conditions if they want them to embrace global free trade Tony Blair warned yesterday.

Trade sanctions against countries using child labour or polluting the environment are often counterproductive, according to a cabinet office report launched by the prime minister yesterday. Developing nations see such threats as a form of closet protectionism by rich states to protect home producers by keeping out cheap imports.

The warning comes in the first intervention by Mr Blair's policy team in the increasingly heated debate over trade that has sprung up since attempts to launch a new round of global trade talks collapsed in Seattle last December.

The report warns that there are "no short term fixes" but holds out hope that growing consumer concern about where their supermarket products come from will lead to better labelling.

The main conclusions of the performance and innovationunit report, entitled Rights of Exchange: social, health environmental and trade objectives on the global stage, include the firm conviction that the World Trade Organisation, is the wrong forum for non-trade issues.

"We cannot pile every woe in the world on the trade round and on trade policy," said the former trade minister, Brian Wilson, who said that the world must "find other ways of achieving desirable international objectives", including improved social and environmental conditions in third world countries.

The report, drawn up in consultation with outside experts, argues that rich countries and international bodies need to do more to help poorer countries gain market access for their products.
