webTitle: French defence firm is backing Britain

fields.headline: French defence firm is backing Britain
fields.trailText: Thomson-CSF, the French defence group which took over Racal Electronics this year, has applied for a secondary stock listing in London and could float Racal's Global Telematics subsidiary.
fields.body:
Thomson-CSF, the French defence group which took over Racal Electronics this year, has applied for a secondary stock listing in London and could float Racal's Global Telematics subsidiary.

Chairman Denis Ranque said he wanted to make Thomson a "British company in Britain" so it could get closer to its British customers, particularly the ministry of defence. He expected a listing by the end of the year.

Mr Ranque was reviewing all options as regards Global Telematics and other parts of Thomson's new information technology and services division. He admitted that a flotation of the satellite-based vehicle tracking business was under serious consideration.

Thomson was undertaking a review of all its operations to decide which should get investment and which could be disposed of.

Mr Ranque was speaking in London after announcing a 29% increase in operating profits in the first half of the year at 202m euros (£124m), ahead of analysts expectations.

The core profit figure compared with a fall in overall net income from 203m euros (£125m) to 120m euros. The 1999 figure was inflated by disposals.

The Racal figures, which will add an extra £450m of turnover, were not included in the results as the £1.5bn takeover was finalised at the end of June.

Thomson was particularly interested in Racal's defence arm and the merger was given the blessing of the MoD which wanted a competitor to BAe Systems, which had taken over Marconi Electronics Systems.

Mr Ranque said the integration of Racal Electronics was proceeding well with the combined company on track to reap synergies of at least 50m euros before tax by 2002.

The defence arm of Thomson recorded a 28% increase in orders in the first half of this year with aerospace up 13% and IT and services up 38%.

fields.headline: London 23rd in life's league
fields.standfirst: Rents and travel costs drag down living standards
fields.trailText: The average Londoner needs to work for 18 minutes to earn enough to buy a Big Mac, compared to a worldwide figure of 36 minutes.
fields.body:
The average Londoner needs to work for 18 minutes to earn enough to buy a Big Mac, compared to a worldwide figure of 36 minutes.

A survey by UBS Warburg examined spending power and standards of living indicators in 58 cities and concluded that higher earnings do not necessarily translate into a higher standard of living.

London is ranked 23rd in the standard of living league table, far behind many other major European and US cities. The survey attributes this to exceptionally high rents and to one of the most expensive public transport systems. It concludes: "An unfurnished three-room apartment is more expensive in London than anywhere else in the world."

Compounding London's problems is the way salaries in the city are "moderate" when compared with other leading cities resulting, the survey claims, in a significant reduction in average spending power. Dubliners, for example, have 20% more purchasing power than Londoners.

Workers in Tokyo are the highest paid in the world but also have the highest cost of living the survey claims. At the bottom of the league for wages are Nairobi, Jakarta and Bombay with average earnings of 3-6% of those at the top. When the research compared average net wages with the overall price of goods and services, the real value of earnings went down in cities at the top of the earnings table. The average cost of goods was highest in Tokyo, Oslo and New York, with London in 10th place.

Burger scale: working time requiredto buy a Big Mac

Tokyo 9 minutes

Hong Kong 9 minutes

New York 12 minutes

London 18 minutes

Nairobi 178 minutes

Source: Prices and Earnings around the Globe, 2000. UBS Warburg. The survey is conducted by UBS Warburg every three years.

fields.headline: Premier Oil 'marooned'
fields.trailText: Premier Oil missed out on £11.4m worth of revenues in the first six months of the year because it hedged its oil price risk at $19.54 a barrel when the average actually turned out to be $26.56.
fields.body:
Premier Oil missed out on £11.4m worth of revenues in the first six months of the year because it hedged its oil price risk at $19.54 a barrel when the average actually turned out to be $26.56.

Chief executive Charles Jamieson admitted the decision "did not look good" with hindsight but said it had been essential to win an injection of much-needed capital.

Despite the hedge the group bounced back into the black, with profits up at £2.5m for the six months to June 30, compared with a loss of £12.5m for the previous six months.

The company saw lower production volumes in the first half but said it planned to double its oil and gas output over the next three years and announced a string of new discoveries in one of its core areas, Indonesia.

Premier's share price fell 0.25p to 14p, and it is still trading well below net asset value. Iain Reid, an analyst at UBS Warburg, said the results were slightly better than forecast, and the hedging policy had been well flagged in the past.

He believed the stock could stay marooned at its present price as long as conglomerates Amerada Hess and Petronas each held 25% stakes.

Mr Jamieson understood this argument, and said discussions were being held with both partners to see whether something could be done. He declined to say whether Amerada Hess or Petronas might reduce their combined stakes to bring more liquidity into the Premier shares.

Premier formed a strategic alliance with Amerada Hess and Petronas under which its financial base was boosted with a £136m cash injection. Amerada Hess had already owned a 25% stake in Premier.

Output from Premier fell 11% to 25,900 barrels of oil equivalents a day in the first half owing to lower production at the UK Wytch Farm and Indonesian fields. But gas began flowing from its Myanmar field in May and gas will be coming from Indonesia by the end of this year.

webTitle: Costs of compensation may yet kill the big game hunters

fields.headline: Costs of compensation may yet kill the big game hunters
fields.trailText: Merger mania has so gripped Wall Street in recent months that the centre of the financial world is beginning to resemble a school dance just before the lights go on: everyone wants to grab a partner before it is too late.
fields.body:
Merger mania has so gripped Wall Street in recent months that the centre of the financial world is beginning to resemble a school dance just before the lights go on: everyone wants to grab a partner before it is too late.

The takeover of JP Morgan caps a week in which Wasserstein Perella, the investment banking boutique, revealed it was in talks with Dresdner Bank of Germany - and Goldman Sachs bought a leading US market maker. This week's deals follow two this summer in which the largest Swiss banking groups, Credit Suisse and UBS, picked up two American beauties - Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette and PaineWebber.

What is causing the rush to pair up, and why now? Most of the couplings depend on a kind of financial Darwinism, but it could all end with a market correction at a time when an increasingly small number of firms dominate global investment banking.

Bill Harrison, the chairman and chief executive of Chase Manhattan, said: "We are quickly coming down to less than a handful of winners in this wholesale investment banking space."

Chase has done more than almost any other firm in the past year to close the gap with the industry's leaders. Its $7.7bn acquisition of Robert Fleming closed less than two months ago, a deal that followed the purchase of two US boutiques, Hambrecht & Quist and Beacon.

Yet a look at some of the most important league tables shows how much banks like Chase still have to do. Just two banks - Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley - have advised 73% of the world's mergers and acquisitions this year, according to Thomson Securities Financial Data. Chase was in ninth place with a market share of less than 10%.

One insider said yesterday: "This is the elimination of the second tier and the fight to see who is to be in the top five."

And the reasons second-tier firms cannot compete? "Smaller firms are simply being killed by compensation," he said.

Merging firms flout the benefits of selling a broader range of services to existing clients. But they can afford to pay soaring salaries in an increasingly competitive market. JP Morgan and other second-tier banks such as Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns pay out more to keep the best staff and then watch their share price suffer as the extra expense hits earnings.

But while some are receiving unprecedented payouts others are left looking for work. Andrew Collins, senior analyst at ING Barings in New York, forecast a "bloodbath" for bankers yesterday.

The dearth of smaller partners left analysts divided about whether there would be many more mergers this year. George Bicher, of BT Alex Brown, said: "This has to be the last for a while ... The costs of playing this chess game are too high."

But one corporate financier said that anything was still possible in the race to reach a top slot. To underline the benefits of acquiring to win, he pointed out that 10 years ago JP Morgan was America's largest bank. At the time, the smart money thought three commercial banks struggling with bad loans and risky lending would go under - but the trio merged to become Chase Manhattan.

fields.headline: Dresdner's £150m ploy to keep staff
fields.standfirst: Handcuffs Lock-in adds to £1bn bill for Wasserstein
fields.trailText: Dresdner Bank is expected to lock in key Wasserstein Perella investment bankers with sweeteners of £150m after its £1bn takeover, which could be confirmed as soon as today.
fields.body:
Dresdner Bank is expected to lock in key Wasserstein Perella investment bankers with sweeteners of £150m after its £1bn takeover, which could be confirmed as soon as today.

The "golden handcuffs" come just four months after the German bank was forced to lock in its own investment bankers with total payments of £240m during its failed merger talks with its rival Deutsche Bank.

The Wasserstein business, which is based in the US, will be combined with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the German bank's investment bank, under the terms of the deal that was still being negotiated last night.

It is a crucial acquisition for the Geman bank which has failed to cement two major deals this year - the merger with Deutsche Bank and then the subsequent attempt to try to merge with its other local rival Commerzbank.

The move to buy Wasserstein raised speculation that the German bank was poised to spin off its investment bank ing business, which has already been given greater automony since the aborted mergers earlier this year.

The fresh series of lock-ins to highly paid investment banking staff are expected to aply to around half of Wasserstein's US-based staff.

Under the terms of the takeover, Bruce Wasserstein, who founded the business with former colleague Joseph Perella in 1988, is expected to be named as co-chairman of the investment bank.

webTitle: Leader: Serbian elections - a result tailored to order

fields.headline: A result tailored to order
fields.standfirst:
Milosevic prepares to defraud the voters

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: A flurry of high-level meetings this week in New York, Washington and Zagreb has served to underscore the west's impotence in the face of mounting evidence that Slobodan Milosevic will perpetrate a massive fraud in Yugoslavia's September 24 presidential election.
fields.body:
A flurry of high-level meetings this week in New York, Washington and Zagreb has served to underscore the west's impotence in the face of mounting evidence that Slobodan Milosevic will perpetrate a massive fraud in Yugoslavia's September 24 presidential election.

US officials said that Mr Milosevic was making "substantial preparations" to rig the poll. The EU admitted it was "worried". Speakers at the Balkan stability pact summit in Croatia, warning that the stakes could not be higher, urged Serbs to "vote wisely". But they all know the truth in this context of Stalin's remark, recycled by the EU's Chris Patten, that "it's not who votes that matters, it's who counts". And while the diplomats deliberately toned down their remarks for fear of inflaming Serb nationalist opinion, they also know that if Mr Milosevic succeeds in his fraud and suppresses any resulting domestic protests with his usual ruthless efficiency, there is precious little Nato's political masters can or will do about it.

It is not all gloom. Opinion polls currently suggest a victory (in a fair fight) for the leading anti-Milosevic candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, behind whom most opposition parties have coalesced. Resistance groups like Otpor, the student movement, would-be election monitors like the non-governmental Centre for Free Elections, human rights advocates like Natasa Kandic, and independent media bravely lead the way in defying state and judicial persecution, police torture and worse. "He's finished!" has become the rallying slogan for those who would be rid of this appalling man. But in his first campaign appearance, in Djerdap on Tuesday, Mr Milosevic made brutally plain what he thought of them. The nation's choice was between "heroes and traitors" in Nato's pay.

Among the "heroic" steps Mr Milosevic has in store are said to be up to 1m ghost votes, a modern version of Gogol's dead souls, which will supposedly be cast for him in Montenegro (despite an official poll boycott) and Kosovo; forged ballots, personation, and doctored electoral rolls; no independent verification; media censorship and blanket propaganda; and the intimidation of state employees, pensioners and public housing tenants. And if he still looks like losing, he may yet manufacture a military crisis with Montenegro's pro-western leadership. All this the west, lacking a firm, coherent Balkan strategy, is powerless to prevent. Better have some more meetings.

webTitle: Morgan marriage  After the divorce, a new partner

fields.headline: Morgan marriage  After the divorce, a new partner
fields.trailText: That Chase Manhattan is renaming itself JP Morgan Chase after the surprise acquisition of its Wall Street neighbour is a reflection of the high regard in which the institution is held in the financial services industry.
fields.body:
That Chase Manhattan is renaming itself JP Morgan Chase after the surprise acquisition of its Wall Street neighbour is a reflection of the high regard in which the institution is held in the financial services industry.

The name originates from its founder J Pierpont Morgan , who died in 1913, 20 years before the influential banking business he founded was forced to split in two.

The 1933 Glass-Steagall Act separated commercial and investment banking and forced the Morgan Stanley brokerage firm to be split from JP Morgan. Ironically the act was lifted last year.

In the last 20 years, JP Morgan has stretched the law to its limit - fending off the US Congress- and managed to set up businesses from which it would normally have been prohibited, such as a share trading service.It also set up businesses in emerging markets and established derivatives operations.

This was a stark step-change for JP Morgan which was built up on advising major companies and tycoons on their business strategy, lending money to governments and corporations.

During much of the last decade speculation mounted that the two Morgan names would be reunited again but they were quashed four years ago when Morgan Stanley merged with Dean Witter to create Morgan Stanley Dean Witter .

Despite its strong origins and reputation, JP Morgan has been saddled with rumours that it would be unable to go it alone. Only last week Deutsche Bank, the German financial house, was tipped as the buyer. That it has sold out to Chase suggests that the bankers at JP Morgan were satisfied that they have secured the right price for their enviable franchise.

webTitle: Olypmic football: Pirlo's late show for Italy

fields.headline: Pirlo's late show for Italy
fields.trailText: Andrea Pirlo gave Italy a winning start in Group A of the football tournament, scoring nine minutes from time just when Australia thought they had done enough for a point.
fields.body:
Andrea Pirlo gave Italy a winning start in Group A of the football tournament, scoring off the inside of a post nine minutes from time when Australia thought they had done enough to send the majority of the 93,252 fans home from the MCG with a point to celebrate.

The Internazionale midfielder, who earlier hit the bar and had a 25-yard free-kick headed off the line, was put through by Massimo Margiotta after a mistake in the Australia defence. With only Leeds's Danny Milosevic to beat, Pirlo slipped a shot past the goalkeper and it just crossed the line before being cleared by a defender.

"I don't think we deserved to win," said Marco Tardelli, coach to the European Under-21 champions Italy. "We had some good saves. We missed some good chances. We had a good goalkeeper."

Indeed Christian Abbiati, the Milan goalkeeper, made two fine saves to defy the Olyroos, but the hosts did enough to suggest they may win their remaining games, against Nigeria and Honduras. Milosevic did well to block a Gianluca Zambrotta shot, and Mark Viduka, who played as Australia's sole striker, had the goal at his mercy but prodded the ball over the bar with a knee.

"To play one of the giants of the world and take them to the task, you have to be proud. We know that Italy are the master of the counter-attack," said Raul Blanco, Australia's coach. "You need only one to pay a heavy bill."

Nigeria, the Olympic champions, needed a 25-yard shot by Yakubu Ayegbeni in injury-time to draw 3-3 with Honduras in Adelaide. Arsenal's Lauren scored Cameroon's third goal as they beat Kuwait 3-2 in the Group C match in Brisbane, and the United States and the Czech Republic drew 2-2 in Canberra.

 Wendy Toms, Britain's only representative in the football tournament, will not officiate at today's women's match between China and Nigeria after spraining an ankle in her hotel room. She is expected to be fit for later games.

fields.headline: Not so great Scott!
fields.standfirst: Driven up the pole by debunkers
fields.trailText: If the London stock market traded in reputations, it would be in the depths of a bear market. This summer the public has been asked to accept that the gilded youth who fought the Battle of Britain were class-ridden snobs and to believe that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle not only stole the plot of the Hound of the Baskervilles from a friend, but then killed him to hide the fact.
fields.body:
If the London stock market traded in reputations, it would be in the depths of a bear market. This summer the public has been asked to accept that the gilded youth who fought the Battle of Britain were class-ridden snobs and to believe that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle not only stole the plot of the Hound of the Baskervilles from a friend, but then killed him to hide the fact. Today an exhibition, South, opens at the National Maritime Museum, bringing with it a fresh verdict on Captain Robert Falcon Scott and the Norwegian rival who beat him to the south pole, Roald Amundsen. Once again the currency of reputation has been shown to be horribly volatile.

Not long ago the story of poor Captain Scott was taught as a simple one of ice, death and stoicism. No longer. The new Scott has been found to be a dismal leader, dismissive of good advice, wrongly equipped (not least with Indian ponies used to tropical heat, not icy blasts) and remote from his men. He even rowed with Sir Ernest Shackleton in a blizzard at 80 degrees south. Meanwhile, the new Amundsen comes over not as the devious dog-eating Norwegian of old, but as a caring, sharing team-leader whose men put on weight as they charged back from the pole and who buried stocks of spare food in ice caves. In its exhibition, the National Maritime Museum is naturally keener to proclaim the new Amundsen than the new Scott, but the sub-text is obvious.

The lessons of such reshuffling are not all bad. As old figures are knocked down, new ones are built up to replace them. But it is tricky to know where the process is at. Napoleon's stock appears to have risen (less power-crazed butcher, more pan-European planner) while Mother Theresa's has fallen. Trading in Diana shares has been suspended pending review, but the Queen Mum remains a blue chip. Nobody's buying Titus Oates and nobody's selling Charles Darwin or Nelson Mandela. Yet.

fields.headline: Petrol crisis: the alternatives
fields.trailText: Three key points have been overlooked in most coverage of the fuel crisis.
fields.body:
Three key points have been overlooked in most coverage of the fuel crisis.

First, why have a cartel of giant oil companies turned off the taps just now? They are effectively in collusion with the petrol pickets, to give the government a bloody nose in the run-up to the crucial world climate talks in the Hague in November. Governments must agree carbon dioxide and other emission cuts to tackle climate change. High fuel taxes are necessary to force industry and householders to use fossil fuels much more efficiently and cut pollution: that action bites into oil company profits.

Second, why has the political response been so feeble? No minister or opposition leader has yet dared explain that high fuel prices are here to stay and are good for the economy as well as the environment. High prices cut resource waste and inefficiencies of production and consumption. As companies and households run more effectively, their costs go down. As fossil fuels be come dearer, clean vehicle fuels like hydrogen and renewable energy become cheaper to develop, developing new companies and creating jobs.

Third, there are better ways to help poorer people who depend on cars than by cutting fuel duty. The Treasury is sitting on at least £4bn of unexpected tax revenue because of crude oil price rises. At least half should be spent on buses and other transport services in rural and suburban areas. Better public transport means fewer drivers on the road, less congestion and quicker journeys for truckers and other professional road users. The government could also tax foreign lorries using our roads to level the playing field for UK hauliers.

There is no need for panic. People who care about the environment should use their power as citizens to bring the corporations and politicians to account.
Charles Secrett
Director, Friends of the Earth

 High fuel tax is a blunt instrument that fails to distinguish between transport needs and problems in different areas. Whatever happened to road pricing? It can be targeted to discourage commuting into cities by car, while leaving alone rural areas where a car is a necessity. The government could then reduce fuel tax and still have enough revenue to fund its spending programme. Labour failed to back it in its transport review, but it remains a Liberal Democrat policy.
David Johnson
Harrogate

 The aim of reducing motor vehicle use could be addressed by petrol rationing. All taxed motor vehicles would receive a ration - for example, private cars 100 litres per month. Over a number of years the allowance would be reduced. This is equal pain for all. On average, rural residents drive less than their urban counterparts. People in rural areas could sell their surplus petrol (coupons) to richer drivers going further. This private petrol trading is equivalent to the proposed company trading of greenhouse gas emissions. It would mean that poorer rural residents could get an income boost from selling their petrol to richer urban residents.
Prof Lewis Lesley
Liverpool John Moores University

 Biodiesel, produced from seed crops like flax or rape, is very clean and removes carbon dioxide from the atmosphere - it even smells nice. The snag is that it currently costs five times as much to produce as oil diesel. However, that hasn't discouraged the Canadians, who are about to open a massive plant in Saskatchewan.
Dr Brendan Hamil
Milnathort, Kinross

 Unlike the UK, many municipal buses in France will be unaffected by the present crisis: they use bio-diesel made from rape seed oil.
Conrad Cork
Leicester

 Biomass is an excellent source of energy as it can be converted easily into alcohol and used to produce fuel. There is a plant source that can be grown quickly and easily without fertilisers or pesticides. Unfortunately it is illegal: cannabis.
Alun Buffry
Legalise Cannabis Alliance

 California's zero emission vehicle mandate will force car makers to offer 10% of their fleets as electrics from 2003. More than 2,000 electric vehicles run in California. If every European government took the same approach, we could start weaning ourselves off oil.
Gerry Woolf
Electric Vehicle Association of Great Britain

 I've just seen the smuggest milkman in Wales.
Mark Lewney
Cardiff

 A hydrogen economy would provide zero-emission transport by utilising renewably produced hydrogen within fuel-cell vehicles. Most motor manufacturers are already developing fuel-cell cars for launch in 2004.
Ben Lane
Director, Ecolane Transport Consultancy

 We need better public transport, real priority for pedestrians and cyclists and tougher planning restrictions on car-based developments. There can be no return to business as usual after this crisis has passed.
Stephen Joseph
Director, Transport 2000

 For half an hour at 4pm on Tuesday, this city suburb felt like a civilised place to be: buses and trains full, local shops bustling, an explosion of cyclists and pedestrians, healthily getting from school and work without risk of being killed by a raging driver.
Rebecca Leach
Stockport

 I must say I am impressed by the preparations here in the UK in the run-up to Car-Free Day on September 22.
Ed Sonsino
London

 Having witnessed the behaviour of males on the forecourts this week, I wonder if there is some way of using testosterone to power the combustion engine?
Liz Wilde
Bromsgrove

 The Learning Journey is already under way in our house (Parents asked to play part in learning, September 12). An empty baby-wipe box is the oil refinery. The toy trucks have formed a blockade and the hastily converted Thomas the Tank Engines are full of angry motorists queueing at the Lego petrol station.
Eileen Burnip
Hebden Bridge, W Yorks

fields.headline: Fuelling the dispute
fields.trailText:
David Handley of Farmers for Action says (Farmers already get subsidy, September 13) "we're not subsidised on anything". So will he support me if I propose in parliament the removal of all headage payments, premiums, arable payments, set-aside, organic grants, countryside stewardship grants, red diesel allowance etc etc? As they are not, apparently, noticed, they are clearly unnecessary.
Colin Pickthall MP

webTitle: Corporate cash is better than antiquated labs

fields.headline: Corporate cash is better than antiquated labs
fields.trailText: George Monbiot (Masters of the universities, G2, September 11) would be proud of my laboratory at Cambridge University. Not a penny of corporate cash corrupts our research. But he is wrong if he thinks this purity of means gives rise to better science. Lack of resources leads to crude expedients, dilution of effort and time wasted flogging life back into antiquated equipment long overdue for the scrapheap. In the end, it leads to lost opportunities and lost leadership.
fields.body:
George Monbiot (Masters of the universities, G2, September 11) would be proud of my laboratory at Cambridge University. Not a penny of corporate cash corrupts our research. But he is wrong if he thinks this purity of means gives rise to better science. Lack of resources leads to crude expedients, dilution of effort and time wasted flogging life back into antiquated equipment long overdue for the scrapheap. In the end, it leads to lost opportunities and lost leadership.

Britain needs more corporate involvement with research, not less, if its universities are to avoid stagnation. The oil companies, whose influence Monbiot seems to think has been so baleful, have on the contrary been generous friends to our work. The principal instru ments and many of the materials we use were donated by oil companies with no strings attached. Since our project is developing an alternative to the petrol engine, they deserve credit for unselfish support.
Dale R McIntyre
Dept of materials science, Cambridge University

 George Monbiot's views on university-industry links are based on a superficial analysis of current practice. Universities have been largely successful in establishing links of mutual benefit to both parties that address the general points he raises and reflect the differing needs of various industrial sectors and of academics with whom they collaborate.

The potential threat to the research base comes from the indirect influence of industry on the way public funds are spent, their diversion to projects with short-term aims and objectives, and the mounting levels of accountability which parody actual industrial practice.
Richard Jennings
Wolfson industrial liaison office, Cambridge University

 I would like to reassure George Monbiot that I have complete academic freedom. I value my total scientific honesty and integrity more than any other aspect of my professional life.
Prof Duncan Maskell
Marks & Spencer professor of farm animal health, food science and food safety, Cambridge University

 In 1945 Shell gave Cambridge University funds to establish a chair and to start a department of chemical engineering. The department has always set its teaching and research as it thought fit, not to an agenda set by Shell.
Prof John Bridgwater
Shell professor of chemical engineering, Cambridge University

 George Monbiot's book shows disdain for the contribution business now makes to higher education, betraying a mindset out of keeping with attitudes in the rest of the world, particularly America.

In writing about me, he says I was "named in the Commons inquiry into the sale of a 'supergun' to Iraq". Could I again state unequivocally that I had no involvement whatsoever in the so-called supergun affair?
Wafic Said

webTitle: Russian navy officer cleared of treason

fields.headline: Russian navy officer cleared of treason
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Alexander Nikitin, a dissident former Russian navy officer jailed on charges of high treason for blowing the whistle on radiation pollution in Russia's far north, successfully concluded a four-year tussle yesterday to clear his name.
fields.body:
Alexander Nikitin, a dissident former Russian navy officer jailed on charges of high treason for blowing the whistle on radiation pollution in Russia's far north, successfully concluded a four-year tussle yesterday to clear his name.

Russia's supreme court upheld his acquittal on treason charges despite prosecutors' attempts to have the case reopened. Yesterday's ruling was the 13th time a Russian court had deliberated on the case of Captain Nikitin who was arrested in 1996 and spent 22 months in jail awaiting trial.

The KGB's successor, the FSB, headed until last year by now-President Vladimir Putin, had sought a 12-year sentence for Captain Nikitin for leaking information on the radiation risks posed by the scores of abandoned nuclear submarines in the Arctic, a hazard highlighted by the sinking of the Kursk in the Barents Sea.

Capt Nikitin leaked his information to the Norwegian environmentalist group Bellona which has issued withering reports on the state of the northern fleet.

Bellona and Capt Nikitin always argued that the information was collated from open sources. Only after the charges were filed were the documents in question declared to contain state secrets.

fields.headline: Free schools from red tape
fields.trailText: Mr Blair's description of William Hague's education plans as the "wackiest collection" of policy for some time (Blair plans schools revolution, September 9), simply demonstrates that the prime minister has failed to grasp the fundamental difference that is being proposed.
fields.body:
Mr Blair's description of William Hague's education plans as the "wackiest collection" of policy for some time (Blair plans schools revolution, September 9), simply demonstrates that the prime minister has failed to grasp the fundamental difference that is being proposed.

Good teachers are now leaving the profession, citing the growing burden of regulation as the reason. The government does now seem aware of a growing professional skills shortage. It is not only education that is suffering. Government control is stifling diversity, innovation and energy out of all public services. By lifting the bureaucratic load from schools, Mr Hague recognises that greater freedom from government and local authority control will benefit teachers and pupils alike.
Cllr Sandy Bruce-Lockhart

webTitle: Fancy a seat in the Lords? Apply now

fields.headline: Fancy a seat in the Lords? Apply now
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Anyone who believes they could do a better job of making laws in this country can now prove it after members of the public were yesterday invited to nominate themselves for a seat in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Anyone who believes they could do a better job of making laws in this country can now prove it after members of the public were yesterday invited to nominate themselves for a seat in the House of Lords.

Would-be "people's peers" have until November 17 to put themselves or others forward for a seat in the upper chamber as one of a handful of independent, non-party political life peers to be appointed next spring. Aspiring lords and ladies will be asked to submit an application form along with a CV and two references to the House of Lords appointments commission, which was set up by Tony Blair last May.

Competition for the eight or 10 places each year is expected to be tough, but those appointed will hold their peerage for life. The panel of scrutineers is keen to appoint peers from a wide range of social backgrounds to balance the largely white, elderly and male population in the Lords.

But Lord Stevenson, the crossbench peer who chairs the commission, stressed that only people with an "outstanding record of personal success and achievement in their chosen fields" and a strong track record of "independence and integrity" should apply, adding: "It would be foolish and irresponsible to raise false expectations."

Lord Stevenson denied there were any plans for Big Brother-style evictions of people's peers who failed to contribute effectively to the Lords, saying: "We won't be appointing any duds."

Would-be people's peers can contact the commission for an information pack and application form on 0117 982 1171.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In the G2 cover story (page 2, September 12), we said there were riots for self-determination in Stanleyville (now Kisangani), the capital of the Belgian Congo, in 1959. Stanleyville was never the capital. That was Leopoldville, now Kinshasa, which is where the riots were. At a later point in the piece we referred to the Lindi research camp which we said was five miles from Kinshasa.
fields.body:
 In the G2 cover story (page 2, September 12), we said there were riots for self-determination in Stanleyville (now Kisangani), the capital of the Belgian Congo, in 1959. Stanleyville was never the capital. That was Leopoldville, now Kinshasa, which is where the riots were. At a later point in the piece we referred to the Lindi research camp which we said was five miles from Kinshasa. It wasn't. We meant to say "five miles from Stanleyville, now Kisangani". In the same piece we seemed to associate Franklin D Roosevelt with the polio epidemics of the postwar period. He had polio in 1921. President Roosevelt died in office in 1945. Sorry for the confusion.

The Peter Doyle whose picture appeared, page 3, G2, September 11, with an article headed Masters of the universities, is indeed Peter Doyle, but in the context, the wrong one. He is professor of marketing at Warwick University. The Peter Doyle we should have shown is chairman of the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council, and a different person altogether. Apologies to both.

The play at the Almeida in London is Conversations After a Burial, as our review, page 18, yesterday, indicated, and not Conversations After a Funeral as a caption to the accompanying picture said (even though it may amount to the same thing).

We misidentified the two players in our photograph from the Fulham-Burnley match at Craven Cottage, page 31, yesterday. They were not Andy Melville and Ian Cox (as originally captioned by the agency supplying the picture). They were Barry Hayles and Mitchell Thomas. Apologies all round.

In an edited extract from George Monbiot's new book, on the front page of the Saturday Review, September 9, we referred to the Skye Bridge and said, "The one-mile crossing now costs £5.70 each way." That is perfectly true. A car and caravan costs twice as much at £11.40 and a coach for more than 22 passengers costs £41.20 each way. What, perhaps, the extract did not make clear is that regular users pay £1.34 per crossing. A book of 20 tickets, valid for a year, costs £26.80.

Sir Richard Branson, contrary to the suggestion in a column on page 7, G2, September 11, is still Sir Richard and not yet Lord Branson.

In a report headed Jolted Bush plays the underdog, page 19, September 9, we referred to "the Missouri Congressman John Kasich". He is from Ohio, not Missouri.

It is Guardian policy to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Spain strikes at Eta brains and money

fields.headline: Spain strikes at Eta brains and money
fields.standfirst: Special report: violence in Spain
fields.trailText: Spanish police swept across the Basque country yesterday to arrrest 20 suspected members of the separatist organisation Eta in an operation believed to have netted some the group's top strategists and fundraisers.
fields.body:
Spanish police swept across the Basque country yesterday to arrrest 20 suspected members of the separatist organisation Eta in an operation believed to have netted some the group's top strategists and fundraisers.

More than 300 members of the civil guard, many with faces covered to prevent retaliation, raided towns and villages throughout the Basque region and neighbouring Navarre.

The operation included raids on a number of offices belonging to Herri Batasuna, Eta's political wing. Several prominent members of HB were among those arrested, including a former MP.

The detainees were taken to Madrid and charged with membership of an illegal organisation by investigating magistrate Baltasar Garzon, a senior member of Spain's national court which has special powers to try those accused of terrorist offences.

The interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, said the operation was a "major blow" to Eta.

"We have virtually destroyed Eta's political structure in Spain," he said, adding that the people arrested were all part of Eta-Ekin, the arm of the organisation responsible for planning attacks, organising funds and devising long-term strategy rather than carrying out violent actions.

Eta has killed some 800 people since 1968 in its campaign for Basque independence. It has been particularly active since ending a 14-month truce last December, claiming responsibility for 11 killings in car bombings and shootings and being blamed for a 12th.

But the leader of the non-violent Basque Nationalist party (PNV), Xabier Arzalluz, cast doubt on the minister's claim, describing the operation as a public relations move. "This sort of action is an attempt to get favourable headlines at a time when the police are failing to catch any of the people who actually carry out attacks," he said.

The arrests followed a government promise to step up police action. Eta used the truce to revamp its structure and recruit new members. Mr Mayor Oreja admitted that counter-terrorist forces were struggling to identify the new units that have targeted journalists and businessmen as well as politicians and members of the armed forces in their attacks.

At the funeral of Eta's most recent victim - a young councillor representing Spain's governing People's party - the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, declared: "Those who take it into their hands to execute their fellow citizens will not remain immune." They have, he said, "good reason to worry".

Yesterday's action proved he was not just sabre-rattling. It was similar to one carried out in 1997 which led to the trial of all 23 members of Herri Batasuna's leadership committee of the day. They were each sentenced to seven years in jail but released two years later when Spain's constitutional court overturned the ruling.

The operation coincided with a French decision to extradite a member of Eta accused of plotting to kill King Juan Carlos of Spain in 1995. He is the fourth member of the group to be extradited this year. But Eta's top ideologues are still thought to operate from France, and its commando units move back and forth across the border to elude Spanish police.

Mr Aznar has also tried to put pressure on the separatists at the political level. Government ministers reiterated calls for the Basque regional president, Juan Jose Ibarretxe, to resign and call early elections to the Basque parliament. "It is clear he has lost control of the region," said a senior member of the People's party.

Mr Ibarretxe, heads a minority nationalist government after breaking off a parliamentary alliance with the separatists. Mr Aznar has accused him of being lukewarm in his condemnation of terrorism and accused the Basque Nationalist party of condoning murder because it insists lines of communication must be kept open to Eta if there is to be a lasting peace.

Spain's opposition Socialist party has said it would back a vote of no-confidence that would force Basque elections.

Herri Batasuna's leader, Arnaldo Otegui, accused the government of trying to deny the separatists their political rights. "They are determined to turn a legitimate political force into outlaws," he said. The separatists have obtained between 16% and 19% of the vote in recent Basque elections.

fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText:
Instant justice
The federal communications commission could force America Online to open its instant-messaging service to rivals as a condition of approving its merger with Time Warner, the Wall Street Journal reported.
fields.body:
Instant justice
The federal communications commission could force America Online to open its instant-messaging service to rivals as a condition of approving its merger with Time Warner, the Wall Street Journal reported.

The FCC has also concluded it should press Time Warner to open its high-speed cable lines to rivals more than the companies have agreed.

The review of the deal, which is now valued at about $126bn (£90bn), will continue for another month before proposals go to the full commission for a vote.

$1.3bn deal
Internet infrastructure company Inktomi said it would buy FastForward Networks of San Francisco, a developer of technology that distributes and manages live online broadcasts, in a stock deal worth about $1.3bn.

The deal adds live broadcasting technology and management to Inktomi's suite of licensed products that provide online searches and manage internet traffic.

Gameplay
Agreeent has been signed by I Software Creations to provide content for NTL 's interactive Knowledge and Games Channels, available through digital TV.

Cycle hub
Business-to-business electronic trading community specialist Infobank has won a contract with BikeCommerce.com to provide software to power an electronic trading hub to connect independent bicycle retailers with suppliers, manufacturers and customers across the US.

fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Police in Croatia have arrested 16 suspected war criminals in the biggest swoop since the new government came to power last January. Those detained are ethnic Croats, wanted for their alleged involvement in crimes against civilians in Bosnia and Croatia. They include three high-ranking officers in the Croatian army.
fields.body:
Police in Croatia have arrested 16 suspected war criminals in the biggest swoop since the new government came to power last January. Those detained are ethnic Croats, wanted for their alleged involvement in crimes against civilians in Bosnia and Croatia. They include three high-ranking officers in the Croatian army.

The crackdown appears to have been triggered by the assassination on August 28 of Milan Levar, a key witness who had given evidence against fellow Croats at the international war crimes tribunal at the Hague.

Zagreb's willingness to cooperate with the Hague has provoked a furious reaction from veterans' groups and extreme nationalists. They accuse the government of sullying the reputation of fighters in the "patriotic war" against Serbia in 1991, and in the two military campaigns to retake lost territory, operations Flash and Storm in 1995.

The Croatian president, Stipe Mesic, has also received a death threat, connected to his willingness to work with the tribunal, from an organisation calling itself the Croatian Revolutionary Fraternity, a paramilitary group originating in Croatian emigre circles.

fields.headline: Hackers access secret union data
fields.trailText: Hackers have accessed personal data on 260,000 civil servants held on computer files by the Public and Commercial Services Union in an attempt to influence who will win an election for general secretary later this year.
fields.body:
Hackers have accessed personal data on 260,000 civil servants held on computer files by the Public and Commercial Services Union in an attempt to influence who will win an election for general secretary later this year.

The action, an offence under the Data Protection Act, enabled tens of thousands of leaflets endorsing the present general secretary, Barry Reamsbottom, to be sent by a union faction to members' work and home addresses. There is no suggestion that Mr Reamsbottom had any involvement in what happened.

Mr Reamsbottom is being challenged for the post by Hugh Lanning, an assistant general secretary.

A confidential investigation prepared for the union's national executive, obtained by the Guardian, reveals "very weak controls" over computer security at the union's headquarters in Clapham, south London. The computer room door was always open because of ineffective air conditioning; program controls were non-existent; passwords were rarely changed; and anybody outside the system would not be logged off automatically after three failed attempts to access it.

An inquiry by Antony White QC for the union says "a person or persons unknown acting on behalf of the National Moderate Group surreptitiously extracted information from PCS membership records and deleted any record of the extraction to cover their tracks".

His findings follow an investigation which has split the union. Marion Chambers, leader of the faction and a former union president, accused Mr White of producing a "tainted" report.

"I do not think you are entitled to draw any particular conclusion about the distribution of National Moderate Group election materials without sufficient supporting evidence," she wrote to him.

She said the faction had obtained the information through decades of experience.

The rival candidate, Mr Lanning, pointed out that this information included 1,300 correct addresses for people working at customs and excise in Dover, and 1,400 at the Ministry of Defence.

Mr Reamsbottom said yesterday: "I am glad that all staff and officials have been cleared by the inquiry of using the information. I am very concerned about the lack of security and will be conducting an urgent review. It could have been an outside job."

fields.headline: Inferno shuts Jakarta stock exchange
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: A big car bomb exploded yesterday afternoon in the underground car park of Indonesia's main stock exchange, packed at the time with drivers waiting to take their bosses home. At least 15 people were killed and more than 30 injured.
fields.body:
A big car bomb exploded yesterday afternoon in the underground car park of Indonesia's main stock exchange, packed at the time with drivers waiting to take their bosses home. At least 15 people were killed and more than 30 injured.

It was the latest in a series of explosions in Jakarta. Nobody has claimed responsibility but security forces believe supporters of the country's former dictator Suharto are responsible. Five people were arrested after the explosion, but police have given no details about them.

A bus was blown up just before the opening of the corruption trial of General Suharto two weeks ago. The second session of these proceedings against the ailing former leader is scheduled for today. "It is the most obvious answer," a senior investigator said last night. "There is certainly a person or group determined to destabilise the country."

Police sources say the bomb, planted near the drivers' cafeteria on the second basement level, probably contained up to 50kg of explosive. It ignited a chain of explosions as petrol tanks blew up in surrounding cars. A huge fire sent black smoke billowing out of the complex, which consists of two skyscrapers.

"I was heading down to the second-level basement when the bomb exploded," said Alex Herlambang, a driver. "I was thrown to the ground. The smoke came up very quickly but I was able to scramble up the stairs and out."

"I was on the 17th floor when the bombs went off," said Benny Slamet, Indonesia representative for the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate. "The blast came straight up from the ground. Everything shook but it was obvious it was not an earthquake."

There seems to have been little structural damage to the building, which also contains the offices of the World Bank, several foreign banks and accounting firms, and numerous stockbrokerages. But police said the stock exchange would be closed until the end of the week while they investigate.

It took firemen, most of them ill-equipped to tackle an incident of this scale, more than four hours to contain the fire. Dozens of people were trapped in the basement. When rescuers eventually descended through the gloom they found a devastating scene.

"There were more than 30 cars that were totally burned, completely wrecked," police sergeant Surwando said. "And then we started to notice the bodies. A couple had clearly been very close to the bomb and died instantly while others had tried to hide from the smoke in their cars." He expected more dead to be found.

There have been several other bombs in Jakarta recently. Two people were killed by a car bomb outside the residence of the Philippines ambassador last month; several were injured when a device exploded at the attorney general's office. Police have also found several bombs before they went off; most, they said, seemed professionally made.

Yesterday's bomb did further damage to Indonesia's battered currency, the rupiah. It fell about 5% yesterday and traders said it is likely to fall further today as investors get increasingly dubious about risking money on Indonesia.

The president, Abdurrahman Wahid, restructured his government last month to try to stimulate a recovery.

There are signs that econonomic reforms are having some effect. But political events - such as the murder of three UN workers in West Timor last week, continued unrest in many parts of the country and the bombings - go on deterring the foreign investors desperately needed by the country.

webTitle: Selma celebrates electing first black mayor

fields.headline: Selma celebrates electing first black mayor
fields.trailText: The city forever associated with the civil rights voting registration struggle of the sixties finally elected its first black mayor yesterday in what is being hailed as a historic victory.
fields.body:
The city forever associated with the civil rights voting registration struggle of the sixties finally elected its first black mayor yesterday in what is being hailed as a historic victory.

There were celebrations in the streets of Selma, Alabama, last night at the end of the 35-year reign of the man who was mayor when state troopers clubbed and teargassed civil rights marchers.

Joe Smitherman, 70, a former member of the White Citizens' Council and a friend of the segregationist governor George Wallace, conceded defeat to local businessman James Perkins Jr after the bitterest campaignfor many years. There were allegations of ballot fraud and fire-bombing and civil rights campaigners from across the country including Martin Luther King III, arrived in the city to bring out the vote in what was seen as a symbolic contest.

Mr Perkins took 5,668 votes to Mr Smitherman's 3,712, a winning margin of 60% to 40%. Although around 1,500 absentee ballots, which Mr Smitherman's supporters had been accused of tampering with, had not been counted there were not enough of them to alter the result.

Conceding defeat, Mr Smitherman said he had found he was running against outsiders brought in by political activists.

"It's a very humbling experience," Mr Perkins, a computer consultant, told the Guardian last night. "It's overwhelming to see how much Selma means to the rest of the world. I have spoken with the mayor and he has congratulated me on my campaign and I congratulated him on his time in office. There is no revenge I desire. It is time to make a transition."

In Selma itself the celebrations started as the first news of the results came through.

Supporters of Mr Perkins gathered on the Pettus bridge where marchers had been beaten back by state troopers as they tried to march on the state capital, Montgomery. Those scenes and the murders of four marchers had horrified the US and led to legislation which finally brought equal suffrage for black people.

"Martin Luther King is smiling now," said Lily Brown, who was on the Pettus bridge 35 years ago when the marchers were attacked and was in Memphis with King when he was assassinated not long after. "Glory, hallelujah!"

"Joe is gone," said Joanne Bland, an activist and co-founder of the National Voting Rights Museum in Selma. "The tyranny is dead. Now we can move on and Selma can heal."

Black people make up around 65% of Selma's 14,000 electorate but Mr Smitherman had never been beaten in nine elections. On this occasion he had the endorsement of the black chief of police, the black city clerk and the local Muslim imam.

Jonathan McElvy, the editor of the Selma Times-Journal, which backed Mr Smitherman, said: "The national and international media have kept Selma on the bridge that we crossed in 1965. Since then it's been full steam ahead here and everybody has equal opportunities in this land. But if this is what it takes to get us over the bridge, that's great."

He added: "It's a shame that it takes a national presence to influence the result. As far as history is concerned, everybody will make of it what they want to make of it. The sun will still come up in Selma tomorrow."

fields.headline: Milosevic smears rival as traitor
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Yugoslav government is accusing the opposition candidate in the presidential election on September 24 of being a puppet working for paid Nato stooges. Its latest poster on the walls of Belgrade shows Vojislav Kostunica as a puppet Pinocchio figure standing in front of an alliance flag.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav government is accusing the opposition candidate in the presidential election on September 24 of being a puppet working for paid Nato stooges. Its latest poster on the walls of Belgrade shows Vojislav Kostunica as a puppet Pinocchio figure standing in front of an alliance flag.

Critics say President Slobodan Milosevic's campaign is running out of ideas. It is certainly exploiting old themes.

The key theme of his Socialist party (SPS) is the slogan of the party congress earlier this year: Obnova, Razvoj, Reforme (reconstruction, progress and reform).

Radomir Vukovic, director of the design company Gras, says that in previous campaigns, the regime hired leading western companies to do their advertising.

This time, he says, the party's main campaign message is: "We don't have enough time to run a campaign, we are rebuilding the country."

An advertisement on state television for the Yugoslav United Left party, led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, plays strongly on the Nato stooge theme, suggesting that opponents of the regime attracted the Nato bombing raids.

Natasa Milojevic, head of the creative team for the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, the coalition of 18 opposition parties which is fielding Mr Kostunica as its presidential candidate, says the regime's leaders began a year ago to portray themselves as patriots rebuilding the country after the bombing, using the state-controlled media as an important part of their strategy.

On Tuesday President Milosevic appeared on the campaign trail for the first time, opening a hydroelectric dam, Djerdap II, on the border with Romania.

His speech was spread across the front of the state newspaper Politika yesterday and dominated state television news. They said he addressed a crowd of 100,000, but non-government newspapers put the number at 10,000.

The president's public appearances are not announced in advance and foreign and non-government journalists only learn of such events after they happen.

Taking up his theme of reconstruction, Mr Milosevic said: "This generation really has something to leave to the generation to come - a 10- year resistance to violence, strongly expressed national solidarity and courageous ability to cope in difficult times."

Then, in an apparent attempt to steal the clothes of opposition leaders who work with the west, he turned to Europe.

"Europe is here," he said. "It started its life here. It struggled with it here. It started to be united here. Here, east and west decided to find a common language."

The regime's charge of collusion with the west sticks poorly on Mr Kostunica. He condemned the Nato bombing, has used strong anti-US rhetoric and has a record of nationalism. The polls consistently show him ahead.

Mr Milosevic's followers include many pensioners and country people and a campaign video featuring a beautiful woman in a field of corn singing My Serbia and happy people in traditional settings is clearly is designed to appeal to them.

One of the challenges to the opposition is to mobilise undecided voters: pollsters say a high turnout will be in its favour.

Mr Kostunica's campaign exploits the feature most people see in him: his integrity. His best known advert shows just his eyes, in monochrome, with the words: "Who can look you in the eye? Kostunica."

With typical panache the federal information minister Goran Matic , said the eyes were not Mr Kostunica's but Al Pacino's.

The next day posters appeared showing the whole of his face, with the slogan: "Who speaks in the name of all of us? ... Kostunica of course."

Milosevic supporters have stuck Nato stickers over the eyes and a wag has added to the slogan the words "... and says nothing."

webTitle: Bill gets bit part in sex pest case

fields.headline: Bill gets bit part in sex pest case
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton was named in a sexual harassment case yesterday, but this time he can face the cameras and swear truthfully that he never touched her. He just happened to be president at the time.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton was named in a sexual harassment case yesterday, but this time he can face the cameras and swear truthfully that he never touched her. He just happened to be president at the time.

The alleged culprit on this occasion is the president's pastry chef, Roland Mesnier, who is being sued by his assistant, Franette McColoch, for "severe sexual harassment".

Mr Clinton is mentioned because Ms McColoch's lawyers claim that as her employer he failed to ensure that there was a complaints procedure in place.

Ms McColoch says that when she complained to her superiors she was "deliberately misled" into believing there was no way of pursuing her claim: that she had no legal recourse and would have to put up with Mr Mesnier's attentions or leave her job making cakes and biscuits for the leader of the free world.

The case could cost Mr Clinton, who is already burdened with legal fees from the Monica Lewinsky affair, up to $1m (about £714,000).

Ms McColoch is claiming $1m in damages from Mr Mesnier, who she said made unwanted advances and demanded to know why she would not have sex with him.

Once spurned, she said, he was "hostile and rude" to her at work, and left dozens of messages on her answering machine.

Although the president has only a walk-on role, the case will undoubtedly add anecdotal weight to his enemies' portrayal of the Clinton White House as a den of licentiousness.

fields.headline: McDonald's attacker jailed for 3 months
fields.trailText: A French court yesterday sentenced José Bové, the sheep farmer who has become a figurehead of the world anti-globalisation movement, to three months in prison for vandalising a McDonald's restaurant.
fields.body:
A French court yesterday sentenced José Bové, the sheep farmer who has become a figurehead of the world anti-globalisation movement, to three months in prison for vandalising a McDonald's restaurant.

The court in Millau, where Mr Bové and nine fellow activists ransacked a half-built McDonald's last year in protest at punitive American import duties on traditional French produce like the roquefort cheese he produces, handed down two-month suspended sentences to three other protesters.

The verdict means Mr Bové, 47, could spend two months in prison since he had already served nearly a month before being released on bail. The sentence was tougher than the 10 months, with nine months suspended, originally demanded by the state prosecutor.

Mr Bové, who was allowed to leave the court pending an appeal, said he was not surprised by the severity of the sentence, but added that he would continue his work in the meantime. "The fight will go on," he said. "The attack on McDonald's was justified and if I have to go to jail, that's not a problem for me."

The pipesmoking, moustachioed activist, who became an international figure during the popular anti-globalisation protests that disrupted the World Trade Organisation talks in Seattle last November, was greeted with cheers by some 200 supporters who waited outside the courthouse.

His two-day trial in June drew some 15,000 assorted ecologists, small farmers and anti-capitalists from around the world for a "festive protest happening" that for two days transformed the sleepy southern town into what protesters dubbed Seattle-sur-Tarn.

Mr Bové, who had just returned from a lecture tour of the United States and was planning a trip to India next week, has become a hugely popular media figure in France, where his campaign against la malbouffe - lousy food - and in favour of healthy, non-industrial food and fair trade for the world's small farmers has struck a chord after a number of highly publicised food scares.

webTitle: New York tunes in for Hillary's TV debate

fields.headline: New York tunes in for Hillary's TV debate
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton's historic attempt to win a seat in the US Senate went into top gear yesterday as she and her Republican rival Rick Lazio held the first of three televised debates.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton's historic attempt to win a seat in the US Senate went into top gear yesterday as she and her Republican rival Rick Lazio held the first of three televised debates.

As many as 80% of New York's 13.5m voters were expected to watch the hour-long debate in Buffalo, as was President Clinton, who was due to tune in at the White House after helping to tutor his wife for the first major election debate of her career.

More than 120 American reporters were on hand for the event.

Despite the millions of dollars already spent on months of campaigning in the state, last night's debate was the first occasion on which the contenders have had the opportunity to compete face-to-face for the voters' attention.

"She's ready. She knows what she has to do. She's excited," said an adviser who had been testing Mrs Clinton with questions,

Mr Lazio, meanwhile, was said to be mugging up his voting record in the House of Representatives, where he has been a Long Island representative since 1992.

Mr Clinton "dropped in and out" of his wife's all-day practice sessions on Tuesday, a White House spokesman said.

The debate took place less than 24 hours after Mrs Clinton's attempt to become the first First Lady to achieve elected office was confirmed by her party's nomination in a primary run-off against a previously unknown Manhattan surgeon.

With 97% of the votes counted in Tuesday's Democratic primary - a contest so inconspicuous that it barely registered even in New York - Mrs Clinton had 82% and Mark McMahon 18%.

The fact that almost one in five Democrats voted for an unknown against the most famous woman politician in the US suggests that Mrs Clinton still faces an uphill task persuading some of the voters whose support she needs.

The presidential couple cast their votes in a school in Chappaqua, their home in the state. Their daughter Chelsea, who is attending the opening of the Olympic Games in Sydney, cast a postal ballot for her mother.

"I voted for myself for the very first time and I was very excited," Mrs Clinton said as she emerged from the voting booth.

"After all these years of her helping me, it was a thrill," Mr Clinton told reporters.

Mrs Clinton's campaign received a boost from two statewide polls yesterday, which both showed her leading Mr Lazio, who won the Republican primary unopposed.

She led Mr Lazio by five points, 49 to 44%, among likely voters in a Quinnipiac University poll. In a separate Marist Institute poll, her lead among likely voters was narrower, 48% to 46%.

Both polls show a slight strengthening of her position in the contest compared with previous surveys.

An important factor in Mrs Clinton's stronger showing seems to be her big lead among Jewish voters, who make up 12% of the state's electorate. She has a two-to-one lead, 61% to 30%, according to a new survey of Jewish voters.

Most of the poll was taken before the publication this week of a photograph showing Mr Lazio shaking hands with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Mrs Clinton will be looking for a further boost among Jewish voters when she campaigns for the first time with the party's vice-presidential nominee Joe Lieberman, who is an orthodox Jew, in New York tomorrow.

Mrs Clinton's supporters said yesterday that they believe the polls underestimated her lead because the probable turn-out of the predominantly Democratic black voters is expected to be higher than usual this year.

The tightness of the Senate race contrasts with the latest New York state poll on the presidential election, in which the Democrat Al Gore leads the Republican George W Bush by 60% to 31%.

This year's New York Senate race is certain to break all previous records for political fundraising for a single state contest.

With more than $60m already budgeted by the two candidates, spending in the Clinton-Lazio contest dwarfs the previous spending record of $44 million in the 1994 California senate race between the Democrat Dianne Feinstein and her Republican challenger Michael Huffington.

fields.headline: Waitresses' war on heels
fields.trailText: The cocktail waitresses of the Nevada casinos are finally putting their feet down. Tired of dressing up in skimpy costumes and the highest of heels, they have formed an organisation to campaign for more sensible footwear.
fields.body:
The cocktail waitresses of the Nevada casinos are finally putting their feet down. Tired of dressing up in skimpy costumes and the highest of heels, they have formed an organisation to campaign for more sensible footwear.

The Kiss My Foot Coalition has already persuaded casinos in Reno to allow them to lower their heels.

The waitresses complain that the nights of serving gamblers while perched on high heels have given many bunions or hammertoes and has left some requiring knee surgery.

Now the coalition, led by a cocktail waitress, Kricket Martinez, is trying to persuade the Las Vegas casinos to follow suit.

"Men waiters don't have to wear high heels - just women," Ms Martinez told the Los Angeles Times. "We're trying to tell casinos where women are walking around in bustiers and thongs that they don't have to endanger the safety of their employees just because someone says sex sells and high heels are sexy."

The waitresses have traditionally put up with the uncomfortable costumes and the gropes of the gamblers because the tips can be even higher than the hated heels.

But the mood in Nevada has changed over the last few years: workers at the casinos and hotels are being unionised as fast as any industry in the US and the city governments in Reno and Las Vegas have been trying to make their hotels appeal more to the family and less to the Family.

But some things have not changed and that is why Ms Martinez and her colleagues are taking action.

The coalition is now planning a public rally in Las Vegas to gain public support for their stance.

If this fails they may look at using equal rights legislation to press their case, on the grounds that men are not required to wear costumes that endanger their health in the same way.

webTitle: Tragedy at the opera:  A tradition dies as La Scala evicts its balcony critics

fields.headline: Tragedy at the opera:  A tradition dies as La Scala evicts its balcony critics
fields.trailText: Opera lovers are mourning the end of an era: La Scala has abolished its standing-room-only balconies, traditional home to fans whose catcalls or cheers could dictate a show's fate.
fields.body:
Opera lovers are mourning the end of an era: La Scala has abolished its standing-room-only balconies, traditional home to fans whose catcalls or cheers could dictate a show's fate.

Protesters are holding candle-lit vigils and collecting signatures outside the Milan theatre to try to save a feature that terrified some performers.

Administrators said the rear of the plush gilt balconies on the first and second floors violated safety codes. Into these loggione 200 poor but ardent fans used to squeeze for the equivalent of £3.50 each. Seat prices at La Scala range from £18 to £1,000.

The loggionisti are upset at missing not only this week's season opener, Puccini's La Boheme, but also the theatre's coming celebrations of the work of Giuseppe Verdi on the centenary of his death.

Seats are likely to be installed in the standing areas during renovation of the theatre, which is more than 200 years old. During the revamp, which is due to start next year and to be completed in 2003, the loggione will be empty.

Fans used to queue for hours for the last-minute tickets. A performance judged sub-standard was the cue for voluble criticism. Luciano Pavarotti and the American soprano Renee Fleming have been among the star targets.

"Knowing there are people who can destroy you listening in the gallery, well, for the singers it feels a lot like going to the front in the middle of a battle," an unnamed performer told the New York Times. But another said it gave a special excitement to La Scala.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Out Of Sight | Boiling Point | Ponette | That Obscure Object Of Desire
fields.body:
Out Of Sight

(Steven Soderbergh, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

This hip and witty thriller brought indie star Soderbergh sauntering into the mainstream. Scriptwriter Scott Frank, who also did Get Shorty, plots an intricate path through Elmore Leonard's twisty novel, and hangs on to the master's snappy dialogue. Meanwhile George Clooney's bank robber and Jennifer Lopez's federal marshal fizz with odd-couple chemistry; Ving Rhames is dead cool as Clooney's partner in crime, and Michael Keaton and Samuel L Jackson appear, unannounced. Outta sight.

Boiling Point

(James B Harris, 1992) 10.10pm, UK Gold

This comes on like a big action movie but simmers more gently, thanks to the well-drawn characters. Wesley Snipes is a treasury agent seeking vengeance after the death of his partner, his path crossing and recrossing that of Dennis Weaver's likeable crook, whose psychotic buddy (Viggo Mortensen) did the deed.

Ponette

(Jacques Doillon, 1996)

11.40pm, FilmFour

Ponette is a four-year-old girl whose mother has just died in a car accident. Her father (Xavier Beauvois) goes away on business, and the girl's left in the country with aunt Claire Nebout and her children to come to terms with death and absence. A touching and perceptive film: Victoire Thivisol, aged four, won best actress award at Venice.

That Obscure Object Of Desire

(Luis Buñuel, 1977)

3.30am, FilmFour

In which Fernando Rey undergoes ritual humiliation at the hands of a beautiful woman. His wealthy Mathieu is aroused by Spanish maid Conchita, a maddening mix of passion and untouchable virginity who turns him into love's buffoon. It's a fine Buñuelian conceit to have two actresses playing her, Angelina Molina hot, Carole Bouquet cool. Set against a backdrop of terrorism, there's a hard satirical centre to the hilarious sex games.

webTitle: Dot.com dodges give Latin lovers a network of alibis

fields.headline: Dot.com dodges give Latin lovers a network of alibis
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: His women friends were cheating on their husbands but needed plausible excuses, so Raul Tello came up with a hi-tech solution: an internet site that provides all the excuses for a four-star affair.
fields.body:
His women friends were cheating on their husbands but needed plausible excuses, so Raul Tello came up with a hi-tech solution: an internet site that provides all the excuses for a four-star affair.

As a web page designer Mr Tello had all the tools to provide an anonymous communications network that would allow for Argentina's lovers to make elaborate getaways.

"We design invitations to conferences, provide the airline tickets and send the invitation to the client," said Mr Tello, the founder of www.amorios.com.ar.

"After the conference they receive certificates of attendance and if necessary, invitations to a follow-up conference," he added.

Despite an economic slump that has hammered most small businesses in Argentina, the affair-planning business appears to be recession-proof. In the first 60 days, Mr Tello grossed £25,000 and signed up 300 clients.

For an annual fee of£40, the clients receive a coded card with their "identity" and an email password. The website has a complete package deal that can be used to convince not only the unsuspecting spouse but also the boss that the unfaithful party is away on business.

"We put a lot of effort into convincing the client's supervisor that this is a business trip," Mr Tello said.

However, Amorios.com is only capable of taking on 1,000 clients. The logistics of planning an affair in Argentina are particularly complicated because so many people suspect their partners of infidelity.

Cover trails are laid in elaborate detail. For example, should a suspicious spouse call the "conference", someone playing a secretary in the Amorio offices will grab the corresponding mobile telephone and read an appriopriate script. Background noise is then blasted over the office loudspeakers to simulate the atmosphere of a conference.

The caller is told that their spouse "just stepped out" and the lover is contacted and told to phone home straight away.

With more than a dozen phones spread out on the desk, the margin for error increases with the number of scripts, sound effect tapes and new personnel.

Mr Tello insists that there have been no major errors but some would argue it is only a matter of time before the wife of a doctor at the Mexican "engineering conference" is played the tape of the Brazilian nurses' association. "With Amorios, there will be no failures, we study every case thoroughly," Mr Tello said.

The clients of Amorios.com are equally divided between the sexes. "I don't care if it is women with women, men with men, whatever. People who are unfaithful will be so with or without Amorios, I am just providing an excuse, nothing more."

Due to the interest from other South American nations, Amorios.com hopes to expand into Uruguay and Peru. "We aren't sure whether to franchise this or do it ourselves, but the number of calls from Peru is huge," Mr Tello said.

But his biggest market may never be realised - in neighbouring Brazil extra-marital affairs are so common that excuses are often unnecessary.

webTitle: Work in progress: Barry Sonnenfeld, director

fields.headline: Work in progress: Barry Sonnenfeld, director
fields.trailText: I was so disappointed with the way Sony released Men In Black on video that I've probably got more involved than they'd like with its DVD release. I've had a hand in most aspects of it, from checking the colour timing to seeking out new features and even appearing in it (kind of) with Tommy Lee Jones in a visual commentary track.
fields.body:
I was so disappointed with the way Sony released Men In Black on video that I've probably got more involved than they'd like with its DVD release. I've had a hand in most aspects of it, from checking the colour timing to seeking out new features and even appearing in it (kind of) with Tommy Lee Jones in a visual commentary track.

On that, I'm armed with a device called a telestrater - it's like one of those video pointers they use on sports shows. I'm using it to point out aliens and other interesting stuff and I believe this is the first time this has been done on a DVD. I love the format and wanted to make the best possible release at the best possible value for money. I don't know what it's like in Britain but in the States the quality of prints in cinemas is shockingly bad. It's pretty sad that the best way to view a movie is in your own home on a DVD.

I'm already hearing a lot of rumours about Men In Black 2, like we have script problems and so on. Well, we don't (the script, incidentally, is being done by Robert Gordon, who did Galaxy Quest). No, what the production hinges on is the money and getting Tommy Lee. You'd think that after such a big hit, the money people would be a bit more forthcoming, but that doesn't seem to be the case.

At the moment I'm down in Miami shooting Big Trouble. It's written by local journalist Dave Barry and I guess you could describe it as Get Shorty-like. I'm here with a great fun cast including Tim Allen, Rene Russo, Janeanne Garofolo, Tom Sizemore, Jack Black and Heavy D. You know, sometimes work just doesn't seem like work...

Men In Black is now available to buy on DVD (Columbia TriStar)

Interview by Phelim O'Neill
