fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which of these Perrier-nominated comics will appear in a big-screen release before the end of 2001?
fields.trailText: Which of these Perrier-nominated comics will appear in a big-screen release before the end of 2001?
fields.body:
Lee Mack 9-4

Dave Gorman 5-1

Gareth Marenghi 5-1

Sean Lock 7-1

This year's Perrier Award winner Rich Hall has already appeared in three films. What chance do his fellow nominees have of following him onto the big screen?

Lee Mack could capitalise on his media-savvy show and the natural talent he displayed in two series of Channel 4's Gas to push his way into the movies. And he certainly understands marketing, if the big poster campaign at Edinburgh is anything to go by. "He has to be favourite with me," says Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, Sean Boyce, "because of his breadth of skills and experience. He's a solid all-rounder with an already established profile making him a live runner."

Dave Gorman , whose latest show involved finding other Dave Gormans across the globe, has a sackful of TV credits. Having appeared on The Comedy Network (C5) and The Stand Up Show (BBC1), he's also worked as associate producer on Jenny Eclair Squats and Private Function (C5), and as a script editor on The 11 O'Clock Show (C4). "The fact that he's already been involved with plenty of TV work makes him a contender, but I fancy he's more likely to go down the documentary route."

Newcomer Gareth Marenghi gained a lot of attention for his spoof of the horror genre at Edinburgh this year. As a result he's been snapped up by big-guns management company Avalon. "He's a long shot on the face of it, but so would Lee Evans have been a few years ago. Like Evans he has a quirky and recognisable style that could be useful in a film. Some hope, then," says Sean.

Rather like old Perrier nominee Sean Hughes in manner, Sean Lock trades in free associative humour, and avoids showbiz front. "I don't know if this guy can act, but if he's willing to be himself on film he's in with a shout. Strange and whimsical, yet likeable and engaging - a part could easily be tailored in Hollywood."

Interview by Jennifer Rodger

fields.headline: Gay abandon
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: As explanations for lesbianism go, an overactive thyroid is new to me. Yet that's what Chris, a lorry driver from Hayes in Middlesex thought was the most likely explanation for his wife Ange's crossing to the other side.
fields.body:
As explanations for lesbianism go, an overactive thyroid is new to me. Yet that's what Chris, a lorry driver from Hayes in Middlesex thought was the most likely explanation for his wife Ange's crossing to the other side. "Can someone fake a relationship for 16 years?" he asked in When A Wife Loves A Woman (C4). "I don't think so." So, Chris maintained, there must be a medical explanation for Ange leaving him for Kaz, losing her perm and gaining an eyebrow piercing. And verrucas at an early age make men gay. Obviously.

Giving Chris his credit, however, he was the only husband to take part in the documentary and, as such, his contributions, and those of the women's very sensible children, lent it gravitas, balance and, it has to be said, some weight that otherwise would have been sadly lacking. Adam, for example, was quite happy his mum's face wasn't as "droopy" as it used to be (though how his mum's facial muscles had been tightened, one would hope he didn't yet know). Toni and Hayley meanwhile were quite uninterested in their mum's sexual proclivities. "She can be a lesbian if she wants," Hayley said in the same way she might had Ange confessed to a love for line dancing.

What When A Wife Loves A Woman proved - and this is probably a good thing - is that lesbians are just ordinary and not necessarily intrinsically interesting.

Some, like Steph and Jane, are middle-class. They drink red wine, eat spinach and have cats. They cuddle on their sofa and have a jolly nice back garden. When they first left their husbands for each other, they were, as we say in Scotland, the talk of the steamie. "We're far too juicy not to talk about", said one in a saucy moment.

Other lesbians, like Ange and Kaz, aren't middle-class at all. They have horrible duvet covers, children with nits and Jack Russells. Still, Ange and Kaz said they loved each other - and that's all that matters - although Kaz wouldn't let Ange go too deep and confessed she might go back to men, but "only for a screw". In the end, they went to Clacton, which is as happy an ending as you can expect these days.

Kaz could do worse than ask the lads from DIY SOS Summer Special (BBC1) for a screw, since they have hefty toolboxes full of everything you'd ever need. Nick Knowles was in Ebbw Vale building a youth theatre group a rehearsal room, while Lowri the wide-mouthed frog was in Stalybridge outside Manchester renovating a Scout Hut, both to a four-day time limit. So far, so Challenge Anneka, but, in what's perhaps an indication that I'm getting soft in my old age, it was rather touching to see Nick and his team crying (in a good way) when the theatre group did a performance for them. Ah, bless.

If there's something more snigger-inducing for the immature among us than thinking about lady-on-lady sex, it's thinking about old people having sex. Modern Times: Falling In Love... Again (BBC2) explored the whole notion of older people falling in love both straight-forwardly and sensitively, seriously but with just the right amount of humour. From the likes of Lorna, 56, and David, 70, who had just moved in together and frolicked like giddy teenagers on their new bed, to Harry, 70, who sat in his corner bath drinking Moët and scouring the personal ads for a slim, attractive lady with a GSOH, Modern Times once again demonstrated its credentials as the best documentary strand on television which explores contemporary Britain. The stories of all the contributors were told simply but to moving effect.

It must be disconcerting being a friend of a telly chef. You'd get a call inviting you to dinner - "Nothing fancy, just a bowl of pasta and a bit of salad" - so you'd turn up in a pasta and salad kind of outfit and there would be a camera crew, lenses poised to capture every detail of you eating dinner. After Jamie, Nigella and Gary, whose casual throwing together of meals for friends foster inadequacy in those of us who can't produce delicious dinners in five minutes flat, comes Ainsley, specifically Ainsley's Gourmet Express (BBC2). Only Ainsley goes off the rails with vomit-inducing camera work, and, cooking alone in his kitchen, as much charisma as a limp lettuce. Like the tree which falls in the forest with no one to hear it, he desperately needs an audience. Without other people with whom to banter, he can't hope to compete with the Nigella Pullman over on platform four.

fields.headline: The big Bangs theory
fields.standfirst: In the 70s, rock'n'roll was about freedom. Free records. Free love. Free drugs. But, as rock critic Lester Bangs knew all too well, there's no such thing as a free lunch. As yet more music hacks invade our movies and TV shows,  Clark Collis reports
fields.trailText: In the 70s, rock'n'roll was about freedom. Free records. Free love. Free drugs. But, as rock critic Lester Bangs knew all too well, there's no such thing as a free lunch. As yet more music hacks invade our movies and TV shows, Clark Collis reports
fields.body:
If he were alive today, legendary rock writer Lester Bangs would be 51 years old. Instead, in 1982, he ingested a cocktail of Valium, a painkiller called Darvon and his usual massive dose of cough syrup, passed out and never woke up. Which was perhaps just as well. Possibly the only rock commentator with sufficient nous to clock the precise moment when his beloved music scene became the despised music industry, Bangs would be truly appalled at the state of rock'n'roll today, with its press junkets, promo videos and multi-million-dollar marketing campaigns.

The ghost of Lester Bangs rises again this week with the Stateside release of Cameron Crowe's semi-autobiographical rock fable Almost Famous, a heady (road) trip back to the early 70s, when Crowe was a wide-eyed 15-year-old kid writing Led Zeppelin cover features for Rolling Stone magazine. Bangs was a friend and mentor to the young Crowe, and his presence in the film - played with low-key brilliance by the laconic Philip Seymour Hoffman - is that of a bluff elder statesman, dropping pearls of wisdom hard won through years of experience. "God," he drawls, "it's going to get ugly. They'll buy you drinks, you'll meet girls... they'll try to fly you places for free... offer you drugs... I know, it sounds great. But they're not your friends. These are people who want you to write sanctimonious stories about the genius of rock stars, and they'll ruin rock'n'roll and strangle everything we love about it."

Bangs had been fretting about the future of rock for some years prior to his death. In 1974 he penned a piece for Shakin' Street Gazette entitled How To Be A Rock Critic, offering a blunt guide to would-be music writers. "You'll get to hobnob with the stars", he conceded, but went on to add a string of caveats: "It almost certainly won't get you laid... It doesn't pay much and doesn't lead anywhere in particular."

A quarter of a century on, much of Bangs' rant still holds true. Music journalists do get to hobnob with stars, or at least snatch a few air-conditioned moments with them at a top hotel. And yes, the position of music journalist on rock's sexual totem pole remains somewhere beneath that of roadies, lighting technicians and even drummers. But what dates the piece is Bangs' comment that music journalism "doesn't pay much and doesn't lead anywhere in particular".

True, considering it's a profession largely staffed by white male graduates, the financial benefits are comparatively meagre. But these days, being a music journalist leads anywhere but nowhere. In fact, working for the music press has become the entry level point for Britain's latest generation of media newcomers. Radio One boasts ex-journos in the form of Steve Lamacq and Mary Anne Hobbs. And Andrew Collins and Stuart Maconie - both NME graduates - host their own shows on Radios Four and Five respectively. And that's before you even begin to consider the still sizeable media presence of such earlier pop press toilers as Tony Parsons, Bob Geldof, Paul Morley, Neil Tennant and, of course, Julie Burchill.

It's a situation that's been more than mirrored in the States. Look no further than former Creem writer Nick Tosches, Bangs' one-time peer, who's established himself as the finest biographer at work today, with peerless books on Dean Martin and, most recently, Sonny Liston. Anyone still not convinced should consider the career of Hollywood's resident not-so-enfant terrible Joe Eszterhas who, like Crowe, first gained widespread recognition in the early 70s for his work at Rolling Stone.

But in those days the phrase "career progression" was far from anybody's mind. "We'd do a story about corrupt narcotics agents," Eszterhas recalls, "and some of the better-known dope dealers in town would pay us homage by handing us gigantic bags of grass. It was their way of saying 'Good story.' Once I got nearly half a shopping bag of the greatest weed in the world from a dealer who was so excited about my new story, he delivered it himself."

Eszterhas's tenure at Rolling Stone coincided with that of Crowe, who had been discovered by Bangs a couple of years before when, unaware of his age, Bangs had commissioned him to write a piece about Humble Pie for Creem. And perhaps more than anyone else, it's Crowe, now one of Hollywood's most acclaimed writers and directors, who has disproved Bang's theory about rock journalism's cul-de-sac-style career curve.

Now 43, Crowe looks back at those years with a mixture of affection and pain, an emotion he describes simply as "happy-sad". In the film, Bangs tells Crowe's alter-ego that the war's over, that rock's becoming a commodity. "They're trying to buy respectability for a form that's gloriously and righteously dumb!" he rages. "And you're smart enough to know that. And the day it ceases to be dumb is the day it ceases to be real. Right? And then it'll just become an Industry Of Cool."

Nearly 30 years later, the Industry is open for business. After all, it's worth remembering that both Clinton and Blair are former rock musicians - it may not be long before ex-rock critics follow their example and start stalking the corridors of power, not the backstage toilets at Glastonbury. God rest his soul, at least Bangs won't be there to witness it.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Up In Flames | The Evening Concert
fields.body:
Author Michael Dibdin adopts the methods of his fictional detective Aurelio Zen to investigate the events of January 29 1996, when the Fenice opera house, one of Europe's finest, was burned to the ground. In true Venetian fashion, as Dibdin reports in Up In Flames (11.30am, Radio 4), scandal and rumour have swirled around the blaze ever since and a former mayor is among those facing trial. No one doubts it was arson, but few think the culprits will ever be unmasked.

The premiere of Elgar's Dream Of Gerontius flopped totally at the Birmingham Triennial Festival 100 years ago. This massive choral setting of Cardinal Newman's reflections on the transition from life to death was dismissed by Delius as "a nauseating work". It's done rather better since, with special centennial performances on offer around the world. The Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) features Vernon Handley conducting the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Choir and Orchestra with the Huddersfield Choral Society.

fields.headline: Brussels backs charter of rights
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: The European commission threw its weight behind a new charter of fundamental rights yesterday, to give a moral dimension to the union.
fields.body:
The European commission threw its weight behind a new charter of fundamental rights yesterday, to give a moral dimension to the union.

Announcing its support, it said the EU had to seek its roots in "fundamental human values common to all European countries".

But the chairman, Romano Prodi, and his team conspicuously refused to say whether the charter should be incorporated into the treaty of Nice, which is due to seal crucial reforms in December, or be left as a non-binding showcase for existing rights.

Britain, suspicious of the charter, has been lobbying hard for it to be just a declaration, fearing that it could be used to create new competences for the EU, feed domestic eurosceptic opinion, and undermine the European convention on human rights.

British officials said they believe the majority of the 15 EU members backed a declaration. But the supporters of a more ambitious charter hope it will be incorporated into a future treaty, perhaps serving as an embryonic constitution.

Antonio Vitorino, the commissioner for justice and home affairs, insisted that there were no plans to use it to give the EU new powers.

"This isn't a theological issue," he said. "You have to look at what's in the text and see whether it adds value or not."

Introduced by Germany last year, the charter was intended to "consolidate" rights already applicable at the EU level, "in order to make their overriding importance and relevance more visible to the union's citizens".

It is being drafted by a unique convention composed, with a rare degree of legitimacy, of 62 representatives of the European parliament and commission and national governments and parliaments.

Andrew Duff, a leading Liberal Democrat MEP, who wants stronger provisions on the right to strike and other key amendments, said last night: "Even the most hostile of prime ministers will find it very difficult to argue that the charter is not worth inclusion in the treaty reform negotiations."

Lord Goldsmith, Tony Blair's representative at the convention, has pressed, with some success, for the deletion of many sections on workers rights, including free collective bargaining and information disclosure.

In a separate development, Neil Kinnock, the commissioner for reform, announced a new code of practice for officials: part of the effort to achieve the highest standards of public service in a bureaucracy still reeling from last year's fraud and incompetence scandals.

"The public has a right to good administration and this is another step in developing a culture based on service which is central to all the reforms," he said.

The code is designed to guide commission staff in their dealings with the public. Offenders can be taken to the European court of justice. It says officials must be "courteous, objective and impartial" in their dealings with the public.

fields.headline: Brainspark 'will make ideas pay'
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Internet incubator Brainspark yesterday announced two new ventures and promised that the value of some of its investments would soon be turned into hard cash.
fields.body:
Internet incubator Brainspark yesterday announced two new ventures and promised that the value of some of its investments would soon be turned into hard cash.

Although losses for the six months to June 30 widened from £373,000 to £5.8m, the company maintained it had enough cash in the bank to survive for more than two years before it had to raise more money.

"We have £14m in the bank which is enough to keep us going for another 26 months," chief executive Stewart Dodd said. "However we are actively working on ways to realise the value of some of our investments.

"One of our firms is set to IPO [float shares], another is negotiating a trade sale and a third is closing a new investment round in which we will probably sell some of our shares. I'm very confident and excited about the months ahead."

Mr Dodd, who was one of the original incubators in highly-rated, Cambridge-based, technology company Zeus, said Brainspark also plans to open a new incubator branch in the area to help nurture similar young companies.

"We think we can add significant value to guys who have great ideas and technology but not much of an idea about how to run the financial side of their business," he said.

The Cambridge branch will focus on wireless internet technology and will be set up jointly with Diamond Technology Partners, a consultancy firm. The centre is likely to cost about £10m, with funding coming from large wireless companies.

It's existing investments include fulfilment company Metapack, which is understood to have just won a contract with a large retail group, and Petspark, a pets portal that is likely to be sold to a bricks and mortar retailer. Mr Dodd said several of his investee e-commerce firms would be encouraged to forge links with retail chains with established distribution networks.

Brainspark's nearest rivals are Antfactory and Speedventures. All three specialise in aiding the development of young technology companies. However, "incubator" has become a dirty word among investors following the collapse in the share price of several firms that floated earlier in the year promising to take stakes in internet firms and help them grow.

Brainspark's share price has proved more resilient and last night closed up 9.5 p at 104.5p.

fields.headline: Notes and queries
fields.standfirst: Legalising and decriminalising * Locating the Near East * When the wine flows free
fields.trailText: What's the difference between legalising something and de-criminalising it?
fields.body:
What's the difference between legalising something and de-criminalising it?

* Not much. Actively repealing a law which prohibits something, decriminalises it - an example was the extension of Sunday trading by shops. By contrast, legalising something might either clarify the law where it was previously unclear - the finance acts following the budget usually both create tax exemptions and limit avoidance schemes - or introduce or extend rights, such as abortion, women's suffrage and the reduction in voting age from 21 to 18.

Examples of confusion, discrimination and misconceptions in this area are commonplace. Sex between men is still seen by the common law (case law developed over the ages by judges) as a crime of "gross indecency". It is decriminalised in only limited circumstances - the men must be 18 or over, there must never be more than two involved and it must be within a very tight definition of privacy, none of which restrictions apply to sex between women and men. Notwithstanding the recent House of Lords rejections of reform, this will not long survive decisions of the European Court nor the Human Rights Act which is about to come into force south of the Scottish border (it is already enshrined in Scottish law).

Another distinction to be made is between actual decriminalisation by law change and the practice of enforcement by the authorities. Contrary to popular belief, Dutch law still criminalises possession and dealing in recreational drugs such as cannabis. In practice certain premises - coffee shops - are licensed by councils for the purchase and consumption of small amounts; similarly in the UK it is a crime to exceed the speed limits but prosecution is rare even if the 30mph limit, for example, is exceeded by around one third. Charges of corporate manslaughter (eg following the Paddington rail disaster) are similarly exceptional.

Chris Morley, Woodhouse, Leeds.

We have "the Middle East" and "the Far East", but where is "the Near East"? And what should we call the area which covers India, Bangladesh, Nepal, etc?

* "Near East" is the old name for Asia between Turkey and India (ie the area west of the pride of the British Empire). After the second world war, a more precise name was needed, so Israel and neighbouring Arab countries became known as the "Middle East". Of course, it all depends where you are standing. Many years ago, on my first visit to India, I was surprised to hear All India Radio talking about the crisis in "West Asia" - the Middle East from their standpoint. "South Asia" is the name given to the sub-Indian subcontinent, plus Nepal, Sri Lanka, etc, to distinguish it from South-East Asia, formerly Indo-China.

Mike Broadbent, Luton, Beds.

*In the days before British military withdrawal from east of Suez, the RAF had three separate eastern commands: Far East Air Force; Air Force Middle East and Near East Air Force. The last comprised, from what I recollect, bases on Cyprus, Malta and Gibraltar. NEAF HQ was based at RAF Episcopi, Cyprus. The building is still in use but has been re-designated as HQ Joint Services.

Tony Cummings (ret. squadron leader), Hough Green, Chester.

My butcher told me not to worry about wasps crawling over the meat in his shop, saying "they're completely germ free, they don't spread anything." Was he right?

* Before turning up in the shop, wasps are likely to have spent time either on the dead cat in the gutter, the mouldy apple cores and bits of ham sandwich in the litter bin or the cowpat in the meadow. They carry bacteria on their feet and bodies from these to the prime cuts in the butcher's window.

Flies and bluebottles do this more visibly by disgorging digestive fluid onto their food to soften it up and also lay eggs (hence maggots) in it - but wasps are just as good at mere germ distribution. Basic hygiene training for butchers seems a good idea.

Robina Barson, London NW5.

On the eastbound carriageway three miles west of M4 junction 13 is a large exit labelled Works Access Only. It leads to a road, not marked on any map, that disappears over a hill. The millennium map on the internet shows a large array of rectangular structures. Is it anything I should worry about?

* Locals maintain that this slip road leads to RAF Welford, which was used as a base by the US during the cold war. This would explain the rectangular shapes on the millennium map - they are missile silos.

My mother, who lives near Newbury, has always maintained that the cruise missiles, allegedly at nearby Greenham Common, were in fact based at Welford. This would make sense, if only in terms of transport logistics. Cruise missiles were designed to be mobile and capable of being launched from any part of the country. To reach the M4 from Greenham (in the 80s) necessitated driving through Newbury, whereas Welford has its own private slip road.

Perhaps all the women who so persistently protested against the cruise missiles were actually camping in the wrong place after all.

Jackie Nickson, Farncombe, Surrey .

*Many Access Only roads are in fact motorway police stations and garages. A couple of years ago, I was given a lift to Luton Airport by a Met police detective. He swung off the motorway on to one of these roads promising that it would take many miles off the journey - which it did. Some way up this road, there were rectangular structures, an array of parked police vehicles and officers relaxing with tea and fags. Anyone wishing to try these shortcuts, however, should be advised that you need someone in the car who can show a warrant card.

Graham White, Milton Bridge, Midlothian.

History books often refer to "fountains flowing with wine" during major celebrations. Is there any credible account of how these fountains were operated, or was the term merely an overblown way of saying that drinks were free?

* At the opening of the Melbourne International Exhibition (1880-81) by the Marquis of Normanby the fountains outside the purpose-built Royal Exhibition Building in the Carlton Gardens flowed with pink champagne. During the ceremonies, which included the performance of an interminable exhibition cantata, everybody waiting outside got drunk and rioting ensued. Buckets of pink champagne were carried off to the suburbs. I do not think similar hospitalities have since been attempted in Melbourne.

Angus Trumble, Art Gallery of South Australia, Adelaide.

* For centuries Exeter's citizen's were supplied with drinking water by a public conduit, an impressive edifice with taps, situated in the centre of the city at the Carfax. On special occasions, such as the visit by Henry VI in 1452 and the coronation of William and Mary in 1689, the conduit ran with wine. This was achieved by inserting a hogshead of claret behind the spout.

Hazel Harvey, Exeter.

*The town of Marino, near Rome, still has such a fountain. During the Sagra dell'Uva, at the grape harvest in August, the celebrated Fountain of the Moors in the main square is decorated with bunches of grapes, and pumps out wine instead of water. We used to join in the scrum to fill glasses, carafes and gerry-cans with the very drinkable local produce. Economic considerations mean that this free-for-all lasts only about an hour, but I am told that in the past it lasted several days.

Mark Langham, Bayswater, London W2.

Any answers?

Given that space is infinite and we are the only inhabitants of the universe, why don't we dump toxic and nuclear waste into space?

Paul Cockburn, London SW6.

Why did men of fashion in the 18th century wear shoes with scarlet heels? Was it a mark of rank?

Angus Trumble, Adelaide, Australia.

How did delicate creatures like jellyfish, or soft-skinned vertebrates such as amphibians, survive the environmental catastrophe said to have caused the mass extinctions at the time the dinosaurs died out?

Clare Passingham, Oxford.

Why are teeth thought worthy of a separate medical profession, when all other parts of the body are looked after by specialist doctors?

Phil Woodford, Teddington, Middx.

Why is it that, even with today's complex technology, the camera is still said to "put 10lbs on you"? And will this problem ever be solved?

L Gunby, Sheffield.

We include the letter 'u' in the spelling of the numbers 4, 14 and 400. Why is forty different?

Graham Hales, Mickleover, Derby.

fields.bodyText: What's the difference between legalising something and de-criminalising it? * Not much. Actively repealing a law which prohibits something, decriminalises it - an example was the extension of Sunday trading by shops. By contrast, legalising something might either clarify the law where it was previously unclear - the finance acts following the budget usually both create tax exemptions and limit avoidance schemes - or introduce or extend rights, such as abortion, women's suffrage and the reduction in voting age from 21 to 18. fields.headline: Quotes of the day
fields.trailText:
"I quite like the idea of feeling dirty, cheap and used but, like a good prostitute, I prefer to work for my money"
The irrepressible (ahem) Denise Van Outen on why she won't sell her wedding photos to a glossy mag, Sun
fields.body:
"I quite like the idea of feeling dirty, cheap and used but, like a good prostitute, I prefer to work for my money"
The irrepressible (ahem) Denise Van Outen on why she won't sell her wedding photos to a glossy mag, Sun

"She looked uncomfortable. Her picture did not make for an exciting cover"
A spokesperson for Harper's Bazaar on why they dropped Renee Zellwegger as their cover star after she gained weight while filming Bridget Jones's Diary, Express

"I had to leave London, basically. It's such an English thing that once you've been pigeon-holed as one thing, you'll never be seen as another. I was always the big girl. Even if I slimmed down to a size 4, I'd always be known as the size 14 model. I became this iconic, curvy creature without having much say in the matter. People would come up to me in supermarkets and start discussing my weight with me. I was made the figurehead of this cause which I never asked to join"
Sophie Dahl on why she now lives in New York, Tatler

"I used to hate my body. I detested it. Now I'm shagged out and nearly 40, I love it"
Tracey Emin on her new exhibit, a beach hut complete with photographs of her naked, Independent

"When I was young, one had to get married if one wanted sex"
Muriel Spark on why she rushed into marriage at 19, Evening Standard

" 'I love Kim,' says Mike Hollingsworth about his beautiful blonde 21-year-old girlfriend, 'and it has nothing to do with her age.' Presumably he means he loves her for her mind. So why do middle-aged men never fall for middle-aged women for their minds?"
Lynda Lee-Potter poses the eternal question, Daily Mail

fields.headline: The shock of the nude
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 83: Last Tango in Paris
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 83: Last Tango in Paris
fields.body:
From a court in Bologna that banned Last Tango in Paris: "Obscene content offensive to public decency... presented with obsessive self-indulgence, catering to the lowest instincts of the libido, dominated by the idea of stirring unchecked appetites for sexual pleasure, permeated by scurrilous language... accompanied off screen by sounds, sighs and shrieks of climax pleasure."

If this is scarcely believable, so now is Pauline Kael's New Yorker review: "This must be the most powerfully erotic movie ever made, and it may turn out to be the most liberating movie ever made, and so it's probably only natural that an audience, anticipating a voluptuous feast from the man who made The Conformist, and confronted with this unexpected sexuality, and the new realism it requires of the actors, should go into shock. Bertolucci and Brando have altered the face of an art form. Who was prepared for that?"

The first ban lasted only two months, though an Italian court later had a negative burned, revoked Bertolucci's civil rights for five years and gave him a four-month suspended prison sentence. In Britain, the sodomy sequence had to be cut, presumably so as not to encourage public schoolboys. Kael's 4,000-word review, however, convinced most sceptics that the film was morally serious and a work of art. It is, of course. But there's such a thing as a morally serious bad work of art.

Last Tango is certainly the film that catapulted Bertolucci towards international fame, the story of a middle-aged man, who, devastated by the apparent suicide of his wife, embarks on a purely sexual sadomasochistic affair with a young girl, who, in the end, kills him.

Throughout the film, the girl is naked and the man is not, which caused further controversy. There were two other significant reviews. Molly Haskell pointed out that it was women rather than men who responded to the film. "Our rearguard fantasies of rape, sadism, submission, liberation and anonymous sex are as important a key to our emancipation, our self-understanding, as our more advanced and admirable efforts at self-definition."

Then there was Norman Mailer, who said that the real thrill was the peephole an improvising Brando offered us on Brando.

Maria Schneider, as the girl, was unknown at the time, and Bertolucci, who failed to cast both Dominique Sanda and Catherine Deneuve when they became pregnant, has said he wanted her to be a Lolita but more perverse. He chose Brando after seeing a Francis Bacon painting "of a man in great despair who had the air of total disillusionment". Certainly it is a performance of extraordinary force. Brando's friend Jack Lemmon claims it was based on his childhood, when he decided not to have any relationship in which he was going to "get murdered emotionally".

This may be the key to the film, since the pair play cruel, often childish games with each other in between and even during their sexual bouts. She is a child-woman - "Growing older is a crime," she says - and he is escaping back into childhood. The film's imagery consistently reflects this as well as commenting on ageing and death.

Whether it really indicts the bourgeois family structures that "civilise" the savage in us all is a moot point. But it clearly tries to do so. In the end, however, it seems too melodramatic to be entirely successful and too much of a neat, if shocking, fantasy psychodrama to get near the truth.

But it does prove Brando to be a great screen actor and Bertolucci to be a director capable of the audacity of Godard and the naked power of Bergman.

fields.headline: The oldest singer in town
fields.standfirst: He's 73, registered blind and has just signed his first record deal.  Esther Addley meets Reg Cooper
fields.trailText: He's 73, registered blind and has just signed his first record deal. Esther Addley meets Reg Cooper
fields.body:
You've heard the story before: a slow breakthrough into the music business masquerading as overnight success. Jamming with a few friends, an album put together on a shoestring, a few demos sent out to record companies more in hope than expectation. All motivated by a dream that someone will take a chance on an unknown singer and give him a chance to make music for a living.

This is Reg Cooper's story. The singer has just signed a £300,000 recording contract with an independent label, and his first album of country music, Beautiful Day, will be released next month. The talk now is of TV appearances, a slot on the National Lottery show, perhaps even Top of the Pops.

But Cooper is not your typical wannabe star. For a start, he's 73 years old. He is also so poorly sighted as to be registered blind, and needs a motor scooter to travel any distance because of arthritis. He lives with his wife, who is deaf and also finds it difficult to get around, on a council estate in Stapleford, Nottingham. Country music has thrown up a few incredible stories in its time, but this one gives them all a run for their money.

Born with cataracts and raised partly in an institution, Cooper was later bankrupted when he tried to run a shop with his wife because he could not see the customers. He was reduced to stuffing bristles into brush heads in a home for the blind in order to scrape a living. It was here that he developed his interest in music. "It's a horrible job, making brushes", he says without irony. He suggested the home's users start a band - not that he could sing or play an instrument, "but I was bored". So he took up the guitar and got a cheap piano to mess around on at home.

It seems almost inevitable, as you hear Cooper's life history unfold, that he would be stopped in the street one day by a stranger offering to teach him to sing. The man was a bass baritone who had sung in a Sadler's Wells touring opera.

After four decades playing in folk clubs in and around Nottingham - and five years honing his album to a standard he was happy with - Cooper won a contract from the dance label Cleveland City, which launched an independent imprint on which to release it.

"We received a demo from a friend of a friend, and it caught our ears straight away," says Rob James, CCM's general manager. "We didn't know who he was when we got the record. It was only when we took it a stage further and Reg sent us a quick biography that we realised he was registered blind."

Cooper does not make a drama out of his situation, although it would be difficult to find a richer seam of achy-breaky country heartache. "I have had numerous operations on my eyes throughout my life, but I've decided I'm too old to have any more," he says simply. The cataracts were inherited from his father, and passed on to his daughter. A much-loved son was also lost to cancer.

But it diminishes Cooper to concentrate on his age and disabilities. He may have found fame late in life, but he has been closely involved in the Midlands country scene since the 60s. He is warm and funny, a self-confessed evangelist for country music, even if some of his anecdotes have got a little rambling with age.

They are worth the retelling, all the same. John Denver recorded one of Cooper's songs, Catch Another Butterfly, on his album Rhymes and Reasons after the pair met at a Philadelphia country festival in the late 60s. Hank Snow recorded another, though Cooper says he never got a penny for either because he didn't know he was entitled to anything. He hosted a country show from 1969 until the early 80s on BBC Radio Nottingham and came to meet Willie Nelson, Johnny Cash and Roger Miller. Certainly, he is far from the cheerful elderly ingenu that has been portrayed in some press reports, a chirpy Clive Dunn figure with a flat cap and a northern accent.

Nonetheless, it was inevitable that a blind pensioner finding success in the music industry would be seized on as a role model. The Royal National Institute for the Blind has offered support. Age Concern has declared Cooper "an inspiration" and is urging its 250,000 members to buy a copy of the album.

Cooper doesn't seem to mind being portrayed as a torch-bearer for his generation, but feels it is more important that he is plugging a gap in the market for "well-written, original songs with a melody, which stand on the merits of the words and the tune. There's a very big market of people who can't get hold of the type of music they like to listen to."

He and his wife have to buy records from cable channel QVC, he says, as local music shops don't stock the sort of music he wants to listen to. "A lot of people were brought up on the Crosbys and Sinatras and so on. I thought it was important to bring my songs up to scratch, as people are going to measure me on that level."

Cooper's songs are simple tales of dreams and hopeful endeavour and beautiful days coming. He explains that one track on the album, Singing Gold, was inspired by a Braille book he used to read under the bedclothes in the home in which he lived as a child. It's an odd story to linger in the memory for 60 years - the tale of a couple in Australia who struggled to save enough money to get married, only for the groom to die on the wedding night as he nipped out to buy champagne. Cooper chuckles at the well-worn memory. "But it was the description of the autumn in that story that I loved: orange and brown, rust and gold." He breaks into a few bars.

James is anxious not to package Cooper as a heart-warming gimmick, but knows that he'll struggle to interest mainstream music fans in an album sleeve that shows a grinning pensioner in a flat cap and milk-bottle specs driving his scooter along a Nottingham street. "We've approached major retailers, but, unfortunately, perhaps because of the cover, most of them have not even listened to the record. Universal Records are distributing it, but we still have to transfer that into sales and convince retailers that it's not a novelty act.

"But we have used the sleeve that Reg wanted. We haven't tried to portray him as something he is not. It might not be a normal thing for most record-buyers to drive down the street on a motor scooter, but it's a normal thing if you are Reg Cooper."

Beautiful Day will be released on CCM next month.

The talk now is of TV appearances, a slot on the National Lottery show, perhaps even Top of the Pops. But Cooper is not your typical wannabe star. For a start, he's 73 years old. He is also so poorly sighted as to be registered blind, and needs a motor scooter to travel any distance because of arthritis. He lives with his wife, who is deaf and also finds it difficult to get around, on a council estate in Stapleford, Nottingham. Country music has thrown up a few incredible stories in its time, but this one gives them all a run for their money. Born with cataracts and raised partly in an institution, Cooper was later bankrupted when he tried to run a shop with his wife because he could not see the customers. He was reduced to stuffing bristles into brush heads in a home for the blind in order to scrape a living. It was here that he developed his interest in music. "It's a horrible job, making brushes", he says without irony. He suggested the home's users start a band - not that he could sing or play an instrument, "but I was bored". So he took up the guitar and got a cheap piano to mess around on at home. It seems almost inevitable, as you hear Cooper's life history unfold, that he would be stopped in the street one day by a stranger offering to teach him to sing. The man was a bass baritone who had sung in a Sadler's Wells touring opera. After four decades playing in folk clubs in and around Nottingham - and five years honing his album to a standard he was happy with - Cooper won a contract from the dance label Cleveland City, which launched an independent imprint on which to release it. "We received a demo from a friend of a friend, and it caught our ears straight away," says Rob James, CCM's general manager. "We didn't know who he was when we got the record. It was only when we took it a stage further and Reg sent us a quick biography that we realised he was registered blind." Cooper does not make a drama out of his situation, although it would be difficult to find a richer seam of achy-breaky country heartache. "I have had numerous operations on my eyes throughout my life, but I've decided I'm too old to have any more," he says simply. The cataracts were inherited from his father, and passed on to his daughter. A much-loved son was also lost to cancer. But it diminishes Cooper to concentrate on his age and disabilities. He may have found fame late in life, but he has been closely involved in the Midlands country scene since the 60s. He is warm and funny, a self-confessed evangelist for country music, even if some of his anecdotes have got a little rambling with age. They are worth the retelling, all the same. John Denver recorded one of Cooper's songs, Catch Another Butterfly, on his album Rhymes and Reasons after the pair met at a Philadelphia country festival in the late 60s. Hank Snow recorded another, though Cooper says he never got a penny for either because he didn't know he was entitled to anything. He hosted a country show from 1969 until the early 80s on BBC Radio Nottingham and came to meet Willie Nelson, Johnny Cash and Roger Miller. Certainly, he is far from the cheerful elderly ingenu that has been portrayed in some press reports, a chirpy Clive Dunn figure with a flat cap and a northern accent. Nonetheless, it was inevitable that a blind pensioner finding success in the music industry would be seized on as a role model. The Royal National Institute for the Blind has offered support. Age Concern has declared Cooper "an inspiration" and is urging its 250,000 members to buy a copy of the album. Cooper doesn't seem to mind being portrayed as a torch-bearer for his generation, but feels it is more important that he is plugging a gap in the market for "well-written, original songs with a melody, which stand on the merits of the words and the tune. There's a very big market of people who can't get hold of the type of music they like to listen to." He and his wife have to buy records from cable channel QVC, he says, as local music shops don't stock the sort of music he wants to listen to. "A lot of people were brought up on the Crosbys and Sinatras and so on. I thought it was important to bring my songs up to scratch, as people are going to measure me on that level." Cooper's songs are simple tales of dreams and hopeful endeavour and beautiful days coming. He explains that one track on the album, Singing Gold, was inspired by a Braille book he used to read under the bedclothes in the home in which he lived as a child. It's an odd story to linger in the memory for 60 years - the tale of a couple in Australia who struggled to save enough money to get married, only for the groom to die on the wedding night as he nipped out to buy champagne. Cooper chuckles at the well-worn memory. "But it was the description of the autumn in that story that I loved: orange and brown, rust and gold." He breaks into a few bars. James is anxious not to package Cooper as a heart-warming gimmick, but knows that he'll struggle to interest mainstream music fans in an album sleeve that shows a grinning pensioner in a flat cap and milk-bottle specs driving his scooter along a Nottingham street. "We've approached major retailers, but, unfortunately, perhaps because of the cover, most of them have not even listened to the record. Universal Records are distributing it, but we still have to transfer that into sales and convince retailers that it's not a novelty act. "But we have used the sleeve that Reg wanted. We haven't tried to portray him as something he is not. It might not be a normal thing for most record-buyers to drive down the street on a motor scooter, but it's a normal thing if you are Reg Cooper." Beautiful Day will be released on CCM next month.

fields.headline: Let's get physical
fields.standfirst: Is it true, as a new report suggests, that women are put off taking exercise by the sight of beautiful young sportswomen such as Anna Kournikova?  Anita Chaudhuri runs through the evidence
fields.trailText: Is it true, as a new report suggests, that women are put off taking exercise by the sight of beautiful young sportswomen such as Anna Kournikova?  Anita Chaudhuri runs through the evidence
fields.body:
Here's a little quiz. When you are in the gym pounding away on the PowerJog, what is running through your mind. Is it:
a) "Wow, there's cute"?

b) "Only 15 more minutes of this torture, then I can scoff a carton of chocolate ginger ice-cream"?

c) "Ooh, look at her over there, does she really think the Lycra thong was a wise option?"?

d) "Right, that's 800m in 6 minutes 38 seconds. Not long to go before I match the 2 minutes 20 seconds speed of Denise Lewis"?

Don't worry - unless you answered d, you are perfectly normal. No, really, you are. According to Dr Precilla Choi, a feminist psychologist based at Keele University, most women exercise in order to boost their sexual attractiveness rather than their sporting prowess. "Physical exercise has become the latest commodity in the highly commercialised beauty culture," she asserts, in a paper just presented to the British Association. "Instead of being promoted to women as a way of improving physical and psychological health, it is promoted as a way of improving their sex appeal through losing weight and improving muscle tone and appearance."

She also claims that attractive sportswomen such as Anna Kournikova are putting women off taking up exercise. "The belief that beauty will result from exercise can also translate into a belief that one has to be beautiful in order to exercise. This prevents women from exercising."

This sounds like a sweeping generalisation to me. Is it really fair to blame Kournikova and her "no bounce" bra ads entirely for the fact that eight out of 10 British women are not taking enough exercise? After a grim day at work, when we put off going weight-training, are we doing so because, as Choi claims, we suddenly feel there is no point because we will never achieve that level of physical perfection anyway? Or are we avoiding physical exercise because we are lazy and slothful, and the pub sounds like more fun?

Aha, I thought so. Yes, gyms tend to attract people who are concerned about their body image, but that goes for muscle-popping men as much as for hollow-cheeked women. It is true that one needs only to spend five minutes in a changing room to realise that weight loss is a major factor in some women's attendance. Female locker rooms are dominated not by personal bests but by endless diet targets. "Only another 10 pounds to go" is a depressingly familiar mantra.

Yet for every dieter, there is another woman who is there because she actually enjoys the rush of endorphins a good work-out releases. Exercise isn't just about the physical body; sport has been shown to boost self-confidence and self-esteem, and to help reduce self-destructive behaviour such as compulsive eating, drinking and smoking.

Back in 1994, a study entitled Perceptions of Female Body Shapes as a Function of Exercising found that exercisers rated themselves as more attractive, confident, healthy and popular, and had much higher body satisfaction than non-exercisers, despite being significantly heavier than the women surveyed who did not exercise. While it is regrettable that women often only think of taking up exercise because they want to lose weight, hopefully many soon ditch the diet once they begin to enjoy mastering their own speed and strength.

Personally I love the fact that every time I run a mile, my time gets a tiny, tiny bit faster, allowing for superhero-type fantasies. Ultimately speed is far more thrilling than weight loss. Certainly, a lot of the blame for the exercise-weight loss connection lies with the people who run gyms. "And how much weight are you wanting to lose?" is still a stock question during many gym induction programmes, regardless of whether a woman is, heaven forbid, happy with her weight.

This is unhealthy because, apart from anything else, it creates a culture of competition between women. "How much have you lost?" is such a pointless question when what locker room bonding should be about is sharing gossip and mutual support.

In the run-up to the Sydney Olympics, much has been made of the cultural conspiracy that exists to keep women out of sport. In her controversial book The Frailty Myth, Colette Dowling suggests that physical equality is the real final frontier of women's liberation. "Strength has a withering effect on male identity. To salvage men's failing sense of dominance (post industrial revolution), women were encouraged to scale back their own physical development. Sport is the last place that men, no longer supremely dominant, can assert their body strength and masculinity. Men need to keep women weak, off the football field and out of the boxing ring, so they can continue to feel strong."

Dowling reckons it is only a matter of time before women start competing with men on the playing field. They had better watch out then. I reckon that by about 2012, I'll be fast enough to take them on.

fields.headline: Kingfisher tale defies logic
fields.trailText: Sometimes the City appears to defy logic. Take yesterday. Kingfisher , the retail conglomerate, rose sharply despite unveiling a lousy set of interim figures and a veiled warning on profits for the rest of the year.
fields.body:
Sometimes the City appears to defy logic. Take yesterday. Kingfisher , the retail conglomerate, rose sharply despite unveiling a lousy set of interim figures and a veiled warning on profits for the rest of the year.

With some analysts bringing their full year profit forecasts down to just £670m (the consensus forecast before Wednesday was £799m), Kingfisher shares ended 24p higher at 477.5p, after 33.3m shares had changed hands

For sure, Kingfisher's plans to demerge its general merchandising arm (Woolworth and Superdrug) from its higher growth DIY and electricals operations (B&Q and Comet) helped. On top of that there were a number of bears closing short positions in the stock.

But try as they might, retail analysts across the Square Mile could not come up with a realistic valuation - given current trading conditions - for Kingfisher shares much above 500p. Even the most optimistic figure, one based on the best of all possible scenarios, was only 550p.

The real reason for sharp rise it seems was a feeling that the company is now in play. The name on everybody's lips yesterday was Home Depot, the world's largest DIY retailer.

Analysts reckon that Home Depot, which has around 1,000 stores, has been considering a move into the European DIY market for a while. Capitalised in excess of £70b, it could certainly afford a bite a Kingfisher, which even after yesterday's gains is only worth around £6.2bn.

Kingfisher was not the only retailer attracting attention. Beleaguered Marks & Spencer shot up 17p, or 8.06%, to 228p on very heavy turnover of 35.7m. The trigger for the gain was news that Terry Green had stepped down as chief executive of Debenhams , down 17.5p to 182.5p.

First of all there was the speculation that Mr Green would be joining M&S. Once this rumour was quashed by the M&S press office, punters started to speculate on the possibility that Mr Green could link up withformer Asda boss Allan Leighton and corporate raider Philip Green and mount an offer for the embattled high street retailer.

It sounded a tall tale but no one was prepared to dismiss it. After all, Mr P Green had the backing to launch an offer for Marks & Spencer earlier this year and was said to have talked to both Mr Leighton and Mr T Green about such a move at the time.

Dealers also noted speculation that a US retailer was about to make an offer for Marks & Spencer.

Leading shares, meanwhile ended down for a seventh consecutive session - their biggest run of losses in over a year - as a spate of profit warnings from the US added to the growing unease about the impact of the fuel crisis.

At the close the FTSE 100 was 77.3 points weaker at 6,478.2, its lowest close in over four weeks. Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 rose 1.2 to 6,908.9 and the Techmark fell 43.22 to 3,921.35.

The market's biggest stock Vodafone , down 8.75p to 264.25p, led the retreat, with oil heavyweights Shell , 16.5p lower at 600p, and BP , off 9.5p at 655.5p, not helping matters.

Elsewhere, speciality chemicals group ICI fell to a two-year low in the wake of a profit warning from US paint maker Sherwin-Williams. It recovered to close down 1p at 433p.

Logistics group Excel recovered some of Tuesday's losses on the back of talk that UBS Warburg had upgraded the stock to "buy" from "hold". Excel ended 40p better at £10.50.

Lower down, marketing group Aegis rose 10p to 164.75p as Merrill Lynch finished placing 27m shares at 151p. The placing had artificially depressed Aegis's stock price on Tuesday. News of a Renault contract win also helped.

Sportsworld Media fell 10p to 545p, despite dealers pointing out that the company has a 3% stake in AIM newcomer Sports Resource which closed 127.5p above its placing price.

fields.headline: End of the Tesco run
fields.trailText: Tesco has enjoyed a healthy run but analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson believe further upward moves are unlikely.
fields.body:
Tesco has enjoyed a healthy run but analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson believe further upward moves are unlikely.

The broker, which describes itself as cautious about the supermarkets sector, is particularly concerned that Tesco could feel the pain of dull consumer spending, price competition and any regulatory changes introduced by the competition commission.

Dresdner's analysis notes that Tesco's stockmarket rating across a wider European measure has started to match its continental counterparts. Pressures in the UK are likely to force a rerating of the stock in the coming months.

With Tesco also embarking on an ambitious overseas expansion programme, Dresdner has lowered its price target for the stock to 185p, down from the 214.5p to which the shares climbed yesterday.

fields.headline: No: 1720 Boules
fields.trailText: Aka: Pétanque; Jeu Provençal; That game some people play on the beach.
fields.body:
Aka: Pétanque; Jeu Provençal; That game some people play on the beach.

Age: About 90. But the tradition of throwing balls at a stationary object is rumoured to go back to Roman times. Motorways, drainage systems, boules. Truly they were a master race.

But it took the French to make it an artform? Indeed it is practically the national game, with at least 500,000 players in France alone.

And what are the rules of the quaint gallic sport? Boules is a game of two people or teams, played on a pitch some 15m long and 4m wide. Players take turns to throw or roll a ball as close as possible to another ball, known as the cochonnet. A contestant may knock an opponent's ball out of the way, if necessary. Think crown green bowling, with a certain je ne sais quoi.

Mmm, sounds like a suitable activity for a leisurely Sunday afternoon. Hardly. Boules is a serious matter. It is Gerard Depardieu's sport of choice. This summer, boules-mania has swept France, with pop stars, film stars and politicians lining up to be snapped mid-pétanque.

Blimey. Sounds a bit cut-throat. No throats cut as yet, but it's only a matter of time. A boy was recently knocked unconscious by a boule which was flung into the crowd by an irate contestant. This was a considerable distance from the cochonnet, and therefore did not assist his game in any way.

And I take it this prompted copycat boule-lobbing attacks across France? Merely days later, a tussle broke out between two players on a campsite in Vif, near Grenoble. Boules were hurled, and a man was shot dead with a rifle. The use of rifles is not permitted in the sport of boules.

Do say: Good shot, Monsieur!

Don't say: You throw like a girl.

fields.headline: At this price?  Regent Inns
fields.trailText: Comedians wishing to emulate Paul Merton, Ben Elton, Harry Enfield, and Jack Dee will soon have new venues to hone their acts.
fields.body:
Comedians wishing to emulate Paul Merton, Ben Elton, Harry Enfield, and Jack Dee will soon have new venues to hone their acts.

Regent Inns yesterday said it was planning to more than double the size of its Jongleurs comedy club chain, and to increase the number of days each club is open.

At present the clubs, where many of today's top comedians cut their teeth, are only open at the group's Bar Risa premises from Thursday to Sunday. Regent is planning to expand the Bar Risa/Jongleurs chain from eight to 20 premises and double the size of its Australian-themed Walkabout large pub chain to 40 sites by 2003.

Stephen Haupt, Regent's chief executive, said the £60m investment would be funded by the group's own free cash flow and by its existing borrowing facilities.

The group will be concentrating on its two branded chains. Walkabout premises had an average gross weekly take of £39,571 last year, while the Bar Risa/Jongleurs sites took £41,860 a week on average. Regent's estate of about 100 non-branded pubs is not expected to change significantly during the year.

The Walkabout premises, which include bars, restaurants, and live sport on large screens, saw business boom during the six nations rugby tournament and the Euro2000 football competition.

Mr Haupt said he was not sure the Sydney Olympics would provide a similar boost since only recordings could be shown because of the time difference.

The Walkabout chain accounted for 37% of Regent's £79.6m sales during the year to July 1. The full year figures, announced yesterday, show that group pre-tax profits rose from £10.9m to £13.5m on the back of a 35% jump in sales. A final dividend of 2.91p a share will lift the total for the year to 4.48p - 10% up on last year.

There is no sign that Regent's branded pubs are losing their popularity. The shares, up 1.5p to 118.5p yesterday, are worth holding.

fields.headline: Restoration
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Crook, Co Durham

A decade of opencast mining removed many of the old hedgerows in the triangle of land between Crook, Billy Row and Tow Law. They were replanted when the land was restored and from a distance their replacements, now head-high, look like long-standing elements of the landscape. Walk alongside them, though, and the difference is obvious.

The new are neat, dense, double rows of hawthorn, sometimes with a sprinkling of dog rose, hazel and blackthorn, punctuated with evenly placed hedgerow trees. The old, like those that flank the Mile Lonnen, a dead-straight coal road that cuts across the landscape, are a jumbled mixture of gnarled oaks and wizened crab apples, hazel, holly, bramble, gorse, and downy rose with its fruity-scented, resinous leaves. Here and there, garden escapes have crept in: a patch of snowberry, a thicket of lilac, a rampant tangle of the Japanese Rosa rugosa.

The flora under the old hedges distinguishes them too - a rich mixture of knapweed, heath bedstraw, hemp nettle, burdock, foxgloves, tufted vetch and harebells. Scattered heathers hint that this was once, in the distant past, heathland.

One legacy of the opencast has made a significant contribution to increasing biodiversity. Hidden behind the old hedges, a large pond - developed from a settling pond used to trap silt from rainwater run-off during opencasting - has been colonised by dragonflies.

Today, on an oppressively hot afternoon, we sat and watched. Thunder rumbled and lightning crackled over distant moorland in Weardale but here, in this small triangle of land that has been repeatedly mined, cultivated, stripped bare and restored over the past three centuries, sunlight sparkled on the surface of the pond. Electric-blue spotted Aeshna and deep red Sympetrum species hawked over the reed mace and through the alders. A decade ago, there would have been a cacophony of draglines, bulldozers and lorries around this spot. This afternoon you could hear the rattle of dragonfly wings and the wind rustling through the reeds.

fields.headline: Letter: Jack Simmons
fields.trailText: Peter Clark writes:
fields.body:
Peter Clark writes:

In the late 1960s Jack Simmons (Obituary, September 13) supervised my PhD. We had a methodological difference about the writing. I was in awe of him and unable to articulate my point of view convincingly. He recommended that I should not submit it, but I did, and at the viva with Jack and Geoffrey Best, the external examiner, of whom I was not in awe, the methodological issue came up, and I was able to argue my point clearly and successfully to him. Jack smiled silently, Geoffrey was persuaded, and I was awarded the PhD. But it took 20 years before Jack would write to me, addressing the envelope with Dr.

fields.headline: Antoni Janusz
fields.trailText: In the annals of ballooning, Captain Antoni Janusz of Poland, who has died aged 98, is famous. His greatest triumph was to win the long-distance Gordon Bennett race in 1938.
fields.body:
In the annals of ballooning, Captain Antoni Janusz of Poland, who has died aged 98, is famous. His greatest triumph was to win the long-distance Gordon Bennett race in 1938. As the winner's nation was entitled to host the next year's race, this meant that the 1939 event was scheduled to start from Lwow, Poland, in early September, a date also chosen by Germany for its invasion of Poland. The peacetime pursuit of crossing one another's frontiers by balloon had been brutally transformed into the crossing of such frontiers by military means.

At the time of the invasion, Captain Janusz, of the Polish Air Force, was duty officer at Warsaw airport. He had already served in the first world war, having been awarded a medal for valour in fighting against the Russians. In 1939, he and others of his unit escaped first to Romania before reaching Yugoslavia, then Greece, and eventually France. There he joined the French Air Force, serving as liaison officer, until he had to move once more. In London, he first worked with the Air Ministry, again as liaison officer, and later with the RAF.

The winning flight of 1938 had started from Liège, Belgium, on September 11. Bad weather had been forecast. Janusz and his companion first met rain and then entered cloud, not seeing the ground - or indeed anything - for the next 30 hours. Only when they had reached Bulgaria did the cloud relent, and they were able to establish their position. Amazingly, and armed only with a portable radio, they had kept track of their flight by listening to the local broadcasts. As such a voyage took them over countries speaking French, German, Hungarian, Serbo-Croat and eventually Bulgarian, navigation was hardly simple.

They landed at Troyan, some 128 kilometres east of Sofia, after travelling 1,692 kilometres over 37 airborne hours, beating a Belgian and a Pole by 248 kms. It took time after their landing to discover they had won, and Poland then gave them a terrific welcome home.

While working at the Air Ministry, Antoni Janusz met Jean Oilier, whom he married after the war. He later became a vice-president of the British Balloon and Airship Club. He is survived by Jean.

fields.headline: John Simpson
fields.standfirst: Atom scientist who became an anti-bomb campaigner after Hiroshima, and championed international cooperation in space exploration
fields.trailText: Atom scientist who became an anti-bomb campaigner after Hiroshima, and championed international cooperation in space exploration
fields.body:
John Simpson, who has died aged 83, was one of the most prolific inventors of scientific instruments for space exploration. For more than 40 years, streams of data have flowed back to Earth from the devices he built for more than 30 American and Soviet spacecraft. Some of them will beam information back for over another decade, pushing back the frontiers of knowledge about the distant reaches of the solar system.

The first of his instruments was carried into space in 1958; the last two were launched only last year. One of these was on board the Ulysses, a satellite now in orbit round the Sun's south pole. The other was carried on Stardust, a mission to rendezvous in 2004 with Comet Wild-2, a frozen snowball one and a half miles in diameter.

But Simpson's career began as a nuclear physicist, when he was recruited by Chicago University for the Manhattan atomic bomb project. At the end of the second world war he abandoned weapons work to become one of the world's leading astrophysicists, and encouraged international cooperation among scientists. Even in the depths of the cold war, he promoted cooperation in research and the free exchange of ideas between Soviet and western scientists. He also turned to campaigning against the use of nuclear weapons, and was co-founder of the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists, still an influential international forum for debate and lobbying on matters of global security and nuclear issues.

Simpson was born in Portland, Oregon. He took his first degree at Reed College in Portland in 1940, and then studied nuclear physics at New York University. From 1943-46 he was a scientific group leader for the Manhattan project at the University of Chicago.

On August 7 1945, the day after the United States dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Simpson and his colleagues organised the Atomic Scientists of Chicago to oppose the further use of nuclear weapons and promote the peaceful use of nuclear power under international control. Simpson was the group's first chairman. The physicists were fortunate in the support they had from Robert Hutchins, the chancellor of Chicago University; he gave them free rein to organise scientists around nuclear policy issues.

Simpson recalled being invited with Eugene Rabinowitch, another Manhattan project scientist, that September to meet a friend of Hutchins. He turned out to be Henry Luce, the influential publisher of Time, Life, and Fortune magazines. After hearing their story, Luce offered the scientists two full pages in Life to tell it.

In those pre-TV days, two pages in Life was an unparalleled public platform. The story was a distillation of ideas that many Manhattan project scientists had debated among themselves for over a year. In the October 29 1945 issue of Life, they said that scientists for the first time had recognised a moral responsibility to carry the warning of the danger of any further use of nuclear weapons.

Hutchins also encouraged the scientists to spend time in Washington, lobbying Congress for the civilian control of atomic energy in the US, and for the international control of atomic energy under UN auspices. Simpson was an adviser to Senator Brien McMahon of Connecticut, chairman of a special committee on atomic energy and sponsor of the McMahon Act of 1946, which called for civilian control of its use.

Simpson later revealed that even before the bomb was tested, many Manhattan Project scientists had concluded that they were morally compelled to try to influence, within the constraints of secrecy, how the bomb would be used in the war, or even whether it should be used at all. Before the first test, many of the team at Chicago tried to do just that. They did not want to see the bomb used against Japan unless that nation was fully warned, and suggested various secret channels through which Japanese representatives might witness a demonstration.

Only years after the war, as layers of secrecy were lifted and the full military and political aspects came into focus, did it become clear to Simpson that the use of the bomb was not likely to have been influenced by a few dozen scientists in Chicago. But that did not stop the pursuit of the principle that scientists and engineers could no longer remain aloof from the consequences of their work.

Simpson's hugely productive career in astrophysics began when he turned his attention to investigating cosmic rays, the subatomic particles ejected from exploding stars that bombard Earth from all directions at nearly the speed of light. In 1948 he invented a neutron monitor to measure the intensity of cosmic rays, which he deployed at stations from Chicago to the magnetic equator in Peru.

He discovered that cosmic ray bombardment was less intense near the equator, and suggested that this was probably due to the Earth's magnetic fields somehow eliminating the lower-energy cosmic rays here on Earth. His cosmic ray detectors were later sent to Mercury, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn.

Simpson was involved in a fly-by of Venus, nine planetary encounters and dust experiments on two Soviet Vega spacecraft that investigated Halley's comet, for which he received the Gagarin Medal for Space Exploration of the USSR Academy of Sciences in 1986, to add to his many awards and posts; at Chicago, he was professor from 1954, and emeritus professor from 1987.

His instruments have measured a solar flare, and provided evidence that the Sun's magnetic field probably has a big effect on where in the solar system the solar wind blows. Equipment he built for Pioneer 10, launched in 1972, may just now be reaching the limits of solar gusts, some 75 times the Earth's distance from the Sun.

Simpson was still gathering information from Pioneer 10 last year. Another of his inventions, aboard the Cassini spacecraft, will collect and analyse dust particles in Saturn's rings.

His second wife, Elizabeth, and his children Mary Ann and John from his first marriage survive him.

John Alexander Simpson, nuclear physicist and astrophysicist, born November 3 1916; died August 31 2000

fields.headline: Ginetta Sagan
fields.standfirst: A torture victim, she fought back against oppression
fields.trailText: Ginetta Sagan, an irrepressible human rights campaigner, who has died in California aged 75, earned her sobriquet Topolino (or Little Mouse) as an anti-Fascist partisan in Italy.
fields.body:
Ginetta Sagan, an irrepressible human rights campaigner, who has died in California aged 75, earned her sobriquet Topolino (or Little Mouse) as an anti-Fascist partisan in Italy. Although she never grew taller than five feet, she made up for her diminutive stature with passion, courage and infectious effervescence.

Mussolini's Black Brigade captured her in February 1945. For three months she endured rape and torture - experiences which spurred her quest to fight oppression. In later life Ginetta Sagan was to become a leading light in Amnesty International. She set up its first branch in the western US in 1968, pioneered its direct mailing campaigns, and later became honorary chair of its board of directors.

Together with her husband, Leonard Sagan, she helped expand the number of Amnesty US members from 700 to 70,000 between 1971-77. Her own Aurora Fund monitors human rights and supports the families of political prisoners. In 1994 Amnesty created the Ginetta Sagan Fund to honour those battling the mistreatment of women and children. It has given prizes of $10,000 to like-minded women from Bhutan, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Rwanda, Guatemala and Peru.

In 1996 Ginetta received two of the highest civilian awards available - the Presidential Medal of Freedom from Bill Clinton and the Grand Ufficiale del Merito della Repubblica from President Scalfaro of Italy.

Yet one incident, 50 years earlier, symbolised Ginetta's mission (it forms the centrepiece of Mary Finley's 1995 biography of Sagan, The Matchbox). A guard flung a loaf of bread into her cell as she was awaiting yet another bout of interrogation. Tearing it open, she discovered a matchbox. Inside was a slip of paper bearing the word, "Corragio!" Soon afterwards two Reichswehr deserters (allies of the partisans) burst into the compound and freed her. Nuns at a nearby hospital nursed Ginetta back to health. Recipients of the Sagan Award today get a little crystal matchbox to remind them that no matter how lonely and forlorn their struggle may seem, someone outside cares.

Both Ginetta's parents had been active anti-Fascists in Milan. Her father, a Catholic physician, was arrested and shot in September 1943. Her Jewish mother, also a doctor, died in Auschwitz. Newly orphaned and aged just 17, Ginetta joined the partisan movement, Giustizia e Liberta. She soon proved agile and cunning - passing messages to the Allies, printing and distributing clandestine anti-Fascist pamphlets, and bringing food and clothing to those in hiding.

Ginetta also smuggled some 300 Jews and other "state enemies" across the border to neutral Switzerland - often under the noses of Nazis, who were being entertained at diversionary parties. Comrades placed bells on goats, and guided them to holes in the barbed wire fence marking the Italian-Swiss border. Ginetta would then listen out for the telltale chimes, and lead her own flock to freedom.

In 1948 she left for Paris, where she studied child development at the Sorbonne. There she befriended René Cassin, the French jurist and guiding light behind the International Declaration of Human Rights. She continued her studies at the University of Chicago in 1951, where she met and married Leonard Sagan. The couple lived in Washington DC, Boston and Japan, before in 1967 settling with their three sons near San Francisco. Leonard, a public health physician and environmental activist, was a pillar of strength to Ginetta until his death in 1998. The couple founded a medical committee to investigate torture in 1973. Today their fledgling outfit has grown into a global network of dedicated professionals.

No one could accuse Ginetta Sagan of partiality. She highlighted the crimes of the military junta in Greece with a hugely successful concert in 1971 featuring Melina Mercouri and Joan Baez; revealed the extent of CIA complicity in the 1973 Chile coup; and fought to free prisoners of conscience jailed in apartheid South Africa. Yet Sagan equally castigated Communist states for their abuses. In 1983 she and Stephen Denney released an excoriating report on Vietnam's maze of "re-education camps". Nearly a million people vanished into this pernicious yet hitherto unknown gulag after 1975. Through persistent lobbying, Sagan secured the release of some 600 prisoners. Her report (updated in 1990) remains a model of clarity and clinical detail.

Ginetta Sagan was one of life's natural raconteurs. Her lilting voice and ready laughter might have given the impression of levity, were it not for her preternatural ability to inspire others, and her unflinching devotion to her cause. "Silence in the face of injustice is complicity with the oppressor," she once wrote.

Sagan certainly knew the risks she was running. In 1987, while visiting dissidents in Poland, her car "accidentally" lost its steering and overturned, leaving her badly injured. Despite the onset of the cancer that eventually killed her, throughout the 1990s she drew attention to child victims of war and rights violations in Algeria and Tibet.

She is survived by her three sons.
